headline: How to Dispute Surprise Medical Bills
text: In October, I received a doctor‚Äôs bill for $21,500 for treatment my daughter received in the emergency room of a local hospital after suffering a one-inch cut on her forehead. I remember opening the bill while walking down my driveway and nearly having a heart attack: How could 10 measly stitches possibly cost more than 20 grand? And why were we being billed for services we‚Äôd received at a hospital that was in our insurance company‚Äôs network?

headline: The Single Best Guide I‚Äôve Heard to the Supreme Court‚Äôs Rightward Shift
text: In the past few weeks alone, the Supreme Court has delivered a firestorm of conservative legal victories. States now have far less leeway to restrict gun permits. The right to abortion is no longer constitutionally protected. The Environmental Protection Agency has been kneecapped in its ability to regulate carbon emissions, and by extension, all executive branch agencies will see their power significantly diminished.

headline: The Supreme Court‚Äôs E.P.A. Decision Is More Gloom Than Doom
text: Many of the headlines about the Supreme Court‚Äôs 6-to-3 ruling on West Virginia v. Environmental Protection Agency on Thursday have suggested an existential setback: a major blow to American decarbonization and global climate ambition. But the effect is less like a nail in the coffin and more like putting an additional set of brakes on an already stalled project. For the time being, at least, the decision functions chiefly to cement the status quo.

headline: Beer Runs, Porcupine Hunts, Jars of Teeth and Much More

headline: What Makes a Fetus a Person?
text: Dobbs v. Jackson Women‚Äôs Health Organization has returned the issue of abortion to legislatures. There, pro-lifers will work to ensure that unborn children in every jurisdiction are protected by law. Though individual states can (and already have) sought to protect the most vulnerable human beings through ordinary legislation, constitutional protection of unborn children as equal ‚Äúpersons‚Äù under the law remains the movement‚Äôs ultimate ‚Äî if elusive ‚Äî goal.

headline: A Supreme Court Head-Scratcher: Is a Colonial Musket ‚ÄòAnalogous‚Äô to an AR-15?
text: Justice Clarence Thomas‚Äôs majority opinion last Thursday expanding gun rights chisels into constitutional law a questionable and judge-empowering form of historical reasoning intelligible only to a very small number of legal elites. headline: Democrats Need Patriotism Now More Than Ever

In practice it amplifies American division. The year that Independence Day memorializes, 1776, also lends its name to the Trumpist 1776 Project, a riposte to the 1619 Project. The very idea of patriotism risks becoming a partisan marker: In 2019, fully 76 percent of Republicans and only 22 percent of Democrats said they were ‚Äúextremely proud‚Äù to be American, according to Gallup.

headline: ‚ÄòThe Princess‚Äô Review: Holding His Heart in Her Hands
text: Le-Van Kiet‚Äôs fantasy ‚ÄúThe Princess‚Äù opens in a traditional manner, with the trill of Celtic-inspired flutes, a pink sunrise and a slow climb to the top of a spindly tower, where an unnamed princess-bride-to-be (Joey King) lies on a bed strewn with rose petals. But here, the royal beauty feigns sleep. Five minutes into this slender yet vigorous blood-spattered fable, two enemy guards enter to drag our heroine to the chapel ‚Äî and she brutally kills them. Clearly, the classic genre that galvanizes Kiet and the screenwriters Ben Lustig and Jake Thornton doesn‚Äôt hark back to ye olde European fairy tales but rather to the feminist revenge thrillers of the 1970s: works of exploitation and wuxia cinema where warrior women stuck it to the man. With knives.

We soon realize that these are our protagonists ‚Äî R√©my (Fran√ßois Civil), a factory worker, and M√©lanie (Ana Girardot), a lab researcher ‚Äî but that they‚Äôre strangers to one another. headline: A Transformative Term at the Most Conservative Supreme Court in Nearly a Century

headline: Father Figure: The Tortured Life of George Michael
text: In 1993, Princess Diana asked her friend George Michael to help organize a benefit concert for World AIDS Day. Then when it came time for the show to air as a TV special, the English singer insisted on seeing the footage, altering the sequence of performers and recutting the shots of himself onstage because he thought his butt looked big. According to a former BBC producer, ‚Äú‚ÄòNever work with children, animals or George Michael‚Äô became an industry mantra after that.‚Äù

headline: Pay Attention to These Old Women. You‚Äôll Learn Something.
text: Novels featuring older characters are well suited to an exploration of questions about time, history and change. Unlike younger protagonists, they already know who they‚Äôve become and what they‚Äôve made of their lives. They‚Äôre not finished yet, but they are as busy reckoning with the past as they are living in the present. They are in full possession of the bulk of their life‚Äôs trajectory, so their primary aim is to resolve and make sense of things before they die.

headline: A Mermaid Makes for a Strange Kind of Immigrant
text: Off the shores of Black Conch, an imagined island in the Caribbean, in 1976, two American white men and a crew of Black island sailors hook a mermaid and wrestle her out of the water. Almost all the sailors experience a deep unease, ‚Äúa sense of blasphemy,‚Äù at the act of capture: ‚ÄúSo close, she was terrifying, a person there, no doubt about it; a trapped and dying woman.‚Äù The mermaid, Aycayia ‚Äî huge, wounded, furious, utterly vulnerable, ‚Äúcrawling with sea-lice‚Äù ‚Äî brings out powerful impulses in the men: to harm, to possess, to touch, to mark her, despite or even because of the hatred in her ‚Äútinfoil eyes.‚Äù This violent, mesmerizing scene begins ‚ÄúThe Mermaid of Black Conch,‚Äù signaling the book‚Äôs ambition. Monique Roffey‚Äôs sixth novel is a fairy tale: The mermaid casts off her tail, regains her legs, falls in love, battles an ancient curse. But it is a ghost story too, the people and the very land of Black Conch haunted by the island‚Äôs legacy of colonialism and enslavement.

headline: The Week in Business: Spending More, Getting Less
text: Consumers kept spending in May, but they got less for their money. Adjusted for inflation, spending fell in May for the first time this year ‚Äî by 0.4 percent, as spending rose less than prices. Spending was also weaker in the first four months of 2022 than previously believed. Though Americans have hardly stopped making purchases even as prices for gas, groceries, travel and just about everything else rise, there are signs that high prices may be starting to take a toll on demand. Big-ticket items, in particular, have been affected, starting with the housing market, which has cooled off in recent weeks as high prices have combined with rising mortgage rates.

text: ‚ÄúI see the damage and the pain,‚Äù says the longtime host of ‚ÄúOn Being.‚Äù ‚ÄúI also see people tending to that.‚Äù

headline: How to Ask a Stranger For Help
text: ‚ÄúAsking for help is hardly ever as bad as you imagine it will be,‚Äù says Vanessa Bohns, a social psychologist and associate professor of organizational behavior at Cornell University. For research purposes, she and colleagues have sent help-seekers out into cities all over the world to request things from 15,000 strangers. Appealing for assistance ‚Äúfeels socially risky,‚Äù Bohns says. Ask anyway. When asked for help, most people are happy to comply. ‚ÄúWe are a social species,‚Äù Bohns says. ‚ÄúWe default to being agreeable rather than disagreeable.‚Äù

headline: I‚Äôm a High-Risk Obstetrician, and I‚Äôm Terrified for My Patients
text: My wife and I practice in medical fields ‚Äî obstetrics and pediatrics ‚Äî that should be filled with happiness. And often they are, though we have selected sub-specialties that are often shrouded in sadness ‚Äî high-risk obstetrics for me, and pediatric oncology for my wife. We have both watched children die while held in their mother‚Äôs arms.

headline: Forbidden Art and Star-Crossed Lovers in ‚ÄòThe Earthspinner‚Äô
text: ‚ÄúWhat just happened?‚Äù I found myself asking aloud upon coming to the end of ‚ÄúThe Earthspinner,‚Äù Anuradha Roy‚Äôs fifth novel. For several days after reading, I held on to a pinching disappointment ‚Äî the novel closes without resolve, and I found myself returning to the book, wondering why Roy had built a world of such rich possibilities just to leave so many unrealized. Little did I know that this was just the beginning of what would become a complicated journey with the novel, leading me to a deep gratitude for this work.

headline: Liberals Need a Clearer Vision of the Constitution. Here‚Äôs What It Could Look Like.
text: For decades now, the conservative legal movement has been on a mission to remake this nation‚Äôs laws from the bench. And it‚Äôs working. On Friday we released an episode with the legal scholar Kate Shaw that walked through case after case showing how conservative Supreme Court majorities have lurched this country‚Äôs laws to the right on guns, voting, gerrymandering, regulatory authority, unions, campaign finance and more in the past 20 years. And if the Dobbs majority is any indication, this rightward shift is just getting started.

headline: How Gun Violence Changed My Father, Ronald Reagan, and Our Family
text: Forty-one years ago, on a cold, drizzly day in Washington, four people were shot by a young man who had concealed a gun in his jacket. This was long before mass shootings became a frequent reality of our lives. It was long before semiautomatic weapons became commonplace. There were many ‚Äúgood people with guns‚Äù there that day. It made no difference. Four men were shot in a matter of seconds. I am the daughter of one of those men, Ronald Reagan, who came incredibly close to losing his life because the bullets John Hinckley loaded into his gun were devastator bullets, meant to fragment. Meant to kill more efficiently. One of those bullets blew apart James Brady‚Äôs head; he was never the same.

headline: In This Novel, America and the Weather Are Both Extreme
text: The novel of future catastrophe tends to create some distance between where we are now, where we have been and where we are afraid we might be heading. Margaret Atwood has said that she put nothing in her 1985 dystopian classic, ‚ÄúThe Handmaid‚Äôs Tale,‚Äù that hadn‚Äôt already happened. Octavia Butler claimed she was partly inspired by her news-junkie ways to write ‚ÄúParable of the Sower‚Äù (1993) but had hoped it would never have the ring of prophecy. In J.G. Ballard‚Äôs 1962 novel, ‚ÄúThe Drowned World,‚Äù which is set in 2145, the author imagined a punishing climate in which the icecaps have completely melted, and where, for the humans left to study them, ‚Äúthe vast swamps and jungles had been a fabulous laboratory, the submerged cities little more than elaborate pedestals.‚Äù

headline: As Her Album Takes Off, a Musician Struggles to Get Pregnant
text: A musician friend once spent hours in a greenroom with Robin Williams. He said Williams started riffing, and that was it. No one spoke and everyone watched, amazed at the ferocity and speed with which his brain spun out like a racecar on an oil slick.

headline: My Wife and I Lied About Our Son‚Äôs Death. Can I Come Clean if She Won‚Äôt?
text: A few years ago, my son died from an accidental overdose when he took a fentanyl-laced pill. When we got the autopsy report, his mother (we are divorced) wanted to keep the cause of his death a secret. I was reluctant, but in the throes of grief did not make a stand for the truth. We lied and said his death was due to a bad heart.

headline: Famous for Happiness, and Limits on Tourism, Bhutan Will Triple Fees to Visit
text: The tiny Buddhist kingdom of Bhutan on the eastern edge of the Himalayas, often referred to as ‚Äúthe last Shangri-La‚Äù for its abundance of natural beauty, sustainable development and rich cultural heritage, has long resisted the quick financial returns of mass tourism in favor of conservation. The approach is aligned with a cultural philosophy where the country‚Äôs wealth and prosperity is measured, through a national happiness index, as an alternative to the gross domestic product.

headline: Lonely Last Days in the Suburban Office Park
text: The wooded campus that once housed the global headquarters of Toys ‚ÄúR‚Äù Us in Wayne, N.J., is 85 percent vacant today. On a weekday, the parking spots for 1,900 cars are mostly empty. The helipad is unused. So is the corporate dining hall, with its views of the serene grounds. Hundreds of cubicles ‚Äî the spacious old-school kind with the high walls, not the little hot desks popular with employers today ‚Äî sit empty as the property awaits redevelopment into something entirely new.

headline: A Vietnamese Menu Worth the Wait

headline: Restaurant Review: Saigon Social Looks Back at Vietnam
text: Order the banh beo chen at the downtown Vietnamese restaurant Saigon Social and six will show up, arranged in a circle around a dish of seasoned fish sauce. This is as it should be. Like Mormon missionaries, banh beo chen never travel alone. Typically, each of these soft disks of steamed rice flour is the size of an oyster, and a single banh beo would be about as satisfying as a single bluepoint. One is not a serving. Six is a good start.

headline: Ford quarterly sales were up slightly from last year, when chip shortages hurt output.

headline: Ready-to-Sear Skewers From Xiao Chi Jie in Seattle
text: Xiao Chi Jie, a Chinese street food restaurant in Seattle owned by Caleb Wang and Jen Liao, turned to frozen takeout when the pandemic began. They specialized in soup dumplings, which they began shipping nationally in late 2020. Now they have introduced shao kao skewers with nicely spiced marinated boneless beef, lamb and chicken to sear in minutes on a stovetop, grill or even in an air fryer. They‚Äôre an easy nibble with drinks; cook a few for a quick supper, and a platter of them makes a feast. The company also sells dipping sauces.

headline: Salumi and Jerky for Summer Snacking
text: In early spring, Jake Dickson of Dickson‚Äôs Farmstand Meats created a salumi bar at his Chelsea Market store using locally raised meats. The specialties available on their site now include jerky for the trail and salami for picnics, or summer snacking. The company makes 10 or so salumi in flavors like tres chiles, cacio e pepe, pistachio and orange peel, and finocchiona, along with a wide assortment of jerky, including za‚Äôatar, honey and anise, and ghost pepper. All of them are available for nationwide shipping, $10 and up; sizes vary. A gift assortment is $81.

headline: Sardine Soap for Fishy (or Garlicky) Hands
text: Na√¢ma Laufer and Luis Correia, who import wines from Mr. Correia‚Äôs native Portugal, started a second company, My Portuguese Market, last year, selling handcrafted goods from Portugal. They have just introduced a lemon- and sea salt-scented, sardine-shaped soap on a rough cord. It‚Äôs ideal for hands that have been working with seafood, garlic and onions, and it‚Äôs easy to hang near the sink. The cute box makes it giftworthy.

headline: Nearly 90 Years Later, Kossar‚Äôs Expands Its Bialy Operation
text: There‚Äôs no end of bagel stores across New York but for bialys, one name stands out: Kossar‚Äôs Bagels & Bialys. It‚Äôs been a fixture on the Lower East Side since 1936, first as Mirsky and Kossar‚Äôs Bakery, then, as of 1953, just Kossar‚Äôs. Now the company is branching into other neighborhoods, first with a store on the edge of Hudson Yards this week and on the Upper East Side in the fall. The bialy, named for the town of Bialystok, Poland, is not ring-shaped like a bagel, but round and chewy with more of an English muffin texture. They are made with a central depression typically filled with onions and, these days, you-name-it, like everything spices, olives and sun-dried tomatoes. The new store has no seating but also sells pletzels, a type of onion and poppy seed flatbread; bagels; and bagel and bialy sandwiches.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‚ÄòIf You Decide to Flirt With a Stranger‚Äô
text: If you decide to flirt with a stranger by sliding into his Twitter DMs, brew a cup of tea first. Then, sit. Sip the tea. Breathe deeply. Allow yourself to swell with giddiness. Don‚Äôt charge forward, rushing with new messages, just because you cannot tolerate the vulnerability of reaching out. That will result with you picking words in a frenzy, words that you‚Äôll pore over later as you wonder why he stopped replying. It might not be flirtatious to point out dead links on a person‚Äôs website; it‚Äôs sometimes a conversation ender to ask, ‚ÄúDo you have a wife?‚Äù ‚Äî Jay Vera Summer

headline: Americans Are Losing Their Right to Not Conform
text: On June 24 the Supreme Court laid waste to Roe v. Wade and Planned Parenthood v. Casey on the grounds that the right to an abortion is not enumerated in the Constitution and is not deeply rooted in the history and traditions of the United States. As many commentators have noted, similar objections could be lodged against precedents like Griswold v. Connecticut, Lawrence v. Texas and Obergefell v. Hodges, which recognize constitutional protections for contraception, sex and marriage.

headline: The End of the Illusion That Smoking Is a Choice
text: The Food and Drug Administration recently proposed lowering the nicotine content in cigarettes to less addictive levels. If adopted, this regulation would finally test one of the tobacco industry‚Äôs favorite claims: that smoking is a choice. Portraying smoking as a willful, personal decision has long allowed tobacco companies to promote cigarettes even while acknowledging their deadly risks. But the paradigm of individual choice has also guided cigarette regulation, ironically strengthening the industry‚Äôs key talking point ‚Äî until now.

headline: The Rise of the Professional-Athlete Podcast
text: Postgame analysis is an integral part of the sports experience. After the final buzzer, fans take to the internet, television and radio to learn what their teams did to win (made their shots, played defense) or lose (missed their shots, didn‚Äôt play defense). Even the sports-averse can easily picture what this traditionally looks like: four men (maybe three men and one woman), seated behind a long desk, offering sage insights like ‚ÄúI thought they struggled with catching the ball,‚Äù to solemn nods of agreement. And yet, for the entirety of the recently concluded N.B.A. Finals, won by the Golden State Warriors over the Boston Celtics, this kind of analysis was also delivered by a more intimate source: the Warriors‚Äô own Draymond Green, who, following every contest, left the court to analyze the game he‚Äôd just played, as the host of a podcast called ‚ÄúThe Draymond Green Show.‚Äù

headline: Roe Is Dead. How Will Democrats and the G.O.P. Evolve Without It?
text: For nearly 50 years, the issue of abortion has driven voters of all persuasions to the polls. But now that Roe v. Wade has been overturned and the question of reproductive rights has been returned to the states, America‚Äôs political parties are going to have to figure out how to metabolize that energy in the years ahead. To discuss what comes next for Democrats and Republicans alike, host Jane Coaston is joined by Times Opinion columnists Ross Douthat and Michelle Goldberg. As colleagues, they‚Äôve been debating abortion with each other, on this podcast and in the pages of the paper, for years.

headline: The Quest by Circadian Medicine to Make the Most of Our Body Clocks
text: ‚ÄúTime,‚Äù when we give it any thought, tends to strike us as extrinsic, a feature of our landscape: We track our passage through it as if traversing an invisible geography, our progress charted by wristwatch, clock, calendar. Humans didn‚Äôt invent time, of course, but you might reasonably argue that because we invented the units we use to keep track of it ‚Äî hours, minutes, seconds ‚Äî we have every right to tinker with them when we want to. This, at least, was the position the Senate took on March 15, when in a surprise, and surprisingly uncontested, vote it passed the Sunshine Protection Act. The new law would, if the House concurs and the president signs, make daylight saving time permanent, beginning on Nov. 5, 2023.

headline: With a Culture War Raging Around Education, Where Does Art School Fit In?
text: Of all the areas of modern life that have been disrupted as of late, arguably none have suffered quite so absurdly as America‚Äôs system of education. Even to merely list, in oblique terms, a few of the basic problems of schools of all kinds in this country is to stare into the maw of a culture in decline. One major political party has decided the right to own semiautomatic rifles is more important than the lives of children, while the other has done little to counter it; state and federal policy has left young, economically vulnerable adults mired in unnecessary debt that many have no hope of repaying; increasingly mainstreamed extremists want to police behavior among students and teachers and rewrite history books in their favor.

headline: A Brief Guide to the Wide, Wild World of Art Schools and Residencies
text: Future doctors are required to learn anatomy and much else. Lawyers must have a basic grasp of civil and criminal procedure and, in the United States, prove it by passing a bar exam. Today, as the scholar Nicholas Houghton wrote in a 2016 paper on art school curriculums, ‚Äúthere are ever more things that could be taught without there being anything which has to be.‚Äù While particular skills ‚Äî a mastery of perspective, say ‚Äî may have been essential in some eras, in some places, artists now do anything and everything, from cooking food to social justice work to having specialists fabricate supersize sculptures for them and even, at least in the case of Sergio Mu√±oz Sarmiento, attending law school, as part of their practice.

This aside, it‚Äôs usually a matter of weighing the benefits ‚Äî namely training and time and space to think and make work ‚Äî against the often literal and sometimes substantial costs. There‚Äôs no clear answer, but what is clear is that art school alone cannot make you an artist, or shield you from self-doubt, uncertainty or rejection. Perhaps for this reason, some artists are most grateful for the sense of community provided by those they met while students ‚Äî often a classmate or teacher becomes a lifelong friend, collaborator or mentor, someone who shows up regardless of the state of the other person‚Äôs career.

headline: Poem: Sister Song
text: The ghazal is a formal poem that has roots in seventh-century Arabia and was often sung by musicians. The poet Agha Shahid Ali introduced the form to America. ‚ÄúGhazal‚Äù literally means ‚Äúthe cry of a gazelle‚Äù as it is being chased and about to die. Like many formal poems such as the sonnet, the ghazal, with its restrictions, can paradoxically illuminate and parse difficult emotions. In L√≥pez‚Äôs poem, the emotion is grief ‚Äî a longing for and memory of a murdered brother. This poem mostly follows the parameters of a ghazal with its repeated end word, ‚Äúsong,‚Äù and the inside rhyme of ‚Äúforever,‚Äù ‚Äúfar,‚Äù ‚Äúmarred,‚Äù etc., as well as the poet‚Äôs name or reference to the poet (‚ÄúSister‚Äù) in the final line. One way this poem breaks the rules is that each couplet doesn‚Äôt stand alone as if it were its own poem. Instead, the end of the couplets often bleed into the next stanza, linking the narratives. Selected by Victoria Chang

headline: It‚Äôs Time to Stop Living the American Scam

I came out, in my essay, as anti-busy; I advocated idling, daydreaming, hanging out and goofing off. My conclusion: ‚ÄúLife is too short to be busy.‚Äù

headline: Why Are We Still Talking About Black Mountain College?
text: Among the most enduring and evocative images of Black Mountain College ‚Äî the experimental liberal arts school in rural North Carolina that was founded during the depths of the Great Depression, and that fostered the talents of numerous artists during the uniquely hopeful and propulsive period that followed World War II ‚Äî are several photographs of R. Buckminster (Bucky) Fuller, the eccentric inventor and designer, attempting to construct his first large-scale geodesic dome. It was the summer of 1948, and Fuller, who was a faculty member in residence at the school ‚Äî along with the likes of Willem and Elaine de Kooning, John Cage, Merce Cunningham, Peter Grippe, Beaumont Newhall and Richard Lippold ‚Äî had brought with him rolls of aluminum Venetian-blind scrap stock and enlisted students and faculty to help him build.

headline: The Enduring Appeal of the Self-Taught Artist
text: ART SCHOOL, AT least as it exists in the U.S., is a relatively new invention. The availability of a degree in fine arts, and the expectation that an artist earn one, became typical around the end of World War II, when the G.I. Bill afforded veterans the ability to attend colleges and universities. Before then, aspirants to the art world largely figured out the mechanics themselves, through apprenticeships, maybe, or informal classes at independent schools like the Art Students League of New York, where working artists like the painter Thomas Hart Benton instructed Jackson Pollock, even if the instruction shaded toward the antagonistic (Benton despised abstraction; Pollock said the only thing that he learned from the older artist was how to drink a fifth of whiskey a day).

headline: Here‚Äôs to Your Health

Colonizing observers had to copy the Indigenous peoples‚Äô use of South American cinchona tree bark (which contains the alkaloid quinine), before someone got the notion to mix quinine with carbonated mineral water ‚Äî along with the juniper-infused gin spirit that had its own medicinal history around Europe.

headline: The Outer Limits
text: There is something ineffable about the appeal of the outer reaches of Cape Cod to generations of writers, artists and architects. Maybe it‚Äôs simply that, as Thoreau observed, ‚Äúa man may stand there and put all America behind him.‚Äù Maybe ‚Äî and this was certainly true for the first part of the 20th century ‚Äî it was the place‚Äôs remoteness and isolation, the sense that as the land reaches out toward the Atlantic, in a single long, crooked limb, the present conventional world slips away, allowing you to rethink, reinvent and get away with all manner of things. Maybe a sort of pre-modern living ‚Äî with so few amenities and creature comforts ‚Äî drew the urban cliques who gravitated there, repelled as many were by the excesses of capitalism.

text: ‚ÄúBlack Bird,‚Äù a new mini-series on Apple TV+ (premiering Friday) that dramatizes a creepy Midwestern true-crime story from the 1990s, has some significant names attached to it. headline: What‚Äôs in Our Queue? ‚ÄòDialogues‚Äô and More

headline: No. 2 Theranos Executive Found Guilty of 12 Counts of Fraud
text: SAN JOSE, Calif. ‚Äî Ramesh Balwani, a former top executive at Theranos, was found guilty on Thursday of 12 counts of fraud, in a verdict that was more severe than that of his co-conspirator, Elizabeth Holmes, and that solidified the failed blood-testing start-up as the ultimate Silicon Valley cautionary tale.

headline: The Nihilism of the Minions
text: One of the peculiarities of the collective American memory is that we imagine that moral rigidity steadily declines over time. One generation, through experimentation and immense tolerance, disentangles the hang-ups of their parents, just as their children will ultimately do for them. This, of course, is nonsense. What‚Äôs particularly odd to me is that most of us are fully aware ‚Äî at least on an intellectual level ‚Äî that cultural moralizing ebbs and flows and there is no clear linearity to any of it. But we hold on to the idea that society got ‚Äúfreer‚Äù during our generation (whatever that means) because we want our own youthful indiscretions to have ‚Äúpushed boundaries‚Äù (another useless phrase) and ‚Äúchanged the scope of what was possible‚Äù (ditto). And while we can usually imagine our own children will take that ‚Äúfreedom‚Äù even further, our narcissism forces us to worry that society will crumble as a result. We, in other words, believe we, and only we, have found the perfect level of moral decline.

headline: Rotterdam Won‚Äôt Dismantle Bridge to Allow Jeff Bezos‚Äô Superyacht Through
text: Jeff Bezos will not be able to sail a new, more than 400-foot-long superyacht through the waters of the Dutch city of Rotterdam anytime soon.

headline: Robert Colescott Throws Down the Gauntlet
text: Watch out. A raucous, enthralling exhibition of the great American painter Robert Colescott (1925-2009) has arrived at the New Museum, to revel in and dissect. ‚ÄúArt and Race Matters: The Career of Robert Colescott‚Äù is the first museum exhibition of this artist‚Äôs relentlessly provocative work to be seen in Manhattan since a 1989 show (also at the New Museum) and the most complete yet. It reveals a man who was eventually able to meld his own private demons about race with his country‚Äôs public ones, creating one of the most compelling, simultaneously personal and socially relevant bodies of work in 20th century American painting.

headline: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
text: CRYPTIC CROSSWORD ‚Äî Daily crossword solvers might recognize this puzzle‚Äôs constructor, Alan Arbesfeld, who has been making daily grids for The Times since 1981 ‚Äî 131 in total, nearly all themed. This is his first variety puzzle and his first cryptic crossword. I love it: On one hand, there is something so mysterious and specialized about cryptics; they‚Äôre rare in the United States, and in their native stamping grounds of England their authors (or ‚Äúsetters‚Äù) often go by pseudonyms. On the other hand, what better source for a cryptic puzzle, full of puns and letter manipulation, than a mind that‚Äôs come up with puzzle themes by the dozen and pun entries by the hundreds? I like to think that this puzzle is composed of outtakes and oddities from all of those years of hard work.

headline: With Roe Overturned, Austin‚Äôs Loss Could Be Brooklyn‚Äôs Gain
text: Imagine that you are a young woman setting out on your adult life in the United States of America in 2022. College is behind you; fulfilling personal and professional ambitions in a stimulating place is meant to come next. Ten or 20 years ago, depending on your interests, you might have moved, as if by reflex, to New York or Chicago, to Los Angeles or San Francisco. But those cities have become only more punishingly expensive. The average rental price of an apartment in Brooklyn is now $3,500, up 12 percent over last year, when we were still lingering in the misguided belief that the pandemic had perhaps changed the city irrevocably toward the softer and more accessible. (In Manhattan, the figure jumped 32 percent to $4,800.)

headline: How to Design a Beautiful, Cruel Universe
text: Most kids who play a lot of video games don‚Äôt grow up to become avid readers. Then again, not every kid who reads a lot of books grows up to become an avid reader. Yet, in the diverse taxonomy of the modern gaming audience, there exists the Literary Gamer ‚Äî someone for whom reading and playing are, and always have been, the same voyage. It would never occur to the Literary Gamer that one activity negates the other. If anything, the Literary Gamer believes, reading and playing enhance systematic thinking and the mysteries of imaginative empathy. This reviewer, for better or worse, is an avowed Literary Gamer ‚Äî and I call upon my brothers and sisters to join me in a recitation of  F√ºnke‚Äôs Axiom: ‚ÄúThere are dozens of us! DOZENS!‚Äù

headline: Windswept Views and ‚ÄòGlories Strung Like Beads‚Äô: Exploring Brooklyn by Ferry
text: Looking for a fresh way to scout Brooklyn‚Äôs waterfront? Try a ferry. For $2.75, you can explore ports of call that cradle a bounty of cultural and culinary adventures. Island-hopping from Manhattan can begin at the Pier 11-Wall Street landing, where the salty air is invigorating and anticipation builds as vessels with names like Ferry Godmother, City Fishy and McShiny pull in to whisk you away.

headline: The Robot Guerrilla Campaign to Recreate the Elgin Marbles
text: Few cultural disputes inflame British passions more than the disposition of the Parthenon Marbles. Public debate about the statuary has raged since the early 1800s, when the sculptures and bas-reliefs, which date from 447 B.C. to 432 B.C., were stripped from the Parthenon and other Classical Greek temples on the Acropolis of Athens by agents of Thomas Bruce, a Scottish statesman and seventh earl of Elgin. The marbles were purchased ‚Äî some say looted ‚Äî by Elgin during his time as ambassador to the Ottoman Empire, the occupying power; they have resided in the British Museum since 1817.

headline: Shinzo Abe Is Assassinated With a Handmade Gun, Shocking a Nation
text: TOKYO ‚Äî Shinzo Abe, Japan‚Äôs most influential former prime minister, was stumping on behalf of a junior politician from his party near a train station in Japan‚Äôs old capital city of Nara on Friday morning when he collapsed, bleeding, on the street. He was shot in the neck, doctors said, by a gunman who later admitted he had come to kill him.

headline: Shinzo Abe, Japan‚Äôs Longest-Serving Prime Minister, Dies at 67
text: Shinzo Abe, the longest-serving Japanese prime minister, who made it his political mission to vanquish his country‚Äôs wartime ghosts but fell short of his ultimate goal of restoring Japan as a normalized military power, was assassinated on Friday in the city of Nara, Japan. He was 67.

headline: Sepp Blatter and Michel Platini Acquitted of Fraud
text: Sepp Blatter, the former president of FIFA, and his onetime ally Michel Platini were acquitted of fraud on Friday in the latest attempt by Swiss prosecutors to win a conviction in a sprawling, seven-year investigation into corruption at the highest levels of world soccer.

headline: Being Marina Abramoviƒá, Even When No One‚Äôs Looking
text: The New York-based artist Marina Abramoviƒá is sitting in the kitchen of her house just outside of Hudson when she invites me ‚Äî over FaceTime ‚Äî to join her in Greece this August for a workshop organized by the Marina Abramoviƒá Institute (MAI). ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs only five days. No food, no talking and heavy exercise,‚Äù says the artist, 75, with a chuckle. Abramoviƒá founded the institute in 2007, originally intending to convert a derelict theater built sometime around the 1930s nearby into a top-of-the-line Rem Koolhaas-designed performance space, archive and education center. But when the project‚Äôs budget ballooned out of her control (Koolhaas‚Äôs plans alone were estimated to be $31 million, which didn‚Äôt include the handling of the theater‚Äôs pre-existing asbestos problem) and her fund-raising efforts fell short (a Kickstarter only got her to a little over half a million dollars), Abramoviƒá decided to turn it into something that didn‚Äôt depend on a physical location. Its new slogan? ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt come to us; we come to you.‚Äù

headline: Biodiversity Crisis Affects Billions Who Rely on Wild Species, Researchers Say
text: Billions of people worldwide rely on some 50,000 wild species for food, energy, medicine and income, according to a sweeping new scientific report that concluded humans must make dramatic changes to hunting and other practices to address an accelerating biodiversity crisis.

headline: The Historically Black College Reconsiders the Studio Art Program
text: The fourth edition of H. W. Janson‚Äôs ‚ÄúHistory of Art,‚Äù long the standard introductory text in art history courses, is over 850 pages long, with more than 1,000 illustrations, weighing in at over seven and a half pounds. It aims for the encyclopedic, ‚Äúfrom cave paintings of the Old Stone Age to the latest video art.‚Äù During the fall of 1992, when the artist Derek Fordjour was 18 years old, he lugged the book to class at Pratt Institute in Brooklyn with earnest intentions of pursuing an artistic career. The child of Ghanaian immigrants who had made a home in Memphis, Fordjour had absorbed his parents‚Äô work ethic and respect for education. But something was missing for him in that hefty tome: nearly the entire history of Black art in America.

headline: Waiting for a Slowdown
text: This morning, the Labor Department  reported that employers added 372,000 workers to their payrolls in June. Economists were expecting hiring to have slowed last month, as fewer workers are available or willing to take open jobs, and while consumer spending is slowing as higher interest rates, imposed by the Fed to combat inflation, take their toll.

headline: Boris Johnson Hasn‚Äôt Left, but the Jockeying to Replace Him Has Begun

headline: Jos√© Eduardo dos Santos, Longtime Angolan Ruler, Dies at 79
text: Jos√© Eduardo dos Santos, a onetime Soviet-trained fighter against Portuguese colonial rule who in nearly four decades as Angola‚Äôs president became one of Africa‚Äôs longest-serving rulers ‚Äî and was also accused of corruption on a grand scale ‚Äî died on Friday in Barcelona, Spain, where he had been living in self-imposed exile. headline: Their Wildest Dreams
text: One summer, when I was a single mother raising my second and fourth graders in Brooklyn and the weeks ahead without child care loomed large, my friend Catherine and I rented a farmhouse in upstate New York for a month. She brought her 9-year-old twins, and we let the kids explore the woods while we worked. We gave them a loud whistle and generous boundaries ‚Äî the distant stone wall, the serpentine stream, the neighboring field ‚Äî and sent them off to run wild.

headline: ‚ÄòTrigger Point‚Äô Review: Pure Pressure √† la ‚ÄòLine of Duty‚Äô
text: There are two kinds of people in the world: those who haven‚Äôt seen or heard of the British cop show ‚ÄúLine of Duty‚Äù and those who are rabid fans of it. But it has a loony, breathless intensity that sucks you in and a willingness to toy with its regular characters‚Äô emotions, and question their motives, that is dramatically suspect but melodramatically potent. Through six seasons, it remains one of Britain‚Äôs most popular and honored TV shows.

text: The dance critic Edwin Denby once wrote, ‚ÄúDaily life is wonderfully full of things to see.‚Äù That observation came to mind on Thursday during Momix‚Äôs ‚ÄúAlice,‚Äù a banal and busy 85-minute spectacle now at the Joyce Theater. headline: Why the Overturning of Roe Won‚Äôt Lead to a Return of Segregation
text: Now that the Supreme Court, with its ruling in Dobbs v. Jackson Women‚Äôs Health Organization, has struck down Roe v. Wade, many have argued that the court might begin diminishing or doing away with other expansions of constitutional rights. Much of the reaction traces to Justice Clarence Thomas, who in his concurring opinion in Dobbs argued that ‚ÄúIn future cases, we should reconsider all of this Court‚Äôs substantive due process precedents, including Griswold, Lawrence and Obergefell.‚Äù It was a shot across the legal bow that prompted James Obergefell, one of the petitioners in Obergefell v. Hodges ‚Äî the case that guaranteed same-sex couples a constitutional right to marry ‚Äî to respond, in an interview on CNN last week, that Thomas had ‚Äúput a target‚Äù on ‚Äúthe right to contraception, the right to intimacy with the person you love and the right to marry the person you love,‚Äù and ‚Äúthat should terrify everyone in this nation.‚Äù

text: In 2019, CJ Hauser‚Äôs essay ‚ÄúThe Crane Wife‚Äù went viral, garnering more than a million views on The Paris Review‚Äôs website. Personally, I accounted for at least three of those views, as I read, reread aloud (exclaiming, ‚ÄúGod, she‚Äôs good!‚Äù at the end), and then emailed several friends to demand they also read Hauser‚Äôs story about breaking off a wedding engagement, leaving the home she shared with her fianc√© in upstate New York and going to Texas to research whooping cranes for her second novel. text: A few years ago, a friend of mine sent a vial of his saliva to a DNA testing company hoping to gain clues about his late father‚Äôs Italian ancestry. The results were a shock. He had no Italian blood at all. The man who‚Äôd raised him from infancy, and whose name he carried, was not his biological father. After weeks of checking his results against those of cousins with whom he shared no DNA, he mustered the courage to ask his nonagenarian mother about the findings. ‚ÄúSo I had an affair!‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúWhoever thought there‚Äôd be 23andMe, for chrissakes.‚Äù

headline: When a Professor Trades the Academy for an Art Career of His Own

One class failed to recognize Picasso‚Äôs ‚ÄúGuernica‚Äù but could name Forky, the Picasso-inspired spork character in Toy Story 4. ‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt count anymore if you‚Äôre a gay man of a certain age who went through the AIDS crisis,‚Äù he says from the same drafting table in his studio, a repurposed barn in Germantown, N.Y., where for more than a year he taught via Zoom. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs something that‚Äôs just kind of like, ‚ÄòWell, you‚Äôre a dinosaur.‚Äô‚Äù

headline: Where My Research Has Taken Me Lately
text: Instead of an extended take on a particular issue or question, I thought I would use this weekend‚Äôs newsletter to share some of what I‚Äôve been reading this summer. My job for The Times involves a lot of research, and while some of what I learn shows up in my work in the form of quotes and other direct references, a lot of it doesn‚Äôt. You can think of this reading list as a glimpse into where my head is at right now, and what I am thinking.

headline: U.C.L.A. and U.S.C., Welcome to the Big Ten. I Already Hate You.
text: My favorite college football team is the Michigan Wolverines, which makes the Big Ten my favorite conference. headline: The End of Roe Doesn‚Äôt Need to Bring an Increase in Maternal Mortality

headline: In Rust Belt Ohio, the First American Rape Case to Go Viral
text: It‚Äôs the grim ordinariness of the Steubenville rape case ‚Äî an August 2012 incident involving an unconscious teenage girl, members of a revered high school football team and the small town that protected the perpetrators ‚Äî that shines through most brightly in Nancy Schwartzman‚Äôs ‚ÄúRoll Red Roll.‚Äù A meticulous account of the ‚Äúfirst rape case ever to go viral in the United States,‚Äù the book moves from the facts of one summer night in Rust Belt Ohio into a broader reckoning with American masculinity and the emerging influence of the internet on sexual assault cases. Schwartzman clearly conveys the brutal banality of what happened in that town, the way rape culture, victim blaming and institutional complicity are the rule rather than the exception in American communities. Steubenville could be anywhere.

headline: The Fight Over Truth Also Has a Red State, Blue State Divide
text: To fight disinformation, California lawmakers are advancing a bill that would force social media companies to divulge their process for removing false, hateful or extremist material from their platforms. headline: The Sunday Read: ‚ÄòThe Rise and Fall of America‚Äôs Environmentalist Underground‚Äô

headline: With schools long shut, a father sees the protests in Sri Lanka as education.

headline: The Week in Business: A Rude Awakening for Start-Ups
text: For many tech start-ups, the era of seemingly endless optimism and immunity ‚Äî from scrutiny, skepticism and, most of all, serious legal consequences ‚Äî began to fray when an expos√© on the blood-testing company Theranos was published in 2015 that raised questions about the effectiveness of the company‚Äôs technology. On Thursday, a jury found Ramesh Balwani, Theranos‚Äôs No. 2 executive, guilty of 12 counts of fraud, delivering another potent warning to Silicon Valley. Prosecutors‚Äô evidence against Mr. Balwani showed that he had been deeply involved in almost every aspect of the company and had knowingly misled investors and customers. The verdict was more severe than that of Elizabeth Holmes, the Theranos founder and chief executive, who in January was convicted of four counts of fraud. It also arrives amid other troubling signs in the start-up world: Tech stock prices have plummeted this year, and investors have become more risk averse.

headline: Preserved Citrus From a Sicilian Institution
text: Caff√® Sicilia in Noto, a Baroque town in the hilly southeast corner of Sicily, has been a destination since it opened in 1892. Now owned by Corrado Assenza, the fourth generation of the founding family, it is a resource for some of Sicily‚Äôs most treasured confections. Corrado follows the longstanding tradition of preserving citrus peels slowly, without additives, merely sugared in the final stage of production. Beatrice Ughi‚Äôs Bronx-based company, Gustiamo, now imports the bergamot, orange and lemon varieties, all in large slabs of peel rendered moist, fragrant and arrestingly fresh-tasting. Use them as you would candied fruits in baking, sliver them to season cocktails or use them to dress roast duck, seafood or even pasta. As a nibble, before you know it they‚Äôre gone.

A shopping list that includes Japanese Kewpie mayonnaise, ponzu with yuzu, truffled vegetables and sauces, Moroccan spices, French p√¢tes de fruit and lovely gift boxes of Portuguese tinned sardines can easily be completed from its shelves. After living in the area during Covid, Charles de Viel Castel, a French-born financier, jewelry designer and entrepreneur, decided to fill a need he saw for products he could not find locally. His shop also sells baguettes from Armin & Judy, a nearby restaurant, and flower arrangements from the local florist Missi Flowers. The store is adjacent to a sliver of a market for baked goods and sandwiches from Pierre‚Äôs, a French restaurant, but Mr. de Viel Castel said the two shops seem to complement each other, not compete.

headline: The Democrats Need to Start Playing Offense
text: Over the past few weeks, I‚Äôve received several messages from readers and friends about the need for hopeful alternatives in my work. This request, I believe, is a response to my main preoccupations in this space: homelessness, nursing homes, protests and the increasing failure of Democrats to reach working-class voters, especially immigrants. It‚Äôs true that my forecast for each of these issues is rather bleak, but I understand why readers might want some alternatives.

headline: What Will Post-Roe Medical Care Look Like? A Times Event.
text: When the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade in June, eliminating the constitutional right to abortion, medical providers were faced with a complex patchwork of state-level abortion bans and prohibitions. In Arizona, medical workers wondered if a century-old law banning almost all abortions and punishing providers with prison time meant that they should stop the procedures. In Wisconsin, a district attorney said he would not prosecute abortion cases after an 1849 state law banning them took effect.

headline: Half of G.O.P. Voters Ready to Leave Trump Behind, Poll Finds
text: As Donald J. Trump weighs whether to open an unusually early White House campaign, a New York Times/Siena College poll shows that his post-presidential quest to consolidate his support within the Republican Party has instead left him weakened, with nearly half the party‚Äôs primary voters seeking someone different for president in 2024 and a significant number vowing to abandon him if he wins the nomination.

text: HONG KONG ‚Äî If his cutoff T-shirts, close-cropped hair and long, thin beard were not enough to make Koo Sze-yiu stand out among the masses who took to the streets to protest in Hong Kong, there were also the coffins.

headline: ‚ÄòHarry Sylvester Bird‚Äô Is a Satire of Antiracist Art
text: The eponymous protagonist of Chinelo Okparanta‚Äôs second novel is racist. And the author wants her reader to find him spectacularly, fascinatingly racist, offering up 300 pages of painstaking detail on every microaggression he commits in the first decades of his life.

headline: How to Recover From Being Ghosted
text: ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt have the control in this situation,‚Äù says Gili Freedman, an assistant professor of psychology at St. Mary‚Äôs College in Maryland who studies social rejection. In the past few years she has become particularly interested in ‚Äúghosting,‚Äù a method of ending a relationship by ceasing all forms of communication and simply vanishing ‚Äî like a ghost. Humans, of course, have always been rejecting one another; ghosting is just a newfangled form facilitated by technology, particularly online dating apps.

headline: A Debut Novel Explores Power in Many Forms, From Capital to Dogma
text: When reading as assured a young novelist as Zain Khalid, it‚Äôs worth considering not only the story he tells, but those he chooses not to. ‚ÄúBrother Alive,‚Äù Khalid‚Äôs beguiling debut, caroms among decades and continents, its epistolary structure lending a confessional tone. It‚Äôs a Muslim novel, albeit one concerned less with doctrine than with the gnarled politics of global traditions. It‚Äôs also a queer narrative and a coming-of-age tale, though neither qualifies as the main attraction. The speculative elements that haunt the book contemplate the present instead of imagining a future.

headline: In These Stories, Familiar Archetypes Face Unfamiliar Twists
text: The stories in Rebecca Miller‚Äôs new collection, ‚ÄúTotal,‚Äù are mostly about a certain type of woman, the type who wields her sexuality and vulnerability as twinned powers related to the desire to be cared for and to care for others. But the book is also about the darker, deeper layers of those powers, their dangers, all the ache and trouble that roils beneath them. Each of these characters feels vaguely recognizable ‚Äî the exhausted hapless mother, the promiscuous young girl seduced by a much older man ‚Äî but Miller is cognizant of the complexity that can still breathe inside familiar stories. She helps us reconsider their elasticity, to see from different angles how they pulse with life.

headline: The Power of Talking to Yourself

headline: Metabolizing the World Into Something Wild and Achingly Alive
text: Where novels are often described as ambitious, and omnivorous, short stories are rarely presumed to have appetites ‚Äî to run rampant through the reader‚Äôs mind, ravenous, devouring, feral. The most common metaphors that try to sum up the particular work a short story can do are postcards and photo albums, icebergs and carefully etched cameos: still, patient objects putting themselves on calm display. Perhaps that‚Äôs why the fierce little machines found in the Taiwanese American writer K-Ming Chang‚Äôs first collection, ‚ÄúGods of Want‚Äù ‚Äî the successor to her gutsy debut novel, ‚ÄúBestiary‚Äù ‚Äî feel so unexpected: Each one is possessed of a powerful hunger, a drive to metabolize the recognizable features of a familiar world and transform them into something wilder, and achingly alive.

headline: A Cold War Spy Novel Depicts the Scramble for Stasi Secrets
text: As the Berlin Wall crumbled in 1989, the Stasi, East Germany‚Äôs bloated and brutal Cold War intelligence service, began destroying the documentary evidence of its crimes, and the C.I.A., just as energetically, set about trying to obtain it.

headline: Ada Lim√≥n Is Named the Next Poet Laureate
text: When Ada Lim√≥n quit her marketing job to try writing full time, she assumed that would mean writing fiction. So she spent her working hours imagining the lives of other people. Then, she said, she would plunge into poetry, where she could be herself.

headline: Why Overturning Roe Will Unleash a Legal Storm for the Supreme Court
text: While laying waste to 50 years of abortion jurisprudence, the Supreme Court ‚Äî or at least four of the five members of the new hard-right majority ‚Äî took pains to reassure the country that it had executed an isolated hit on an ‚Äúegregiously wrong‚Äù precedent that would not reverberate in other areas of constitutional law.

headline: Josephine Baker, International Woman of Mystery?
text: In the first half of the 20th century, Josephine Baker was one of the most famous women in the world. Born into poverty in St. Louis, she became a star of the Paris stage in the 1920s. Stories of her walking down the Champs-√âlys√©es with her pet (and sometimes co-star), a cheetah named Chiquita, had already made her the stuff of legend. In ‚ÄúAgent Josephine,‚Äù the prolific historian Damien Lewis goes a step further in burnishing this legend, arguing that Baker was a spy for the British.

headline: As Sixth Covid Wave Hits, Many New Yorkers Shrug It Off
text: New York City‚Äôs Covid-19 test positivity rate is 15 percent, an intensity not seen since January. Transmission levels of the virus, according to federal guidelines, are high in every borough. headline: Earl McGrath Was a Character. His Closet Was Filled With Rare Recordings.
text: An outsize character, Earl McGrath had variously worked as a record company head, film executive, screenwriter and art dealer before he died in early 2016 at age 84. Afterward, the contents of his Midtown Manhattan apartment were carefully cataloged and valued. His art collection, including prized works given to him by Andy Warhol, Cy Twombly and Ed Moses, was sent to auction at Christie‚Äôs. His papers, containing correspondence with Jack Kerouac, Allen Ginsberg and Stephen Spender, were donated to the New York Public Library‚Äôs archives.

headline: A Perfect Weekend in Asbury Park, N.J.
text: To call Asbury Park a secret would betray its tumultuous and storied history: A wellspring of American music, tucked around the swamps of Jersey. A home to national icons. A vibrant L.G.B.T.Q. community. A city that bears the scars of the civil rights movement, blighted for decades by mismanagement and mistrust, that‚Äôs now in the midst of a soaring recovery fueled by the very soul that gave Asbury its reason for being: music.

headline: Drought Tightens Grip on Northern Italy
text: ARRO, Italy ‚Äî Every morning at dawn, Roberto Guerrini walks the perimeters of the paddies in northern Italy where his family has grown rice for four generations to ensure that there are no holes ‚Äî often caused by burrowing animals ‚Äî in any of the earthen embankments.

headline: Can Elon Musk Get Out of Buying Twitter?
text: Last week, Elon Musk announced that he was pulling out of his $44 billion agreement to purchase Twitter. Today, we explore why a company that once tried to fend off this acquisition is now trying to force Mr. Musk to buy it.

headline: 4,000 Beagles Are Being Rescued From a Virginia Facility. Now They Need New Homes.
text: When U.S. Department of Agriculture officials inspected a beagle breeding facility in Virginia last year, they found a female beagle whose paw had been trapped in shoddy flooring for so long that she was dehydrated, according to court documents. headline: Euro Falls Near Parity With Dollar, a Threshold Watched Closely by Investors
text: For the first time in nearly 20 years, one euro is almost worth the same as one U.S. dollar. The euro, which is shared by 19 European countries, has recently come under pressure, like many other currencies against the dollar, losing more than 10 percent of its value this year.

text: ST. ANDREWS, Scotland ‚Äî Tiger Woods, having returned to his sport‚Äôs most ancient ground on Tuesday, at first tried succinct bluntness. Fittingly, he soon enough reached for history. headline: Musk‚Äôs Damaged Goods

headline: Robots Aren‚Äôt Done Reshaping Warehouses

headline: Rage Against the Machine Returns for Fresh Battles
text: CHICAGO ‚Äî Four songs into Rage Against the Machine‚Äôs set Monday night at the United Center, the frontman Zack de la Rocha pulled up with a limp, hobbling across the stage while the rest of the band closed out ‚ÄúBullet in the Head,‚Äù a jaggedly groovy anti-propaganda anthem from the band‚Äôs 1992 self-titled debut album. Early in the song, he‚Äôd been jumping, bounding toward the arena ceiling. At its end, he was carried offstage by crew members.

headline: U.N. Yields to Russia‚Äôs Limits on Aid Mission in Syria
text: WASHINGTON ‚Äî World powers agreed on Tuesday to continue a United Nations aid mission to northwest Syria for six more months, bending to a deadline demanded by Russia that will, for now, avoid shutting down lifesaving deliveries for about four million people living amid an 11-year civil war.

headline: First look: The Exoplanet WASP-96b
text: Setting stunning space pictures aside, the bulk of the James Webb Space Telescope‚Äôs most profound scientific work ‚Äî the where-do-we-come-from, are-we-alone stuff ‚Äî will probably involve little squiggles on graphs of a planet orbiting a distant star.

headline: The Grill Is Hot. The Yogurt Is Cool.
text: Charcoal-grilled skewers and yogurt dips made with market produce are the specialties of Eyval, a new Persian restaurant in Brooklyn.

headline: Restaurant Review: A Fresh Look at Iran‚Äôs Street Food at Eyval
text: If you have eaten at Sofreh, the four-year-old Persian restaurant in a Brooklyn brownstone, chances are you know its mast-o musir, a yogurt dip. The first things you see are chips of dried musir, the Iranian wild shallot, prized for its courtly but distinct whiff of garlic. Underneath this is a bed of musir-enriched yogurt. It has a richness that puts you in mind of custard and a sour streak that makes your mouth water.

headline: ‚ÄòPersuasion‚Äô Director Thinks Jane Austen Will Be Just Fine
text: The trailer for ‚ÄúPersuasion,‚Äù the debut feature from the British theater director Carrie Cracknell, landed in mid-June. Social media attacks, led by fans of the Jane Austen novel on which the film is based, followed swiftly. Viewers objected to the flashes of contemporary language (‚Äúexes,‚Äù ‚Äúa 10‚Äù) and the moments in which Dakota Johnson, who plays the heroine, Anne Elliot, addresses the camera directly. There were complaints about the ‚ÄúFleabag‚Äù-ification of the Regency romance and the emphasis on comedy. ‚ÄúJane Austen Turns in Her Grave,‚Äù a headline in the Daily Mail read.

headline: When Republicans Backed Herschel Walker, They Embraced a Double Standard
text: As I wrote in this newsletter in March, the phrase ‚Äúthe soft bigotry of low expectations,‚Äù coined by George W. Bush when he was a presidential candidate, pithily captures a wisdom that‚Äôs difficult to discount, regardless of one‚Äôs political stripe. But its emergence as a critique of the educational establishment has meant that it‚Äôs generally thought of as a charge from the right.

headline: First look: Carina Nebula
text: The Carina nebula is a turbulent cloud of gas, dust about 7,600 light-years from here, a birthplace and graveyard for some of the Milky Way‚Äôs hottest and most massive stars.

headline: Abubakr Ali Gets a Boost From Whale-Watching and Eid Fashions
text: Growing up in Pasadena, the actor Abubakr Ali never thought he‚Äôd play many lead roles. Even after coming up through the acting program at New York University and then the Yale School of Drama ‚Äî where he graduated alongside the playwright Jeremy O. Harris and ‚ÄúThe Gilded Age‚Äù actress Louisa Jacobson, the daughter of Meryl Streep ‚Äî he‚Äôd become used to a world in which an Egyptian-born Arab American like himself would be relegated to the margins.

headline: Trump prefers golfing to watching the hearings. But he‚Äôs still getting the highlights.
text: When former President Donald J. Trump maintains that relatively few people are watching the public hearings staged by the House select committee, he is counting himself among the uninterested.

headline: In ‚ÄòCarnality,‚Äô a Wild Ride Fueled by Rash Decisions
text: ‚ÄúAh, a nice old-fashioned novel,‚Äù the reader thinks, gliding through the opening pages of ‚ÄúCarnality.‚Äù The author, Lina Wolff, begins in a conventional close third-person perspective and quickly dispatches with the W questions. Who is the main character? A 45-year-old Swedish writer. What is she doing? Traveling on a writer‚Äôs grant. When? Present day, more or less. Where? Madrid. Why? To upend the tedium of her life.

headline: Images From the James Webb Space Telescope
text: NASA and its partner space agencies revealed a stunning series of images ‚Äî from the Carina Nebula in our own Milky Way to a cluster of galaxies much farther away ‚Äî taken by the James Webb Space Telescope, the largest and most powerful space observatory ever launched. The photograph below shows Stephan‚Äôs Quintet, five galaxies, four of which interact and stretch each other with their gravitational forces.

headline: A Culture Warrior Goes Quiet: DeSantis Dodges Questions on Abortion Plans
text: When the Supreme Court erased the constitutional right to an abortion last month, Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida was among the many Republicans who celebrated. ‚ÄúThe prayers of millions have been answered,‚Äù he tweeted.

headline: Stress on workers at an occupied nuclear plant elevates risks, experts say.
text: When work started in southern Ukraine in 1981 on what would become Europe‚Äôs largest nuclear plant, the country was part of the Soviet Union and political instability barely figured as a risk. Today, Ukraine is at war with Moscow, the plant is occupied by Russian forces and experts say they are concerned about its safety.

headline: Pat Cipollone, Trump‚Äôs White House counsel, could help the panel flesh out important moments.
text: Pat A. Cipollone, President Donald J. Trump‚Äôs second and final White House counsel, appeared for a videotaped, transcribed interview with the House Jan. 6 committee last week after being subpoenaed, and his testimony could help the panel flesh out episodes at the heart of its investigation.

headline: Ballet Theater Promotes Several Dancers, Including 3 to Principal
text: American Ballet Theater announced on Tuesday that it has promoted two of its dancers ‚Äî Catherine Hurlin and Roman Zhurbin ‚Äî to the role of principal, while also hiring Daniel Camargo, who has been a guest artist, as a principal, the company‚Äôs highest rank.

headline: Bosco, Serving Cocktails and Latin American Fare, Opens in Greenwich Village
text: Back when Bleecker Street was a corridor for Italian American food shops, some of which still thrive, Mario Bosco‚Äôs delicatessen was among them. This new bar with the consulting chef Alan Delgado, formerly of Oxomoco and the now-closed Xilonen in Brooklyn, honors the Bosco name. Reflecting changing tastes, the menu tilts Latin American, with dishes like queso fundido; snapper ceviche; mango-tuna aguachile; several tacos including masa-fried cod; tortas like pulled pork, chicken milanesa and Portobello pibil; plus a flan and a tres leches cake for dessert. (Bosco, the brand of chocolate syrup, does not appear to figure in any of the sweets.) The owner, Kevin Doherty, has also seen to it that cocktails, created by Stephen Wynne, include at least one taste of Ireland, with a Mo Chara featuring Irish whiskey, ginger-lime sherbet, falernum and bitters. The space, which was previously a bar, has a bar area seating 25 and a 50-seat dining room beyond, and a spacious sidewalk terrace. There‚Äôs music Thursday through Sunday evenings.

headline: At This Summer‚Äôs Aix Festival, the Only Laughter Is Bitter
text: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France ‚Äî Few opera institutions have as strong a track record in new work as the Aix-en-Provence Festival. Two of the most significant pieces of the 21st century have originated here: ‚ÄúWritten on Skin,‚Äù in 2012, and ‚ÄúInnocence,‚Äù which premiered last year.

headline: How Deep Is Our Love for Prime Day?
text: We love an internet shopping novelty. For a while.

headline: Chasing Precious Seconds, Pogacar Holds Tight to Tour de France Lead
text: His lead sits at only 11 seconds after a dramatic finish Tuesday, but the two-time defending champion, Tadej Pogacar, seems to have taken control of the Tour de France and is starting to squeeze his competitors out of the race.

headline: Jockeying in oil markets may strain Russia‚Äôs relations with Venezuela ‚Äî and Iran.

text: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Senator Joe Manchin III‚Äôs opposition to government incentives for electric vehicles is a sticking point in negotiations over President Biden‚Äôs tax and spending package ‚Äî talks that appear to be coming to a head this week after months of fits and starts.

text: When Americans are asked to name French musicals, their go-to is ‚ÄúLes Mis√©rables,‚Äù which opened in Paris in 1980 before an extensively retooled English version went on to conquer the world a few years later.

headline: Stephanie Murphy: Her roots in Vietnam fuel a concern for democracy.
text: In spring 2002, Representative Stephanie Murphy, a Florida Democrat who was born in Vietnam, returned to the country for the first time as an adult with her father, as local elections were underway. headline: The pandemic remains a global health emergency, the W.H.O. says.

headline: Shoppers are still willing to pay more for drinks and snacks, Pepsi says.
text: PepsiCo defied some expectations for an inflation-induced slowdown, raising its revenue forecast for the year for a second time, citing the ‚Äúresilience‚Äù of consumer spending. headline: For Erdogan, talks with Putin next week put spotlight on a complicated relationship.
text: When President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey and President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia meet next week in Iran, the two leaders will navigate a sometimes fraught but also symbiotic relationship that has been complicated by the war in Ukraine.

headline: The Humbug Economy
text: There‚Äôs an old story about Charles Darwin, which may or may not be true but seems appropriate to our current economic moment. According to the tale, two boys glued together pieces of various insects ‚Äî a centipede‚Äôs body, a butterfly‚Äôs wings, a beetle‚Äôs head and so on ‚Äî then, as a gag, presented their creation to the great naturalist for identification. ‚ÄúDid it hum when you caught it?‚Äù he asked. When they said yes, he declared that it was a humbug.

headline: ‚ÄòYellowstone‚Äô and ‚ÄòReservation Dogs‚Äô Are Among the Emmy Snubs
text: Amid the mostly business-as-usual announcement of the 2022 Emmy Awards nominees ‚Äî get ready to be sick of hearing ‚ÄúSuccession‚Äù and ‚ÄúTed Lasso‚Äù called out on Sept. 12 ‚Äî there were some slightly unexpected occurrences. headline: Emmys 2022: Lee Jung-jae Would Stay in the ‚ÄòSquid Game‚Äô Contest

headline: Oil Prices Fall Below $100 on Weaker Economic Outlook
text: Crude oil prices plunged more than 7 percent on Tuesday as the American and world benchmarks fell below $100 a barrel.

headline: ‚ÄòTwelfth Night‚Äô Review: A Shot of Joy Under a Darkening Sky
text: For so many of us, stress roared in and put down roots. The stress of living at perpetual high alert in a world that has seemed, for the past several years, to be in an ever-shifting state of emergency. Amid all that, in the post-shutdown theater, has come a tsunami of shows dedicated to elucidating social ills and processing cultural pain. Such work is vital now and always; don‚Äôt get me wrong.

headline: ‚ÄòMister Miss America‚Äô Review: A Fight for the Crown
text: A boy forced to dim his flame discovers a local beauty pageant that sets off a spark in him again. text: SIVERSK, Ukraine ‚Äî The streets of this frontline town are deserted, pockmarked with shell craters, and littered with broken metal roofing and dangling electricity lines. headline: Ice Cream in the City

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‚ÄòPlenty of Parents Don‚Äôt Like Their Children‚Äô
text: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôll know when he‚Äôs ‚Äòthe one‚Äô,‚Äù my mother said. She died when I was 20, leaving no further guidance. At 23, I was stale inventory by Jewish matchmaking standards. Despair settled in. Until one Shabbat afternoon when Phil, an old friend of my roommate, breezed into our 93rd Street apartment. He was cute, interested in my aspirations and favorite author. My roommate asked how his birthday had been. ‚ÄúWhen was it?‚Äù I asked. He replied, ‚ÄúSeptember 14.‚Äù My mother‚Äôs birthday. Serendipity or shidduch (a match)? I know which. He was her gift to me. Twenty-three anniversaries later, I still know. ‚Äî Gila Pfeffer

headline: Webb Telescope Reveals a New Vision of an Ancient Universe

headline: Four takeaways from the latest hearing of the House Jan. 6 committee.
text: The seventh public hearing by the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 riot focused on how Donald J. Trump and his allies turned their efforts toward summoning a mob of his supporters to Washington to protest the certification of the election after they had exhausted all legal avenues. Relying on testimony from Trump aides, right-wing media commentators and militia members, the committee demonstrated how Mr. Trump‚Äôs public statements led his supporters to believe the election had actually been stolen and storm the Capitol in an attempt to stop the certification.

headline: A Mysterious Fall Was the First Sign Something Was Wrong
text: ‚ÄúOK, let‚Äôs go,‚Äù the hairdresser cheerfully instructed the 67-year-old woman reclining at the hair-washing basin. The woman rose, her hair swathed in a fluffy towel, but at the first step she stumbled. She smiled, a little embarrassed, and looked behind her. Did someone bump into her? As she reached the doorway to the room of mirrors and styling chairs, the woman again felt a shove. This time it sent her up against the doorway, and she dropped to her knees. The hairdresser grabbed her arm and steadied her. ‚ÄúYou OK?‚Äù she asked, helping the woman to her feet. ‚ÄúI guess so,‚Äù the older woman answered. But she hadn‚Äôt been, for those two brief moments.

headline: What‚Äôs Really Going on in Those Police Fentanyl Exposure Videos?
text: For the past five years, I‚Äôve watched a bizarre news cycle play out on repeat. The most recent recurrence began on June 16, when KCTV5, a local news organization in Kansas City, Mo., published police body-camera footage under a dramatic headline: ‚Äú‚Äâ‚ÄòI Knew I Was Dying‚Äô: How 5 Rounds of Narcan Possibly Saved KCK Police Officer‚Äôs Life.‚Äù The operative word in that sentence is ‚Äúpossibly.‚Äù The footage shows a police officer standing on a snowy lawn in what looks like a suburban neighborhood, wearing sunglasses and disposable gloves, inspecting pills stashed inside a crumpled piece of paper. ‚ÄúSeal it up ‚Äî that‚Äôs fentanyl, dude,‚Äù another officer says. ‚ÄúGet that in a bag quick, so we don‚Äôt have an exposure.‚Äù The time stamp on the video then jumps to five minutes later. The officer who held the pills is now collapsed on the ground, limbs splayed as though making a snow angel. We hear another officer yell, ‚ÄúNarcan, Narcan, Narcan!‚Äù The fallen officer gasps rapidly as his fellow officers, with what seems like genuine panic, spray the opioid-overdose antidote up his nose several times.

headline: Please Laugh About My Abortion With Me
text: On Friday evening, June 24, I arrived at the Cherry Lane Theater in Manhattan having already traveled between outrage, exhaustion and despair. Roe v. Wade was overturned that morning, and I was about to perform my comedy show ‚ÄúOh God, a Show About Abortion.‚Äù I performed the show after the draft of the Supreme Court decision in Dobbs v. Jackson Women‚Äôs Health Organization leaked, and the mood in the theater then was somber; an edgier joke, one that normally elicits reluctant bursts of laughter, earned groans.

headline: Why Do So Many Republicans Tolerate Donald Trump?

headline: Mitt Romney Is Inventing Policies for a Fantasy G.O.P.
text: Last year, as an alternative to the temporary expansion of the child tax credit under President Biden‚Äôs American Rescue Plan, Senator Mitt Romney of Utah introduced a plan to give every family a monthly benefit of up to $350 per child for children 5 and under and $250 per child for children 6 to 17. It was simple, generous (it included a payment before birth, too) and ‚Äî on paper, at least ‚Äî effective. According to the Niskanen Center, which helped devise the proposal, the Romney plan would cut overall child poverty by roughly a third and the deepest child poverty by half.

headline: The Case for Grilling Cucumbers
text: There‚Äôs nothing more pointless, you might say, than grilling a cucumber. If not meat, then it‚Äôs whole fish or fish fillets that should be grilled, isn‚Äôt it? These are the things that, generally speaking, need to be cooked to be eaten, that need to undergo the transformation that the heat under the grill creates.
