headline: Avignon Festival Gets Its Buzz Back
text: AVIGNON, France ‚Äî After two years of pandemic-related disruption, the Avignon Festival is well and truly back. As the event, a longtime highlight on the European theater calendar, got underway here last week, there were familiar sights everywhere. All around the small city center, buzzing crowds filled the streets, while blas√© regulars zigzagged between performers handing out fliers for some 1,570 Fringe productions.

headline: ‚ÄòPutin‚Äôs War Must Be a Strategic Failure,‚Äô Biden Says in Israel
text: JERUSALEM ‚Äî President Biden restated his determination that Russia fail in its Ukraine ambitions, speaking on Thursday during a four-day visit to Israel and Saudi Arabia in which he and other leaders discussed the international response to the war and the global grain shortage it has exacerbated.

headline: He Wanted a New Condo (With a Bathroom Sink) for Less Than $1 Million. These Were His Options.
text: Feeling not ‚Äòestablished enough for a co-op board,‚Äô an East Village renter searched one-bedroom apartments in newer buildings. By the time he found one, it was a home for two.

headline: Poem: Portrait of D17: Female, 37 Years Old
text: This poem is part of a sonnet sequence that meditates on Andrea Modica‚Äôs photographs of skulls unearthed from the Colorado Mental Health Institute in Pueblo. In this sonnet (there‚Äôs a dropped line in the poem, making it technically 15 lines ‚Äî one more than a traditional sonnet), the speaker compares two kinds of skulls: anonymous skulls at the Tuol Sleng Genocide Museum in Phnom Penh and the tagged and mounted skulls in Colorado. Paisley Rekdal‚Äôs poems are often struck with intellect, and this one is no different ‚Äî in the second part of the poem during the volta, or the turn in a sonnet, the skulls are animated with their own opinions. The syntax mirrors a thinking mind. Note all the interruptions, from the em-dash after ‚Äúrain,‚Äù to the commas, to the colon after ‚Äúwitnesses,‚Äù to the line breaks, as if to say that the only way to make sense of horror is to populate it with the turning language of logic.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on What to Call Your Wife
text: Ben writes: My wife, Maegan, hates when I use her name to get her attention. She prefers I call her ‚Äúhoneybee.‚Äù We were at a restaurant, and the hostess told me our table was ready. Maegan was a ways away, so I spoke her name loudly. (If shouting is a seven, this was a six.) She didn‚Äôt like it, but it worked. May I address her this way in time-sensitive situations?

headline: Meryl Streep‚Äôs One Weird Trick
text: The dramatic removal of eyeglasses is a cinematic clich√©. On Streep, it‚Äôs a revelation.

headline: My Dog‚Äôs Death Taught Me Spiritual Detachment. Then My Sister Got Sick.
text: Shortly after my parents died in 2017, I nearly lost custody of my dog, Zoe, in my divorce. When we were reunited, I remember telling her firmly, ‚ÄúYou cannot die now,‚Äù even though she had just turned 15.

headline: The Big Ten Is Growing, but All I See Is Decline
text: Philip Larkin once wrote that all historians of jazz are either H.G. Wells or Edward Gibbon ‚Äî ‚Äúonwards and upwards, or decline and fall.‚Äù It‚Äôs the relentless progress of Wells‚Äôs ‚ÄúOutline of History‚Äù or the inexorable doom of Gibbon‚Äôs Roman Empire.

headline: Which States Are the Most Safe and Secure for Renters?
text: The United States has experienced nine weather or climate disasters so far this year that have caused at least $1 billion in damages, according to the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration. The agency also reported that above-normal temperatures were in the forecast for most of the country this summer. With extreme weather on the rise, people may be wondering which areas are safer than others to find a new home.

headline: Elon Musk Bought Twitter. Now He Must Own It.
text: Elon Musk is trying to walk away from his $44 billion agreement to buy Twitter, but the Court of Chancery in Delaware, where the company is incorporated and is now suing Mr. Musk, should order him to buy the social media company.

headline: His Ship Finally Came In, but Should He Be on It?
text: Since the Covid pandemic started, we‚Äôve all had to make endless decisions about what is worth the risk ‚Äî eat out or stay home, attend a best friend‚Äôs wedding or watch the livestream, go on vacation or cancel it again. But going into Year 3, that calculus has lost its urgency for many people. This summer‚Äôs chaotic travel season is evidence enough.

headline: In Battle to Beat Democratic Titans, a Lawyer in Sneakers Bets on Youth
text: Suraj Patel has few illusions about what he‚Äôs up against as he takes on two titans of New York politics, Representatives Carolyn Maloney and Jerrold Nadler, in this summer‚Äôs blockbuster Democratic primary. But he does take hope from a theory about coffee shops.

headline: ‚ÄòDrive to Survive‚Äô Made Americans Fall in Love With Formula 1
text: One Thursday morning in May, the Formula 1 driver Valtteri Bottas was enjoying an alfresco breakfast with his girlfriend, the cyclist Tiffany Cromwell, on the secluded terrace of a South Beach hotel. It was a last bit of vacation before the start of practice sessions for that weekend‚Äôs Miami Grand Prix. Bottas and Cromwell had spent an hour biking along the beach. Now they were sitting under a trellis of bougainvillea, chatting casually in the way that romantic partners do.

headline: U.S. Electric Car Sales Climb Sharply Despite Shortages
text: Americans are buying electric vehicles at a record pace, undeterred by rising prices and long waits for delivery, a further indication that the twilight of the internal combustion engine is on the horizon.

headline: Janeane Garofalo Never Sold Out. What a Relief.
text: On a rainy Wednesday night in Brooklyn, after an introduction with a minimum of fanfare, Janeane Garofalo walked onstage at the Eastville Comedy Club and looked out at a dozen people so scattered that calling them a crowd seems like a stretch. She spotted one man by himself who had attended a show of hers a few days earlier and happily pointed him out.

headline: How to Invest When Inflation Is Bad and a Recession May Loom
text: The news on inflation has been bad for months, but it‚Äôs recently gotten worse. On Wednesday, the government reported that in June the Consumer Price Index rose at an annual rate of 9.1 percent ‚Äî the fastest pace since November 1981.

headline: The Magic of Your First Work Friends
text: The things that Lisa Degliantoni learned at 22 from the two best friends she met at her New York City publishing job included but were not limited to:

headline: For a Woman in a Wheelchair, Abortion Access Was One More Challenge
text: Roxanne Schiebergen, a 30-year-old writer and actress who lives in New York, was in the bathroom of her Midtown apartment when she received a text from a close friend one day in May. The text included a screenshot of a marketing flyer promoting a ‚ÄúBans Off Our Bodies‚Äù rally sponsored in part by Planned Parenthood. The photo in the ad showed four women ‚Äî and the woman at the center was in a wheelchair.

headline: Toronto Steps Into Summer
text: Canada‚Äôs biggest city and North America‚Äôs fourth-largest metropolis, Toronto received more than 27.5 million visitors annually before the pandemic, making it Canada‚Äôs top tourism destination, according to Destination Toronto, the city‚Äôs tourism-marketing arm.

headline: Young Voters Are Fed Up With Their (Much) Older Leaders
text: Alexandra Chadwick went to the polls in 2020 with the single goal of ousting Donald J. Trump. A 22-year-old first-time voter, she saw Joseph R. Biden Jr. as more of a safeguard than an inspiring political figure, someone who could stave off threats to abortion access, gun control and climate policy.

headline: The Housing Shortage Isn‚Äôt Just a Coastal Crisis Anymore
text: San Francisco, Los Angeles, New York and Washington have long failed to build enough housing to keep up with everyone trying to live there. And for nearly as long, other parts of the country have mostly been able to shrug off the housing shortage as a condition particular to big coastal cities.

headline: China‚Äôs Surveillance State Hits Rare Resistance From Its Own Subjects
text: Chinese artists have staged performances to highlight the ubiquity of surveillance cameras. Privacy activists have filed lawsuits against the collection of facial recognition data. Ordinary citizens and establishment intellectuals alike have pushed back against the abuse of Covid tracking apps by the authorities to curb protests. Internet users have shared tips on how to evade digital monitoring.

headline: For New York‚Äôs Anti-Abortion Veterans, Roe‚Äôs Fall Is Not a Full Victory
text: For local veterans of the anti-abortion movement, the Supreme Court‚Äôs June 24 decision reversing Roe v. Wade came with a sobering reminder: In New York, New Jersey and Connecticut, nothing had changed.

headline: Biden‚Äôs Saudi Lesson: The Only Path Runs Through M.B.S.
text: BEIRUT, Lebanon ‚Äî The Saudi Arabia that President Biden will visit this week is a country being actively reshaped by the whims and visions of one man: Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman.

headline: For Young Offenders, Restitution Debts Can Present Crippling Obstacles
text: WASHINGTON ‚Äî Arabella Guevara spent much of her adolescence paying for her mistakes.

headline: A strike on the Ukrainian city of Vinnytsia kills at least 23 people, officials say.
text: VINNYTSIA, Ukraine ‚Äî A volley of Russian cruise missiles hit a shopping center, a dance studio and a wedding hall in central Ukraine on Thursday, killing at least 23 people and setting off a frantic search for dozens more lost in the rubble, in a latest strike to hit a civilian area far from the front lines.

headline: How Sri Lanka‚Äôs Economy Collapsed
text: In recent days, the political crisis in Sri Lanka has reached a critical point, with its president fleeing the country and protesters occupying his residence and office. Today, ‚ÄúThe Daily‚Äù explores how the island nation, whose economy was once held up as a success story in South Asia, came apart ‚Äî and why it‚Äôs a cautionary tale.

headline: The Impossible Task of Keeping Up With the Ingebrigtsens
text: FLAGSTAFF, Ariz. ‚Äî Jakob Ingebrigtsen is surrounded by silence, all those empty spaces between workouts and competitions. As the fastest miler in the world, he is aware of the peculiarities of his profession.

headline: The Semiconductor Problem
text: The most advanced category of mass-produced semiconductors ‚Äî used in smartphones, military technology and much more ‚Äî is known as 5 nm. A single company in Taiwan, known as TSMC, makes about 90 percent of them. U.S. factories make none.

headline: What is the I2U2?
text: JERUSALEM ‚Äî I2U2 sounds as though it might be a cross between a legendary Irish rock band and a droid from ‚ÄúStar Wars.‚Äù

headline: Brittney Griner‚Äôs case shows the limits of American power.
text: As outrage mounts over Brittney Griner‚Äôs continued detention in Russia, many in America have wondered publicly if U.S. officials could be doing more to secure Griner‚Äôs release. LeBron James, the argument goes, would have been freed long ago.

headline: What‚Äôs in Our Queue? Dance and More
text: I‚Äôm a general assignment reporter on The Times‚Äôs Culture desk. Here are five things I've been watching, reading and listening to.

headline: ‚ÄòPaws of Fury: The Legend of Hank‚Äô Review: A Tail of Two Samurai
text: Michael Cera stars as an anthropomorphic dog, who is in training to be a samurai, and Samuel L. Jackson plays his washed-up feline mentor in Paramount‚Äôs latest animated family flick, ‚ÄúPaws of Fury: The Legend of Hank.‚Äù The film sounds like standard CGI family fare, until you learn that the movie, originally titled ‚ÄúBlazing Samurai,‚Äù is a PG adaptation of Mel Brooks‚Äôs 1974 satire of Western films and race relations, ‚ÄúBlazing Saddles.‚Äù

headline: ‚ÄòMrs. Harris Goes to Paris‚Äô Review: High Fashion for the Humble
text: In ‚ÄúMrs. Harris Goes to Paris,‚Äù Lesley Manville returns to the world of high fashion in a reversal of her Oscar-nominated role in ‚ÄúPhantom Thread.‚Äù Her deliciously frigid character in that film ‚Äî the forbidding manager of a British fashion house and foe to Vicky Krieps‚Äôs lowborn muse ‚Äî would go catatonic were Manville‚Äôs Mrs. Ada Harris to waltz into the fitting room, asking for a ‚Äúfrock‚Äù with her cockney drawl.

headline: ‚ÄòShe Will‚Äô Review: Payback Is a Witch
text: The first name we see onscreen in ‚ÄúShe Will‚Äù belongs not to its director (Charlotte Colbert) or its star (Alice Krige), but to one of its executive producers, the horror maestro Dario Argento. And it doesn‚Äôt take long to recognize the ways in which the plot of this confident first feature (written by Colbert and Kitty Percy) might have appealed to Argento: The emphasis on dreams, the sly humor and ‚Äî perhaps most of all ‚Äî the despoilment of female beauty.

headline: ‚ÄòCosta Brava, Lebanon‚Äô Review: Paradise Tossed
text: As civic emergencies go, few possess the symbolic clarity of a garbage crisis. They‚Äôre ugly. They stink. They signify dysfunction, rot and toxicity in ways that need no sorting.

headline: ‚ÄòDon‚Äôt Make Me Go‚Äô Review: Sharp Curves Ahead for Next 2,000 Miles
text: ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre not going to like the way this story ends,‚Äù Wally (Mia Isaac), 15, warns the audience at the start of ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Make Me Go,‚Äù a father-daughter drama of startling honesty and humor. Max (John Cho), Wally‚Äôs protective single dad, has learned that his headaches aren‚Äôt just from the struggle of parenting his restless teenager. A cancer diagnosis gives him one year to live ‚Äî and instead of coming clean about his condition, Max packs up their wood-paneled Jeep for a road trip with an ulterior motive: To take a surprise detour to introduce Wally to her mother (Jen Van Epps), who ran away with Max‚Äôs best friend (Jemaine Clement) when the girl was an infant.

headline: ‚ÄòPersuasion‚Äô Review: The Present Intrudes Into the Past
text: The great irony of this new, not-quite-modernized adaptation of Jane Austen‚Äôs final novel, ‚ÄúPersuasion,‚Äù is that it communicates its tense relationship to its 19th-century source material in a repressed, passive-aggressive manner ‚Äî an approach oddly suited to Austen‚Äôs trenchant view of society. The film doesn‚Äôt take the creative leap to transpose the beloved story in the present day. Instead, in curiously excruciating fashion, the director, screenwriters, and star imply their discomfort with Georgian-era social norms from within the novel‚Äôs period setting.

headline: ‚ÄòAnonymous Club‚Äô Review: The Joy of Creation
text: The singer-songwriter Courtney Barnett started out as a DIY artist, home-recording energetic songs communicating knotty feelings. Early in this documentary, written and directed by Danny Cohen, a cheery interviewer leads into a question by saying that it‚Äôs not too common to hear artists ‚Äúsinging about panic attacks.‚Äù This reflects more on the limited listening experience of the interviewer than anything else, but you get the idea.

headline: Janet Yellen Says It‚Äôs in Russia‚Äôs Interest to Go Along With an Oil Price Cap
text: On the eve of a meeting of finance chiefs from the world‚Äôs major economies in Bali, Indonesia, Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen continued to push for a price cap on Russian oil, calling it ‚Äúone of our most powerful tools‚Äù to alleviate the painful leaps in energy and food prices.

headline: Italy‚Äôs Unity Government Teeters, as Mario Draghi Offers to Resign
text: ROME ‚Äî Italy‚Äôs golden period of stability suddenly seemed on the familiar precipice of chaos on Thursday after Prime Minister Mario Draghi tendered his resignation in response to a revolt by anti-establishment populists within his broad national unity government.

headline: Biden calls for a ‚Äòlasting negotiated peace‚Äô between Israel and the Palestinians.
text: JERUSALEM ‚Äî President Biden called on Thursday for a ‚Äúlasting negotiated peace between the State of Israel and the Palestinian people‚Äù and reiterated his calls for a two-state solution to the conflict.

headline: Science and Data Change Soccer‚Äôs Definition of Old
text: LONDON ‚Äî The exact location of the threshold has always been contested. At Manchester United, for a time, it lurked close enough to 30 for that to serve as a natural watershed. Once players hit their 30s, Alex Ferguson, the club‚Äôs manager at the time, tended to grant them an extra day‚Äôs rest after a game, in the hope that the break might soothe their creaking bodies.

headline: ‚ÄòQueen of Glory‚Äô Review: Back to the Bronx
text: Molecular neuro-oncologist Sarah Obeng is very smart. But in the subtle delight ‚ÄúQueen of Glory‚Äù ‚Äî written and directed by its lead actor, Nana Mensah ‚Äî the American daughter of Ghanaian parents can be foolish, too. Take her married boyfriend and university colleague, Lyle (Adam Leon): He‚Äôs simply not worthy.

headline: Amazon Moves to End a Long-Running Antitrust Case in Europe
text: Amazon tried on Thursday to end a three-year investigation by antitrust regulators in the European Union by offering to make a series of changes to its business practices and give rival merchants an easier way to reach customers on its website.

headline: What Californians Need to Know About Monkeypox
text: By now you‚Äôve probably heard of monkeypox, the latest disease making headlines as it spreads across the world.

headline: Biden, Oil and the Middle East
text: JPMorgan Chase reported earnings this morning that were lower than forecasts, as it set aside bigger reserves to cover bad loans, a possible ominous sign for the rest of the banking sector. Its C.E.O., Jamie Dimon, said the bank was suspending share buybacks. Morgan Stanley‚Äôs earnings also fell short of expectations.

headline: Twitter suffers a global outage at a delicate moment for the company.
text: Twitter, the social media giant with 330 million active users, was back online on Thursday morning after reports of a worldwide outage that came at a sensitive time for the company, which is locked in a heated legal battle with the billionaire Elon Musk over its acquisition.

headline: My Friends Were Terrible Guests. Why Won‚Äôt They Apologize?
text: I let friends stay at my lake house for a long weekend while I was away. I returned to six loads of dirty laundry, furniture moved all over the place and a pile of water toys in my shed ‚Äî without so much as a thank-you note for letting them stay. I was upset and let them know it. Not only did they fail to apologize, they criticized my reaction (and questioned the amount of laundry they had actually left). I feel gaslit. These people are like family to me, but I‚Äôm not sure I can forgive them. Their response to my complaint was worse than the original inconsiderate behavior. What can I do?

headline: Chess Replay: You Versus Bronstein
text: This is Chess Replay, an interactive puzzle based on a historic chess game. As a solver, you embody a famous player during a critical game in his or her career. A new edition of this puzzle is published each week on Thursdays.

headline: A London Restaurant Inspired by Ghana‚Äôs Chop Bars
text: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we‚Äôre eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: With Few Able and Fewer Willing, U.S. Military Can‚Äôt Find Recruits
text: FOUNTAIN, Colo. ‚Äî The local Army recruiting station was empty. The normally reliable recruiting grounds at the nearby Walmart were a bust. With the Army still thousands of soldiers short of its recruiting goal, the station commander, Sgt. First Class James Pulliam, dressed head to toe in camouflage, scanned a strip-mall parking lot for targets.

headline: U.K. Issues an Unprecedented Heat Warning
text: Britain is bracing for its hottest day ever as a heat wave sweeps across Europe. Follow live updates here.

headline: A Photographer Follows Paul Revere Williams Into the West
text: Paul Revere Williams came by his nickname ‚Äúarchitect to the stars‚Äù over a career that saw his designs dot the wealthiest enclaves of Southern California, leaving a silver-screen-size impact during the decades coinciding with Hollywood‚Äôs golden era. He created homes for Frank Sinatra and Lucille Ball, among others, and helped erect elegant municipal, federal and commercial developments as far afield as Washington, D.C. In two best-selling books, he championed affordable housing for a new generation of homeowners.

headline: Sri Lanka‚Äôs President Resigns After Months of Protest
text: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka ‚Äî President Gotabaya Rajapaksa of Sri Lanka, who fled his country early Wednesday after months of fervent protests blaming him for the country‚Äôs economic collapse and widespread hardship, officially resigned on Thursday, setting off celebrations in his homeland.

headline: ‚ÄòEarwig‚Äô Review: Danse Macabre
text: Near the beginning of ‚ÄúEarwig,‚Äù the latest trip down the darkest of rabbit holes by the French director Lucile Hadzihalilovic, a 10-year-old girl admires a landscape painting, seated before it in an image similar to the famous scene from ‚ÄúPoltergeist.‚Äù Fascinated, she runs her fingers over the rough canvas and its vibrant colors; it‚Äôs a moment not unlike the experience of watching the film, which can feel like being hypnotized by disturbingly palpable still lifes from the unconscious realm.

headline: Has remote work changed your relationships with colleagues?
text: Office occupancy across the United States is still less than 50 percent of its prepandemic levels. Many people are working from home, which comes as a relief to some workers while others find it harder to socialize with their colleagues. Some have found inventive ways of staying connected, whether through virtual gatherings, instant messaging or in-person retreats.

headline: Big Banks Prepare for Downturn, but Don‚Äôt See Recession Yet
text: Slowing demand and sinking markets have put an end to a period of record-setting profits for the country‚Äôs biggest banks, but that doesn‚Äôt mean a recession is imminent, top bankers say, even if it may look like they are preparing for one.

headline: Man Exonerated in Malcolm X Murder Sues New York City After Talks Fail
text: New York‚Äôs criminal justice system took 55 years to acknowledge that it had wrongly branded Muhammad A. Aziz as one of Malcolm X‚Äôs killers.

headline: Kevin Spacey Pleads Not Guilty to Sexual Assault
text: LONDON ‚Äî Kevin Spacey, the Oscar and Tony Award-winning actor, pleaded not guilty to charges of sexual assault on Thursday, British prosecutors said.

headline: How Mo Farah Outran His Sad Beginnings
text: My first meeting with him was inadvertent, clandestine. It occurred in Albuquerque in October 2010. I had traveled there to write about another runner, the American Dathan Ritzenhein, as he trained for that year‚Äôs New York City Marathon with his new coach, Alberto Salazar, a former star who had morphed into an eccentric tailor, making alterations to Ritzenhein‚Äôs posture and stride.

headline: ‚ÄòThe Deer King‚Äô Review: Medicine, Family and Empire
text: Based on a series of fantasy books by the Japanese author Nahoko Uehashi, the animated film ‚ÄúThe Deer King‚Äù opens on a chain gang of enslaved people forced to labor in a salt mine. While they and their captors sleep, a pack of wolves enter the mine, biting hundreds and passing on a deadly disease. A pair of humans manage to get out alive: Van (Shinichi Tsutsumi), a former soldier, and Yuna (Hisui Kimura), an orphaned toddler. The two escape to the countryside, only to find themselves thrust into an effort to discover a cure for the disease that killed the others. The movie, directed by Masashi Ando and Masayuki Miyaji, follows Van‚Äôs tender relationship with Yuna and the lengths he will go to protect her, even as he finds nefarious forces stacked against him.

headline: Why Woodpeckers Don‚Äôt Mind Hitting Trees With Their Faces
text: Watching a woodpecker repeatedly smash its face into a tree, it‚Äôs hard not to wonder how its brain stays intact.

headline: ‚ÄòGabby Giffords Won‚Äôt Back Down‚Äô Review: A New Mission
text: In 2011, Gabrielle Giffords, then a Democratic congresswoman, was hosting a public meet-and-greet outside a Safeway supermarket in Arizona when a gunman opened fire into the gathering, killing six people and wounding many more. Giffords suffered a bullet to the head that shattered her skull and wreaked havoc on the left side of her brain. She now struggles with aphasia, a condition that interferes with the expression of language.

headline: The S.E.C. broadens its inquiry into Elon Musk‚Äôs disclosures about Twitter.
text: The Securities and Exchange Commission has broadened its inquiry into whether Elon Musk properly disclosed his investment in Twitter and his intentions for the social media company, the agency revealed on Thursday in a filing.

headline: Review: In ‚ÄòThe Rehearsal,‚Äô All the World Is Staged
text: Life, the philosopher Soren Kierkegaard once said, can be understood only backward, but it must be lived forward.

headline: What are the Maccabiah Games?
text: The Maccabiah Games, which President Biden attended on Thursday evening, are Israel‚Äôs biggest sporting event, often referred to as the Jewish Olympics.

headline: France Faces a Shortage of Mustard, Its Uniquely Beloved Condiment
text: PARIS ‚Äî Mustard runs deep in French culture. ‚ÄúMy blood is boiling‚Äù is rendered in French by the expression ‚Äúla moutarde me monte au nez,‚Äù or ‚Äúthe mustard is rising into my nose‚Äù ‚Äî and as Bastille Day testifies, when that happens in France, the effect can be devastating.

headline: The W.H.O. warns against ‚Äòapathy‚Äô in efforts to contain Covid in Africa.
text: With coronavirus case counts climbing and vaccination efforts lagging in some African nations, regional officials of the World Health Organization issued a warning on Thursday against lax enforcement of public health measures to curb the pandemic on the continent.

headline: Stocks edge lower as bank earnings add to concerns about the economy.
text: Stocks fell Thursday as investors grappled with the possibility of another higher-than-expected interest rate increase by the Federal Reserve and some downbeat earnings reports from major banks.

headline: ‚ÄòFrom Where They Stood‚Äô Review: Auschwitz, as Seen by Prisoners
text: Christophe Cognet‚Äôs ‚ÄúFrom Where They Stood‚Äù scrutinizes an astonishing record of the Holocaust: photographs secretly taken by prisoners within Auschwitz-Birkenau and other concentration camps. Cognet‚Äôs analytical documentary adopts the stance of an investigating historian to explicate the pictures, which were made and smuggled out at mortal risk.

headline: ‚ÄòZombies 3‚Äô Review: Take Me to Your Cheerleader
text: In ‚ÄúZombies 3,‚Äù directed by Paul Hoen, an interspecies utopia faces an alien invasion. Like the franchise‚Äôs previous allegories for marginalized experiences ‚Äî the zombies of ‚ÄúZombies‚Äù and werewolves of ‚ÄúZombies 2‚Äù share hardships with Black and Indigenous Americans, respectively ‚Äî this one is dubious at best.

headline: Guardian names Betsy Reed, The Intercept‚Äôs top editor, to run its U.S. newsroom.
text: Betsy Reed, the editor in chief of The Intercept, has been tapped to be the head editor of The Guardian‚Äôs U.S. newsroom, the British news organization said Thursday.

headline: South Carolina Lawyer Alex Murdaugh Charged With Killing Wife and Son
text: Alex Murdaugh, the fourth-generation lawyer whose family has long held power and influence in a rural swath of South Carolina, was charged on Thursday with killing his wife and one of his sons at the family‚Äôs secluded hunting estate in a mysterious murder that remained unsolved for more than a year.

headline: black midi Bristles at a Bleak World With ‚ÄòHellfire‚Äô
text: War, disease, murder, exploitation, sleaze, cynicism, callousness. Humanity isn‚Äôt exactly humane in the songs on ‚ÄúHellfire,‚Äù the caustic, exhilarating third album ‚Äî a masterpiece ‚Äî by the English band black midi.

headline: A Fed Governor Signals a Full-Point Rate Increase Is Possible, but Not Yet His Call
text: Christopher Waller, a Federal Reserve governor, said he supported increasing the central bank‚Äôs policy interest rate in July by the same amount as in June, though he suggested that an even larger move could be warranted if economic data continued to come in hot.

headline: W.N.B.A. Adds Charter Flights for the Finals. Here Is Why That Matters.
text: Delay after delay. Then, a cancellation. Germy bathrooms. Wrestling with yourself over paying $4 for a small bag of Skittles. Forgetting your headphones and wanting to cry. Now, the power plug at your seat is not working, and the people sitting next to you on the airplane won‚Äôt stop coughing. Do they have Covid?

headline: ‚ÄòEmboldening and Humbling‚Äô: Gasping at the Wonders of the Universe
text: To the Editor:

headline: Summery Marinated Vegetables
text: Hetty McKinnon‚Äôs new charred eggplant recipe is such a good blueprint for summery cooking: Grill a vegetable that‚Äôs in season, then, while it‚Äôs still warm, let it soak up something delicious. Repeat.

headline: Hidden Artwork Revealed by X-Ray Appears to Be Van Gogh Self-Portrait, Experts Say
text: AMSTERDAM ‚Äî There were 35 known self-portraits of Vincent van Gogh in the world. That appears to have changed this week.

headline: Revisiting the Pyramids‚Äô ‚ÄòAvant-Garde African Jazz,‚Äô Four Decades Later

Camillo doubted that his anguish could be healed through political engagement. ‚ÄúMarx can wait,‚Äù he told his brother. Not long after, Camillo died by suicide. He was 29.

headline: Asian American Student Success Isn‚Äôt a Problem
text: Over the past three years, as universities across the country have abandoned standardized test requirements and moved toward more holistic models for admission, a persistent yet largely unexamined question has arisen: Would these changes be happening if white students were at the top of the academic food chain? The performance gap between Asian American and white high school students on standardized tests has grown over the past decade. In 2018, for example, Asian American students, on average, scored 100 points higher on the SAT than white students. Just three years later, in 2021, that gap had risen by over 25 percent, to 127. Many of the universities that have dropped the SAT requirement have cited a desire for diversity and equity and a de-emphasis on hard-core academic competition. (This has always struck me as errant and, frankly, self-serving reasoning. If elite colleges actually want economically and racially diverse campuses free from the academic stressors that plague high school students, they should take their own advice and stop competing so fiercely to prove that they are the most exclusive places of higher learning in the world.)

headline: A Rape Trial, and a Legal Travesty. In 1793.
text: In the early morning hours of Sept. 5, 1793, a couple of blocks from what is now New York‚Äôs City Hall, a gentleman with a reputation as a ‚Äúrake‚Äù raped a 17-year-old seamstress whom he had carried into a brothel by force. No doubt countless cases like this one are lost to history ‚Äî papers didn‚Äôt report on them, records (if anyone kept them) rarely exist, and they rarely went to trial. In fact, in the decade since the end of British rule, there had only been two sexual assault prosecutions in the city of New York. But this case was unusual for several reasons: Lanah Sawyer, the young victim, had the mettle to report the crime. The state prosecuted it vigorously. And an English lawyer newly arrived in America with a personal interest in rape prosecutions (his patron‚Äôs son was under indictment for the same) decided to take notes, producing the first published report of such a trial in the United States and the material for ‚ÄúThe Sewing Girl‚Äôs Tale,‚Äù John Wood Sweet‚Äôs excellent and absorbing work of social and cultural history.

headline: Migraine Treatment Has Come a Long Way

headline: A Weird, Wonderful Conversation With Kim Stanley Robinson
text: Kim Stanley Robinson is one of the great living science fiction writers and one of the most astute observers of how planets look, feel and work. His Mars Trilogy imagined what it might be like for humans to settle on the red planet. His best-selling novel ‚ÄúThe Ministry for the Future‚Äù is a masterful effort at envisioning what might happen to Earth in a future of unchecked climate change. Robinson has a rare command of both science and human nature, and his writing crystallizes how the two must work together if we are to rescue our collective planetary future from possible ruin.

headline: Taking the Magic Out of Magic Mushrooms
text: Nick Fernandez was in hell ‚Äî one filled with fire and skulls and the long-legged elephants from a Salvador Dal√≠ painting. A spirit had guided him there after his funeral; other stops on their journey included Grand Central Terminal, the top of the Empire State Building and the sewers flowing beneath New York City. Their final destination was a cave where Mr. Fernandez encountered his own body, hung up on a clothes hanger. By examining his body in this way, he was able to come to peace with all that it had been through and accept it as his own.

headline: Dr. Caitlin Bernard Was Meant to Write This With Me Before She Was Attacked for Doing Her Job

But then Dr. Bernard became a target of a national smear campaign for speaking out about her 10-year-old patient, a rape victim from Ohio who needed an abortion and had to travel to Indiana to receive one, given the restrictions in her home state.

headline: The Week in Business: Twitter Hits Back
text: In Elon Musk‚Äôs saga with Twitter, the end of one chapter is just the start of another. Shortly after signaling that he was backing out of his deal to buy the social media company, Mr. Musk was sued by Twitter. The company accused him of ‚Äúknowingly, intentionally, willfully and materially‚Äù breaching their agreement. Mr. Musk‚Äôs lawyers said on Friday that Twitter‚Äôs request in the suit for an expedited trial in September was unreasonable and asked to delay it. When, and if, the case goes to trial, a judge in Delaware‚Äôs Court of Chancery will decide whether Mr. Musk‚Äôs claims that Twitter withheld information about spam accounts on the site are valid. The two parties could also settle, with Mr. Musk paying damages. Or, if his financing falls through, he could get out of the deal by paying a $1 billion breakup fee. Another possibility still is that Mr. Musk‚Äôs threat to walk away spooks Twitter into renegotiating with him, which could result in his buying the company at a discount. Worried shareholders will hear about how much damage Mr. Musk may have done when Twitter releases its second-quarter earnings this week.

headline: Why Union Drives Are Succeeding
text: After decades of declining union membership, organized labor may be on the verge of a resurgence in the U.S. Employees seeking better working conditions and higher pay have recently organized unions at Starbucks, Amazon, Apple and elsewhere. Applications for union elections this year are on pace to approach their highest level in a decade. I asked Noam Scheiber, who covers workers and labor issues for The Times, what‚Äôs behind the latest flurry of union activity.

headline: I Went to the State Where the First Big Fight Over Abortion Is On. Here‚Äôs What I Saw.
text: KANSAS CITY, Kan. ‚Äî When Sharon Brown answered the door of her modest town home on a recent Saturday, she was a little rude at first to the two young women standing before her, Yazmin Bruno-Valdez and Melanie Haas. They introduced themselves as volunteers with Kansans for Constitutional Freedom, a group that sounds conservative but is fighting to preserve abortion rights in the state. They were knocking on doors in Wyandotte County, one of the state‚Äôs bluer pockets, urging voters to oppose an amendment to the Kansas Constitution that would pave the way for tighter abortion restrictions, even a total ban. Ms. Bruno-Valdez offered a ‚ÄúVote no‚Äù flyer explaining the measure, but Ms. Brown misunderstood which side the women were on. Rocking black fuzzy slippers and a hot pink robe, she made a disgusted face and waved the volunteers away. ‚ÄúI believe in abortion,‚Äù she said, moving to shut her door.

headline: Putting Family First, in a Pandemic and at a Price

headline: Don‚Äôt Drag Our Most Basic Rights Into the Culture Wars
text: One of my fustiest and most out-of-touch opinions is that progressives need to rediscover the political power of civil liberties. Such declarations usually accompany free speech controversies ‚Äî some professor gets canceled at some college with an 11 percent acceptance rate, everyone starts tweeting about who has the right to say what in which settings, and by the time it‚Äôs all forgotten two days later, nobody really has any clarity on what freedom of speech actually means. I will admit that as something of a free speech absolutist, I am not immune to such temptations. But I also acknowledge that these episodes don‚Äôt really have much to do with civil liberties at all. Instead, they use a vaguely defined ethos of free speech as a prop in an ongoing power struggle between two sides that have both largely lost the plot.

It‚Äôs a reprisal of a work she conceived in 1962 called ‚ÄúCelebration Red‚Äù (later titled ‚ÄúHomage to Each Red Thing‚Äù for Hans Ulrich Obrist‚Äôs influential show of artists‚Äô instructions ‚ÄúDo It.‚Äù) It‚Äôs also one of Knowles‚Äôs most famous ‚Äî and vivid ‚Äî participatory artworks in a long history of making them.

text: Churros, the irresistibly crunchy fluted cruller strips from the Iberian Peninsula that are often snacks and desserts in Spain, Portugal, Mexico and across Latin America, pair perfectly with ice cream. At ChikaLicious Dessert Bar, Chika and Don Tillman‚Äôs sweet spot in the East Village, they‚Äôre being twisted into crisp ice cream cones. They‚Äôre filled with oat milk ice cream called S‚Äômore Mother Earth, made with berries, graham crackers and a burnished marshmallow topping; available by reservation only.

With the cookbook author Eden Grinshpan as his sidekick, he will demonstrate various lightly charred kebabs, Israeli-style. headline: A Spritz With a Cassis Pedigree
text: Cassis should be Rachael Petach‚Äôs middle name. A year and a half ago she introduced C. Cassis, her Hudson Valley version of the French liqueur, the essential ingredient for a Kir. Now with her local blackcurrant liqueur as a base (cassis means black currant in French), she‚Äôs introduced a spritz. Some botanicals, honey and citrus peels with seltzer added to the liqueur make for a refreshing, pleasantly fruity yet tart quencher at 5.4 percent alcohol-by-volume. You could go stronger, using it as a cocktail mixer, leaning on its affinity for gin or vodka.

headline: The Art of the Serving Set
text: The work of Jono Pandolfi, a ceramist based in Union City, N.J., adorns the tables of a number of restaurants, among them Jean-Georges Vongerichten‚Äôs Nougatine. This month, he is offering a serving set designed for Mr. Vongerichten‚Äôs Seeds & Weeds, a restaurant soon to open in the Tin Building market in the Seaport District. The set is part of a series of special editions offered monthly; the next one will be released on Aug. 5. The Vongerichten set includes an oval red platter and three white bowls of varying sizes with hand-painted red stripes. The glazes Mr. Pandolfi applies to his clay pieces provide a look that‚Äôs at once rustic yet polished.

headline: A New Space for the French Cheese Board
text: French cheeses need no introduction. But in recent years selections from elsewhere in Europe and the United States have challenged the hegemony of Roquefort and Reblochon. Back in 2014, the French Dairy Board opened a storefront on Spring Street to promote its cheeses. Now it has moved to a larger, two story space nearby. The new French Cheese Board has a retail area stocked with a rotating selection of about 30 cheeses and 15 butters, a demonstration kitchen for classes and to allow chefs to experiment with the products, and an area to show the work of artists relating to flavor and dairy. Tasting classes covering the basics are scheduled for July 28, Aug. 4 and 24 at 6:30 p.m. ($49 each.)

headline: A Banner Year for Bristol Bay‚Äôs Sockeye Salmon Harvest
text: The sockeye salmon harvest in the Bristol Bay area of Alaska is expected to be among the largest on record. State officials are reporting a run of 74 million fish, mostly from Bristol Bay, during a season that started on June 1 and continues until early August. Bristol Bay, the world‚Äôs largest source for wild sockeye salmon, is a sustainably managed resource where thousands of local fishermen work on small boats. The salmon are smaller than king salmon, with firmer, succulent, characteristically deep red-orange flesh. The fish are widely shipped for sale in stores, online and in restaurants. Among the reliable sources for home cooks is Pride of Bristol Bay, which has started accepting orders for delivery in September. They sell the fish in 10- and 20-pound lots, either filleted sides of about 1.25 pounds each ($219.90 for 10 pounds, $399.80 for 20), or in individual 5- to 7-ounce portions ($229.90 for 10 pounds, $419.80 for 20).

headline: The Echoes and Echoes and Echoes of War
text: Violence ‚Äî whether between individuals or between nations ‚Äî has a long, intergenerational tail. It haunts the lives of those who witnessed, participated in or fell victim to that violence, and it haunts their descendants. Jamil Jan Kochai is one of those descendants. He was born to Afghan refugees in a camp in Peshawar, Pakistan, after the Soviet invasion of Afghanistan, and migrated to the United States as a child. He is currently a Stegner fellow at Stanford University, and his first novel, ‚Äú99 Nights in Logar,‚Äù was an interconnected series of stories with the war as a backdrop. His debut story collection is also about war, but it‚Äôs about family, too, and how each generation forges its own stories in the wake of the generation that preceded it.

headline: Long Ago, I Bought a Human Skull. What Should I Do With It?
text: In the 1970s, as a middle-school science teacher, I bought a preserved human skull from an educational-supply company. I did so in part for my own and my students‚Äô education and wonderment, and in part to have a fascinating conversation piece that I could put on my mantel. At the time, this was entirely legal. Since then, statutes have oscillated between permitting this commerce in human remains and outlawing it, though it has remained largely legal. Of course, there are now excellent plastic replicas available too.

headline: Why Housing Is So Expensive ‚Äî Particularly in Blue States

Developers often face the steepest obstacles to building in the places where new housing is needed most. And young people are increasingly viewing homeownership, once a vital part of the American dream, as hopelessly out of reach.

text: The European heat wave that baked Italy, France and Spain over the past week has reached London, putting life on hold and testing infrastructure. We traded clunky dialogue and then he leaned over and said: ‚ÄúI‚Äôm really enjoying getting to know you. ‚Ä¶ Can I kiss you?‚Äù As directed, I paused, then enthusiastically blurted out, ‚ÄúOK!‚Äù

headline: The Burger J. Kenji L√≥pez-Alt Can‚Äôt Improve (Only Tweak)
text: Humans have been cooking meat with onions for at least as long as recipes have been recorded, but I‚Äôd argue that the combination was simplified to its primal core during the Great Depression, when Homer Davis and his son Ross invented what they called the Depression burger at the Hamburger Inn in El Reno, Okla.

headline: Bodega Clerk Who Fatally Stabbed Man Will Not Face Charges
text: After weeks of mounting pressure, the Manhattan district attorney on Tuesday morning dropped a murder charge against a bodega clerk who fatally stabbed an attacker.

headline: Lizzo‚Äôs Empowerment Pop Gets Stuck in the Same Groove
text: Since her charismatic breakout hit ‚ÄúTruth Hurts‚Äù dominated the Hot 100 in 2019, the music of the Houston-raised singer, rapper, songwriter and flutist Lizzo has been a pop cultural omnipresence ‚Äî a glossy sonic lacquer ready to provide any humdrum moment with a hater-repellent sheen.

headline: Here‚Äôs a secret about your neighbors
text: Merciless heat is scorching much of Europe this month, with temperatures also hitting dangerous levels in parts of Asia and the Americas. It‚Äôs one of those times when global warming feels as undeniable as it feels scary.

headline: Manchin‚Äôs ‚ÄòVeto‚Äô of the Climate Bill, as the World Heats Up
text: To the Editor:

headline: Migrants in Morocco Are Sentenced in Attempt to Cross Into Spanish Enclave
text: PARIS ‚Äî A judge in the northeastern Moroccan city of Nador sentenced 33 migrants to 11 months in prison on Tuesday and ordered them to pay small fines in connection with a mass attempt to cross into the Spanish enclave of Melilla last month, defense lawyers said.

headline: Sinkhole Swallows Van in the Bronx
text: The sinkhole opened up after a heavy rainfall and caused damage to a water main.

headline: Bennie Thompson, chairman of the Jan. 6 panel, has tested positive for the coronavirus.
text: Representative Bennie Thompson of Mississippi, the chairman of the House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the United States Capitol, announced on Tuesday that he had tested positive for the coronavirus and would not appear in person at what could be the committee‚Äôs last hearing of the summer.

headline: ISIS Fighters‚Äô Children Are Growing Up in a Desert Camp. What Will They Become?
text: AL HOL, Syria ‚Äî Viewed from a helicopter, this enormous camp that holds the wives and children of dead or captured Islamic State fighters was a sea of white tents against the desolate landscape of drought-stricken northeastern Syria.

headline: A Behind-the-Scenes Eminence Shapes a Festival‚Äôs Future
text: AIX-EN-PROVENCE, France ‚Äî On a recent Monday afternoon, the Grand Th√©√¢tre de Provence here was almost empty, a few hours before a concert performance of Monteverdi‚Äôs opera ‚ÄúL‚ÄôOrfeo.‚Äù

headline: Sashay Away!
text: It has been two weeks or an internet eternity since Shaheel Sanil Prasad, a.k.a. Shaheel Shermont Flair, a former call center agent and part-time influencer from Suva City in central Fiji, posted one of the funniest catwalk videos ever to hit social media.

headline: Do Eye Creams Actually Work for Wrinkles?
text: Q: Does eye cream really prevent wrinkles?

headline: After Heavy Rains, a Sinkhole Opens in the Bronx
text: A sinkhole appeared in the Bronx on Monday as rain and high winds rolled through New York City, growing throughout the evening and swallowing a parked van.

headline: Britain‚Äôs record-breaking heat comes amid a closely watched political campaign.
text: LONDON ‚Äî Britain‚Äôs record-breaking heat wave came against the backdrop of an intensely watched national political contest, as the race to succeed Prime Minister Boris Johnson was winnowed to just candidates ahead of a critical vote on Wednesday.

headline: Money Managers Are in a ‚ÄòDire‚Äô Mood, Poll Finds
text: Investors are hoarding cash and lowering their expectations for growth, as pessimism about the outlook for the U.S. economy has reached a ‚Äúdire‚Äù level, according to a survey of 259 fund managers responsible for more than $700 billion in investments.

headline: How Penguins Beat the Heat and Went South
text: Few animals have evolved to survive the unforgiving Antarctic like penguins. Species like the emperor penguin have overlapping layers of insulating plumage, tightly packed veins to recycle body heat and just enough paunch to weather wind chills that approach minus 80 degrees Fahrenheit.

headline: Vacations Bar & Rooftop, With Tropical Drinks, Opens in Bushwick, Brooklyn
text: New York is blessed with rooftops galore for drinks and dining amid stupendous views.  Given a felicitous location, even the second floor will do as at this sprawling new bar in Bushwick, Brooklyn, with the Manhattan skyline as its backdrop. Come September, the building below will be turned into an all-seasons restaurant; for now, there is a bar on the rooftop, with a  second coming soon. (A third will be located downstairs.) It has a tropical influence, with greenery, weathered wood, green tiles, chessboard stone flooring and blue walls. Drinks and food are self-service, to order at the bar, with choices like fried smashed fingerling potatoes with aioli and brava sauce, shrimp cocktail, fish and chips, and a broccoli rabe hero. Drinks, all $12, include a Tropicale, made with Meyer lemon vodka, passion fruit liqueur, lime and guava juice; and the Proposal, made with pineapple rum, lime and simple syrup. Vantage Point Hospitality owns and runs Vacations with Annie and Andy Shaner, restaurant veterans who live in the neighborhood.

headline: Netflix Says It Lost Nearly 1 Million Subscribers, and Breathes a Sigh of Relief
text: Disaster has been averted at Netflix.

headline: Elon Musk and Twitter will go to trial over their $44 billion deal in October.
text: Twitter and Elon Musk will go to trial in October over whether the billionaire must complete his $44 billion acquisition of the social media company, a Delaware judge ruled on Tuesday.

headline: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Jenny Schuetz
text: Every Tuesday and Friday, Ezra Klein invites you into a conversation about something that matters, like today‚Äôs episode with Jenny Schuetz. Listen wherever you get your podcasts.

headline: From Adam Pendleton, Pancakes That Taste Like Perfection
text: In ‚ÄúOne Good Meal,‚Äù we ask cooking-inclined creative people to share the story behind a favorite dish they actually make and eat at home on a regular basis ‚Äî and not just when they‚Äôre trying to impress.

headline: ‚ÄòPorn of the Self‚Äô: Novels of Female Angst
text: Eighteen-year-old Raizl hiding her laptop beneath her covers while she basks in the glow of endless, muted porn is a picture burned into my memory as permanently as the shvantzes and shmundies are in the protagonist‚Äôs imagination (look them up). Felicia Berliner‚Äôs SHMUTZ (260 pp., Atria, $27) is about a young woman with a porn addiction that‚Äôs somehow even more forbidden than most.

headline: ‚ÄòAftershock‚Äô Review: A Moving Ode to the Black Family
text: There‚Äôs no getting around just how terribly sad it feels watching ‚ÄúAftershock,‚Äù the new documentary from the directors Paula Eiselt (‚Äú93Queen‚Äù) and Tonya Lewis Lee. After all, it spotlights the tragic deaths of two Black mothers in New York City who died from childbirth-related complications ‚Äî Shamony Gibson, in 2019, and Amber Isaac, in 2020 ‚Äî leaving behind young children, partners, families and communities gutted by grief.

headline: British homes were built to retain heat. That‚Äôs becoming a problem.
text: For generations, homes in Britain were designed to retain heat, to make cold winters bearable.

headline: Facing Tepid Support, Bill de Blasio Drops N.Y. House Bid
text: Bill de Blasio, the former mayor of New York City, abruptly ended a campaign for Congress on Tuesday, saying that voters were clearly ‚Äúlooking for another option‚Äù and that his time in electoral politics was over.

headline: Trying to Salvage His Climate Agenda, Biden Weighs Remaining Options
text: President Biden will travel Wednesday to a shuttered coal-fired power plant that is now part of an offshore wind project in Massachusetts, where he is expected to deliver remarks on clean energy as his administration scrambles to salvage its climate agenda.

headline: Inflation: A Revolution of Falling Expectations
text: Macroeconomic policy in the United States has been subject to two great errors over the past half-century. The odds are that you‚Äôve only heard about the first, the way the Federal Reserve allowed inflation to become entrenched in the 1970s. But the second ‚Äî the way policymakers allowed the economy to operate far below capacity, needlessly sacrificing millions of potential jobs, for a decade following the financial crisis ‚Äî was arguably even more severe.

headline: Questions About An Unsolved Murder Linger Over ‚ÄòWhere the Crawdads Sing‚Äô
text: When Delia Owens, a retired wildlife biologist, released her novel ‚ÄúWhere the Crawdads Sing‚Äù in 2018, no one anticipated a blockbuster. Owens, who is in her early 70s, had never published fiction before. Her publisher printed a modest run of 28,000 hardcover copies.

headline: New York City Opens Cooling Centers as It Braces for a Heat Wave
text: As New Yorkers brace for a week of extremely hot weather, cooling centers in air-conditioned buildings throughout the city will be open to the public from Tuesday through Thursday to offer relief from the heat.

headline: In ‚ÄòThe Pink Hotel,‚Äô Delusional Newlyweds Head Toward a Grand Reckoning
text: One strange element of human behavior is that much of what we call ‚Äúvacation‚Äù involves endlessly tinkering with our body temperatures. Think of the beach. You lie on a towel, grow hot, dip in the ocean to cool down, get out, reheat yourself, dip, cool down, repeat. The joy of recreation can‚Äôt be reduced to the fact that it‚Äôs really fun to swivel between hot and cold, but signature vacation moments often involve just that: snuggling up to a campfire on a cold night, plunging into a frigid lake on a sweltering afternoon, coming in from the snow to warm up with cocoa.

headline: 3 Ways Musk Can Support Free Speech
text: Way back in the Paleolithic age of April, Elon Musk seemed excited to buy Twitter and said that he wanted to transform the site by promoting free speech.

headline: Hasbro reports rising sales on strong demand, despite higher prices.
text: Despite higher prices, people continued to spend on Nerf blasters, Power Rangers action figures and Magic the Gathering cards, helping Hasbro overcome rising costs for materials and freight, the company said on Tuesday.

headline: Mapping Europe‚Äôs Heat Wave
text: Maps show where soaring temperatures have spread across Europe, many in areas unaccustomed to such extreme heat.

headline: ‚ÄòLaw & Order‚Äô Crew Member Is Fatally Shot at Brooklyn Film Location
text: A Brooklyn film location for a ripped-from-the-headlines television crime show became a murder scene early Tuesday when a man who was enforcing parking restrictions connected to the production was fatally shot while he sat in a car, the police said.

headline: Tiny Love Stories: ‚ÄòJust Like Me, but Hotter‚Äô
text: After a terrible year (I was attacked in my home then suffered through a difficult divorce), my elderly parents visited and helped me pull the ivy that had swallowed my backyard. My father said, ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt let that take over again, Irene.‚Äù Ten years later, while grappling with stubborn regrowth, I found dad‚Äôs hat ‚Äî gnarled, mouse nibbled, rotted. I‚Äôd been missing him fiercely, wishing he were still here to guide me. Not one for assigning spiritual meaning to coincidence, I‚Äôll take this particular tap on the shoulder. Thanks for taking care of me, dad. I‚Äôll take care of the ivy. ‚Äî Irene Ziegler

headline: Ritzi Jacobi, Maker of Mind-Bending Textile Art, Dies at 80
text: Ritzi Jacobi, a European pioneer of contemporary textile and fiber art who was best known for her monumental wall hangings and soft sculptures, died on June 19 at her home in D√ºsseldorf, Germany. She was 80.

headline: ‚ÄòA Dark, Dark Man‚Äô Review: Murder and Corruption in Kazakhstan
text: ‚ÄúA Dark, Dark Man‚Äù is set in a stretch of Kazakhstan where few people seem to live, yet corruption pervades every corner.

headline: How to Spend a Day in Brighton Beach
text: I like to say that New York City is famously a beach town. It certainly has more beach access than where I grew up ‚Äî landlocked¬†metro Atlanta; that you can get to most of these beaches by subway, bus, bike or ferry is even better.

headline: Ann Shulgin, 91, Who Explored Psychedelics With Her Husband, Dies
text: Ann Shulgin, who alongside her husband, Alexander Shulgin, developed and experimented with hundreds of psychedelic drugs that he concocted in his California laboratory, then showed readers how to formulate them in a pair of massive books that attracted a cult following, died on July 9 at her home near Lafayette, Calif. She was 91.

headline: Scenes of Devastation Emerge From a Fire-Ravaged Southwestern France
text: LA TESTE-DE-BUCH, France ‚Äî As firefighters battled raging wildfires for the eighth consecutive day in southwest France, scenes of devastation emerged from the ashes, underscoring yet another facet of the disastrous effects of the heat wave currently sweeping Europe.

headline: Iran warns Turkey against new incursion into northern Syria.
text: Iran warned Turkey on Tuesday against launching a new military operation in Syria just before the leaders of both countries attended a three-way summit meeting with Russia‚Äôs president.

headline: Your Wednesday Briefing: Putin Visits Iran
text: Vladimir Putin, Russia‚Äôs president, visited Iran on Tuesday, underscoring how the war in Ukraine has altered the world‚Äôs geopolitics by helping to align two regional powers that have been isolated from Europe and the U.S.

headline: Claes Oldenburg Captured a Carefree (and Consumerist) America
text: Of all the major American Pop artists, Claes Oldenburg was the only one who was born in Europe. He was still in grade school when his father, a Swedish diplomat, moved the family to this country. They settled in Chicago, a city that has a much-lauded architectural history and calls itself, not unjustly, the birthplace of the skyscraper.

headline: Dana Canedy, Publisher of Simon & Schuster‚Äôs Flagship Imprint, Has Left the Job
text: Dana Canedy, the first Black woman to serve as publisher of Simon & Schuster‚Äôs flagship imprint, left her position after two years, the company said on Tuesday.

headline: Why Russia Believes It Cannot Lose the War in Ukraine
text: Sergey Karaganov is a prominent Russian political scientist whom I have known for almost 20 years in covering Russia and have interviewed many times as a window into Kremlin thinking. The academic director of the faculty of World Economy and International Affairs at Moscow‚Äôs Higher School of Economics and honorary chairman of Russia‚Äôs premier nongovernmental think tank, Mr. Karaganov warned for years about a potential conflict in Ukraine over NATO expansion. Since the brutal Russian invasion of Ukraine began in February, he has written articles and given interviews in broad support of President Vladimir Putin, so I interviewed him to better understand Mr. Putin‚Äôs aims in the conflict. Ukraine continues to suffer, and those who hope to support Ukraine must understand those aims as it tries to confront Russia‚Äôs aggression.

headline: Maryland‚Äôs primary election results are expected to be delayed.
text: Maryland is the only state that prohibits mail-in ballots from being processed until after the election, a prepandemic rule that lawmakers were unsuccessful in changing.

text: See full results and maps from the Maryland primary elections.

headline: Spanish Authorities Seize a ‚ÄòContraband‚Äô Picasso at Ibiza Airport
text: Officials in Spain seized a drawing believed to be by Pablo Picasso valued at more than $460,000 from a passenger who failed to declare it to airport customs, the Tax Agency and Civil Guard in Spain said in a statement on Monday.

headline: Europe‚Äôs Heat Wave Shatters British Records and Drives Wildfires
text: LONDON ‚Äî For the first time on record, Britain suffered under temperatures above 40 degrees Celsius ‚Äî 104 Fahrenheit ‚Äî on Tuesday, as a ferocious heat wave moved northwest, leaving a trail of raging wildfires, lost lives and evacuated homes across a Europe frighteningly ill-equipped to cope with the new reality of extreme weather.

headline: A Mariupol teen wrapped in the Ukrainian flag has become a symbol of resistance.
text: It is a searing image: A 17-year-old boy wrapped in a Ukrainian flag and standing near a theater that was destroyed by a Russian airstrike in the razed southern city of Mariupol. The sky in the photograph‚Äôs frame is a clear blue and all around him is ruin and destruction.

headline: Ukrainian D.J. Spins Rare Music in N.Y.C.
text: Daria Kolomiec, a D.J. from Kyiv, is playing Ukrainian music in New York City clubs this summer.

headline: The C.D.C. shuts down its public Covid dashboard for cruise ships.
text: The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has ended its Covid-19 mitigation program for cruise ships in U.S. waters, the public health agency announced on its website.

text: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here‚Äôs the sign-up.)

headline: House Moves to Protect Same-Sex Marriage From Supreme Court Reversal
text: WASHINGTON ‚Äî The House on Tuesday passed a bill that would recognize same-sex marriages at the federal level, with a bipartisan coalition supporting a measure that addresses growing concerns that a conservative Supreme Court could nullify marriage equality.

headline: Intelligence Agencies Say Russia Election Threat Persists Amid Ukraine War
text: Top national security officials warned on Tuesday about the continuing threat of election interference from abroad, emphasizing that Russia could still seek to meddle or promote disinformation during the 2022 midterm races even as it wages war in Ukraine.

headline: On Sweltering New York Day, Rockaway Beaches Close Over Shark Sightings
text: As temperatures in Queens climbed into the 90s, Rockaway‚Äôs beaches were closed on Tuesday afternoon for swimming because of shark sightings, officials said, leaving only the boardwalk open for beachgoers on the hot day.

headline: Secret Service Says Some Missing Jan. 6 Texts Are Unlikely to Be Recovered
text: WASHINGTON ‚Äî The Secret Service said it may not be able to recover a batch of erased text messages from phones used by its agents around the time of the attack on the Capitol last year, a development that comes amid intensified scrutiny over lapses in the agency‚Äôs accounting of its actions during the riots.

headline: Bannon ‚ÄòDecided He Was Above the Law,‚Äô Prosecutor Says
text: WASHINGTON ‚Äî After weeks of legal wrangling and heated speeches on the courthouse steps, the criminal trial of Stephen K. Bannon, a onetime aide to former President Donald J. Trump, opened on Tuesday as prosecutors told the jury they would have to answer a simple question: Did Mr. Bannon defy the House select committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol by blatantly ignoring a subpoena?

headline: Soaring Overdose Rates in the Pandemic Reflected Widening Racial Disparities
text: The pandemic‚Äôs devastating impact on drug overdose deaths in the United States hit people of color the hardest, with rates among young Black people rising the most sharply, according to a federal report that was released on Tuesday and that analyzed overdose data by race, age and income.

headline: Amid Campaign Revamp, Herschel Walker Stumps Without a Stumble
text: OCILLA, Ga. ‚Äî Herschel Walker, Georgia‚Äôs Republican nominee for the U.S. Senate, gave a 10-minute stump speech on Tuesday in which he told no new whoppers, made no obvious mistakes and allowed reporters to witness the whole thing.

headline: The Midterm Races That Give Democrats Nightmares
text: Professional Democrats have many fears about the 2022 midterm elections that keep them up at night.

headline: Putin Finds a New Ally in Iran, a Fellow Outcast
text: President Vladimir V. Putin left Russia for a rare international trip on Tuesday and received a handsome reward: a meeting with a prominent world leader who voiced a full-throated endorsement for Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine.

headline: Trump Electors Targeted in Georgia Criminal Inquiry
text: Prosecutors in Atlanta have informed 16 Trump supporters who formed an alternate slate of 2020 presidential electors from Georgia that they could face charges in an ongoing criminal investigation into election interference, underscoring the risk of criminal charges that Donald J. Trump and many of his allies may be facing in the state.

headline: M.L.B. Commissioner Rejects Idea That Minor Leaguers Aren‚Äôt Paid Fairly
text: LOS ANGELES ‚Äî Asked why Major League Baseball‚Äôs team owners do not pay minor league players a living wage ‚Äî whether it was because they could not afford to or because they didn‚Äôt want to ‚Äî M.L.B. Commissioner Rob Manfred suggested those players were actually compensated fairly.

headline: Abortion Provider Prepares Defamation Suit Against Indiana Attorney General
text: An Indianapolis doctor who provided abortion care to a 10-year-old rape victim is preparing to sue Attorney General Todd Rokita of Indiana for defamation after he said he would investigate her actions in the case, according to a statement released on Tuesday by her lawyer.

headline: U.S. Marshals Seek Man Mistakenly Freed in Shooting of Lady Gaga‚Äôs Dog Walker
text: The U.S. Marshals Service this week announced a $5,000 reward for information that leads to the capture of a 19-year-old man who was charged last year with stealing two of Lady Gaga‚Äôs French bulldogs and shooting her dog walker ‚Äî but was accidentally released from a Los Angeles jail in April.

headline: After Indiana Mall Shooting, One Hero but No Lasting Solution
text: It was an act of pluck and composure worthy of a scene in the movies. But this was real life: A heavily armed man emerged from the bathroom in a Greenwood, Ind., shopping mall on Sunday evening and began shooting ‚Äî until he was killed by an armed bystander.

headline: Corrections: July 20, 2022
text: An article on July 13 about the recovery of timbers from the so-called Beeswax Wreck omitted a credit to the news organization that first reported how researchers identified the Beeswax Wreck as the Santo Cristo de Burgos, a 17th-century Spanish galleon. The findings were reported on June 16 by National Geographic.

headline: Leading Russian Tennis Player Criticizes War in Ukraine
text: For the first time since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, a Russian tennis player has publicly criticized the war, a move that may land her in trouble if and when she returns to her home country.

headline: The highest-ranked Russian in women‚Äôs tennis calls the war ‚Äòa full-blown nightmare.‚Äô
text: For the first time since Russia invaded Ukraine in February, a Russian tennis player has publicly criticized the war, a move that may land her in trouble if and when she returns to her home country.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Hey, Is Anybody Watching the Interns?
text: ‚ÄúThe thing I‚Äôve always been taught by my parents is to be the first one in and last one out. But there‚Äôs no one else there.‚Äù

headline: A View From the Right on Progressives‚Äô ‚ÄòMoral Crusade‚Äô
text: For years, Republicans have been known as the party of moral outrage. Take for instance the recent book banning wars, or Florida‚Äôs ‚ÄúDon‚Äôt Say Gay‚Äù bill. But Democrats aren‚Äôt immune to moral outrage. At least that‚Äôs what Noah Rothman, a conservative writer and commentator, believes. He is the author of the new book ‚ÄúThe Rise of the New Puritans: Fighting Back Against Progressives‚Äô War on Fun.‚Äù In it, he argues that progressives, in their pursuit of liberal ideals, are fueling a movement of moral panics more reminiscent of 17th-century preachifying than 1960s liberalism ‚Äî and that we‚Äôre all worse off for it.

headline: What Driving Means for America
text: The experience of driving across America, which my family just recklessly embraced, is an experience of America but, of course, also an experience of driving. In the last three weeks I‚Äôve spent roughly 55 hours behind the wheel, counting all our detours and side trips, in a rented American minivan (the make and rental company shall remain anonymous) that turned out to have two leaky tires and low oil and a middle seat whose headrest couldn‚Äôt be detached to fit our carseat without assistance from several YouTube videos.

headline: Chance, Design and Inevitability in Three New Poetry Books
text: Some people believe that before we are born, we choose our own parents. In a poem called ‚ÄúThe First Number Will Be a Blues,‚Äù Sommer Browning describes one version of this story: ‚ÄúBefore we‚Äôre born, my mother tells us, / We watch movies of every life we might be born into. Then we choose. / The little baby points from her / astral cradle.‚Äù The speaker marvels at the implications: ‚ÄúI choose that mama. / I choose that daddy. / I choose that irrevocably broken marriage, / That accident that wires my jaw shut, / That burned popcorn‚Äù ‚Äî the litany continues ‚Äî ‚ÄúThat root canal, that unending night on mushrooms, / That dog bite.‚Äù ‚ÄúThat DUI.‚Äù Is it absurd to imagine we select our own pattern of suffering, or that we might have picked a life without any? As Willard Spiegelman notes in his book ‚ÄúSeven Pleasures,‚Äù ‚Äú‚ÄòHap‚Äô means chance.‚Äù Happiness and happen share the same root. Whether we choose them or not, the random happenings of our lives, good and bad, are our own. The details that add up to days and years ‚Äî your street name, your first word, your favorite podcast ‚Äî have what Ernest Becker might have called a ‚Äúcosmic specialness.‚Äù

headline: Michael Mann‚Äôs Damaged Men
text: Michael Mann stood at the center of a long, sunlit room, scrutinizing a model of the Ferrari factory as it looked in 1957, thinking about how to improve its appearance. ‚ÄúThis should be a pattern,‚Äù he said, pointing at the windows, ‚Äúso that you have almost a musical rhythm, like, two-two-two-two-two, then it breaks, to drive your attention to the entryway.‚Äù Around him, a half-dozen collaborators listened closely. After Mann‚Äôs decisions were finalized, a construction team would be dispatched to a nearby site to build a replica of the 1957 factory.

headline: Fighting a Brutal Regime With the Help of a Video Game

headline: A Chocolate Cake for the Queen of ASMR Eating
text: The sound of people eating, chewing, enjoying food makes me sleepy, which is unfortunate, considering that I cook for a living. I‚Äôve had this, let‚Äôs call it ‚Äúgift,‚Äù for as long as I can remember. It could have been anything: my father‚Äôs snacking on salted peanuts while watching the Golf Channel; a classmate‚Äôs opening a bag of chips in the library, crinkling the crispy polypropylene; the clickety-clacking of a lozenge around the mouth of my third-grade teacher, Mrs. Smith, while she explained an assignment, each word trailing off in my ears as I fell asleep at my desk. Though I didn‚Äôt know it at the time, these eating sounds gave me a relaxing, tingling sensation in my brain, an auditory-tactile synesthesia that scientists call A.S.M.R., or autonomous sensory meridian response. For me, that response is instantaneous somnolence.

headline: Endemic Covid-19 Looks Pretty Brutal
text: It may surprise you to learn, given the pandemic mood of the country and indeed the world, that probably half of all Covid infections have happened this calendar year ‚Äî and it‚Äôs only July. By December, the figure could be 80 percent or more. The gap between cases and severe outcomes is bigger than it has ever been, with the fraction of infections ending in deaths one-tenth that of the pandemic‚Äôs early stages. But simply in terms of infection, this year towers over each of the previous two.

headline: After Roe, Sex Ed Is Even More Vital

headline: Inflation Is Bad, but Unemployment Is Far Worse
text: What‚Äôs worse, higher inflation or higher unemployment? That question is at the core of the debate over how rapidly the Federal Reserve should raise interest rates to cool off the economy and bring inflation down from its 40-year highs. If you think higher inflation is worse, then it makes sense to raise rates hard and fast, even at the cost of causing a recession. If you think higher unemployment is worse, then moving cautiously is a better choice.

headline: ‚ÄòThe Gray Man‚Äô Review: Guy vs. Guy

The Russos‚Äô lead, an agent known as Six (Ryan Gosling), wears a snazzy red suit with matching fingernail polish to his first onscreen assassination. Six works for his freedom, not his 401(k): He is a convicted murderer who was plucked from prison by a government suit (played by Billy Bob Thornton) and placed in a secret kill squadron. He seems to be OK with the deal, despite showing a light layer of fatigue that Gosling wears like a rain poncho.

headline: Have You Been Reinfected With Covid?

headline: What are the signs of heat stroke?
text: The symptoms of heat stroke, according to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, include a high body temperature (103 degrees Fahrenheit, or 39.5 degrees Celsius, or higher); hot, red, dry or damp skin; a fast and strong pulse; a headache; dizziness; nausea; confusion and passing out. If someone is experiencing these symptoms, call your local emergency number and try to move the person into the shade or a cooler area. You can also use cool cloths or a cool bath to lower the person‚Äôs body temperature. Do not give him or her anything to drink.
