headline: Putin, Chekhov and the Theater of Despair
text: LONDON ‚Äî There‚Äôs a chill in the air at the Almeida Theater, notwithstanding the record-breaking heat here. That drop in temperature comes from the coolly unnerving ‚ÄúPatriots,‚Äù a new drama whose look at power politics in Russia over the last quarter-century induces a shiver at despotism‚Äôs rise.

headline: Italy‚Äôs President Accepts Draghi Resignation, Calling for New Elections
text: ROME ‚Äî Italy‚Äôs president on Thursday accepted the resignation of Prime Minister Mario Draghi, dissolved Parliament and called for new elections, bringing to a close an exceptional period of Italian stability and influence, and opening what promised to be a chaotic political season as Europe struggles to maintain resolve in the face of Russian aggression.

headline: New York Times Columnists on What They Got Wrong
text: Eight Times Opinion columnists revisit their incorrect predictions and bad advice ‚Äî and reflect on why they changed their minds.

headline: Holding Out for the Right Fit in Brooklyn. Which Apartment Did She Choose?
text: Reluctant to renew an expensive lease, and working remotely, a first-time buyer took her $700,000 budget to three Brooklyn neighborhoods. These were her options.

headline: A Pastor Ripped Apart by Our Divided Country
text: America is burned out. Between the stress of the pandemic, growing polarization and declining trust in institutions, many people are near their breaking point. The feeling is particularly acute for those who have traditionally been society‚Äôs bridge builders ‚Äî teachers, health care workers, faith leaders ‚Äî as they increasingly find themselves in the cross hairs of our divisions.

headline: Hip, Woke, Cool: It‚Äôs All Fodder For the Oxford Dictionary of African American English
text: The first time she heard Barbara Walters use the expression ‚Äúshout out‚Äù on television, Tracey Weldon took note.

headline: I Was Wrong About Inflation
text: In early 2021 there was an intense debate among economists about the likely consequences of the American Rescue Plan, the $1.9 trillion package enacted by a new Democratic president and a (barely) Democratic Congress. Some warned that the package would be dangerously inflationary; others were fairly relaxed. I was Team Relaxed. As it turned out, of course, that was a very bad call.

headline: I Was Wrong About Chinese Censorship
text: Among the most important questions that I‚Äôve wrestled with since becoming a columnist in 1995 are if, when and how fast China will open up its information ecosystem to allow a much freer flow of uncensored news ‚Äî from both Chinese and foreign sources. I confess that I‚Äôve been too optimistic. I plead guilty.

headline: I Was Wrong About Why Protests Work
text: Growing up in Turkey, with my childhood under the shadow of heavy censorship, I was fascinated by what new technologies would mean for the world and especially for free speech and dissent. I got into a graduate school in the United States, hoping to study how the internet and the digital transformation were affecting society. I was especially curious about the relationships among technology, dissent and protests.

headline: I Was Wrong About Capitalism
text: I have a specific way I tend to be wrong. I fall behind. Every day the world turns and every day I try to adjust my belief system to the realities of the moment. You would think I‚Äôd be able to recognize the emerging challenges and shifting tectonics fairly quickly. As a newspaper columnist, I‚Äôm paid for one skill above others: careful observation. But sometimes I‚Äôm just slow. I suffer an intellectual lag.

headline: Poem: Excerpts from the Poem ‚ÄòHeadlands Quadrats‚Äô
text: These excerpts are a masterwork in opposites ‚Äî shape and disarray, the known and the unknown, desert and blooming, doom and hope. The small sections physically look like plots used for ecological studies, their insides brimming with language, emotion and movement. Language occasionally cuts with slanted syntax. A doe‚Äôs fear is described so that the reader can feel this fear through discombobulated language. There‚Äôs more subtle surprise, too, with the gentle synesthesia of ‚Äúa coyote/exactly the color of July.‚Äù The repetition of war and complicity is deftly handled: ‚Äúthe ridge we curl into/during a different war//without trees to shade/their names soldiers did too.‚Äù  Poem Selected by Victoria Chang

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Brunch Parameters
text: Andy writes: My friend and I have debated the concept of brunch for years. He eats ‚Äúbrunch‚Äù in the afternoon. He can eat when he wants, but words have meanings. And brunch is a meal between breakfast and lunch that takes place before noon.

headline: I Was Wrong About Mitt Romney (and His Dog)
text: I‚Äôve been thinking about columns I‚Äôve come to regret over the years. Hmm, lots of potential there. But let me go back to Mitt Romney.

headline: Nearly a Third of Gen Z Is Living at Home (and They Plan to Stay)
text: This year‚Äôs rapid inflation rates have meant higher prices for virtually everything, including rent, food and even partying. So what comes next may not be much of a surprise: Nearly a third of Americans between the ages of 18 and 25 ‚Äî part of what is collectively known as Gen Z ‚Äî live at home with their parents or other relatives, according to a new study, and they considered it a long-term housing solution.

headline: A Quicksilver Mystery That Flickers, Flashes, Twists and Turns
text: Riku Onda has been a fixture of Japanese suspense literature since the 1990s, but she found her audience in the Anglophone world with her 2020 English-language debut, ‚ÄúThe Aosawa Murders,‚Äù translated by Alison Watts and released by Bitter Lemon Press, a small London-based publisher of international crime fiction. ‚ÄúFish Swimming in Dappled Sunlight,‚Äù a dreamy, circuitous psychological thriller, is Onda‚Äôs second work to be translated into English, again by Watts.

headline: We Are Retired Generals and Admirals. Trump‚Äôs Actions on Jan. 6 Were a Dereliction of Duty.
text: The inquiry by the House‚Äôs Jan. 6 committee has produced many startling findings, but none to us more alarming than the fact that while rioters tried to thwart the peaceful transfer of power and ransacked the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, the president and commander in chief, Donald Trump, abdicated his duty to preserve, protect and defend the Constitution.

headline: I Was Wrong About Al Franken
text: During the height of the #MeToo movement in 2017, a woman named Leeann Tweeden accused Al Franken of sexually harassing her during his comedian days and produced a photo of him pretending to grope her breasts. I called on Franken to resign from the Senate, not because I thought his alleged actions were irredeemable, but because I thought Democrats should free themselves of the burden of defending him.

headline: Ruth Ware Won‚Äôt Read ‚ÄòBleak House‚Äô Until She Retires
text: Too many to list. I mean, literally about 20 or 30 titles. Some are old favorites that I like to dip back into after a hard day ‚Äî ‚ÄúHowl‚Äôs Moving Castle,‚Äù by Diana Wynne Jones, would fall into that category. Some are books I finished a while ago and just haven‚Äôt moved to the shelves in my office ‚Äî Sarah Pinborough‚Äôs ‚ÄúInsomnia‚Äù or Dorothy Koomson‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Ice Cream Girls,‚Äù for example. Some are books I‚Äôm in the middle of or have yet to get to ‚Äî Lisa Jewell‚Äôs ‚ÄúThe Family Remains‚Äù is one of those. I‚Äôm halfway through and got distracted by something I had to read for an event, but it‚Äôs waiting for me!

headline: There‚Äôs a Reason We Can‚Äôt Have Nice Things
text: The United States is one of six countries in the world without a national guarantee of paid parental leave. Twenty-three other countries have universal child or family allowances. We spend just 0.2 percent of our gross domestic product on child care for our youngest children, compared with an average of 0.7 percent among countries in the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development.

headline: New Reading Curriculum Is Mired in Debate Over Race and Gender
text: Lucy Calkins, a professor at Columbia University, has long been a controversial figure in the education world for her approach to teaching reading. Her eagerly anticipated new curriculum was meant to address her critics with a more research-backed, phonics-based approach to literacy.

headline: Murder in the Brain-Broiling Heat and Red Dust of the Outback
text: Imagine a remote Australian town, hours from anywhere and on the road to nowhere. Bypassed by highways, forgotten by time. There are no tourist-bait boutiques ‚Äî no farmers‚Äô markets or dinky little tearooms ‚Äî just a handful of relics: a dingy pub, a school, a half-stocked grocery store, a one-man cop shop. A church or two. Imagine a town of rough-handed men and stoic women; of cast-iron silences and failing farms; of swift gossip and slow reckonings. A town baked to dust by the paint-stripping, brain-boiling Aussie heat.

headline: Gabrielle Zevin Is Not Going to Post This Article
text: If you visit Gabrielle Zevin‚Äôs author website, you will encounter a kind of opacity that is downright refreshing. In lieu of links to Twitter, Facebook, TikTok, Snapchat, YouTube, LinkedIn and so forth, Zevin provides an unusual statement. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm allergic to being online, but you will sometimes find me on Instagram, and only for the three months before and after I have a book out,‚Äù she writes under the ‚ÄúContact‚Äù tab. ‚ÄúAfter that time, I completely disappear from the internet and resume writing books again.‚Äù

headline: How to Make a Decision When There‚Äôs No ‚ÄòRight‚Äô One
text: In 1838, Charles Darwin faced a problem. Nearing his 30th birthday, he was trying to decide whether to marry ‚Äî with the likelihood that children would be part of the package.

headline: I Was Wrong About Trump Voters

headline: I Was Wrong About Facebook
text: Early in 2009, I offered the world some tech advice that I have regretted pretty much ever since: I told everyone to join Facebook.

headline: How Software Is Stifling Competition and Slowing Innovation
text: More than a decade ago, Marc Andreessen, the internet entrepreneur and venture capitalist, famously declared, ‚ÄúSoftware is eating the world.‚Äù

text: Outside City Hall, as a nonprofit social justice group was unveiling a report about public safety for Black New Yorkers, Mayor Eric Adams suddenly emerged from the building.

headline: She Wants to Heal the World Through Second Line
text: In most places, people either watch parades or march in them. In New Orleans, they have another option: second line.

headline: New York‚Äôs Last Movie Clerk Knows More Than You Do
text: As the founder and sole employee of Film Noir Cinema, Will Malitek appears to be the final movie rental clerk left in New York City.

headline: San Francisco Shines With New Museums, Restaurants and Parks

headline: Through It All, Staten Island Cricket Endures
text: The moment that Nancy Johnson saw the gentlemen in white throwing and batting on the thin, sandy pitch carved into Walker Park on Saturday, she flashed back to the 1950s. As a young girl, she had gone with her father, who was from Grenada, to the same park on Staten Island, sometimes with a picnic basket, and watched.

headline: The Penn Station $7 Billion Fix-Up Moves Ahead: Here‚Äôs What to Know
text: New York State officials on Thursday approved a sweeping redevelopment of Midtown Manhattan that would transform Pennsylvania Station, the busiest transportation hub in North America, from a run-down transit center into a city centerpiece. The eight-member board of Empire State Development, the state‚Äôs economic development agency and the group steering the project, unanimously voted in favor. The plan calls for constructing 10 towers around Penn Station and providing an estimated $1.2 billion in tax breaks to developers.

headline: A Recession Alarm Is Ringing on Wall Street
text: Wall Street‚Äôs most-talked-about recession indicator is sounding its loudest alarm in two decades, intensifying concerns among investors that the U.S. economy is heading toward a slowdown.

text: It‚Äôs Never Too Late is a series about people who decide to pursue their dreams on their own terms.

text: Complaining about the sorry state of New York City‚Äôs airports has become a national pastime.

headline: Europe Joins Fight Against Inflation, Raising Rates for First Time in 11 Years
text: FRANKFURT ‚Äî As consumer prices across Europe soar at the fastest rate in generations, officials in Frankfurt on Thursday took a powerful step to control rapid inflation amid mounting concerns over an economic slowdown.

headline: Baltimore Symphony‚Äôs New Conductor Breaks a Racial Barrier
text: For decades, the 25 largest orchestras in the United States have been led almost exclusively by white men.

headline: The Case Against Donald Trump
text: A series of blockbuster hearings from the Jan. 6 committee has put growing pressure on Attorney General Merrick B. Garland to bring criminal charges against former President Donald J. Trump over the efforts to overturn the 2020 election.

headline: Ukrainian troops gain confidence after retaking a village.
text: PAVLIVKA, Ukraine ‚Äî A sheep dog, padding the streets on his own, was the only sign of life in this destroyed village. Flames licked the rafters of the school and smoke poured out of a burning house several streets away after Russian artillery strikes earlier in the day.

headline: The Latest Covid Surge
text: The Covid virus has a Darwinian quality. As variants emerge, they compete with one another to become dominant. The most contagious variants tend to win the competition because they can spread more quickly. It‚Äôs survival of the fittest.

headline: Nolan Ryan Had a Softer Side. He Just Hid It (Very) Well.

headline: Russia continues to bombard Kharkiv despite little recent progress in Moscow‚Äôs eastern campaign.
text: Even as Russian forces have stalled in their advance in eastern Ukraine, they continued their unrelenting bombardment of the country‚Äôs second largest city, Kharkiv, on Thursday as the Ukrainians in turn pursued a limited counteroffensive in the direction of the eastern city.

headline: ‚ÄòMy Donkey, My Lover & I‚Äô Review: Three‚Äôs a Crowd
text: ‚ÄúMy Donkey, My Lover & I‚Äù is yet another story about a woman who ventures out into the wild and finds herself. But to the writer and director Caroline Vignal‚Äôs credit, this low-key romantic French comedy proves friskier and more idiosyncratic than its reliance on this trope of feminist empowerment would suggest.

headline: ‚ÄòMy Old School‚Äô Review: An Impostor Makes the Honor Roll
text: ‚ÄúWhat is a person?‚Äù It‚Äôs a profound and complicated philosophical question, posed by a man named Stefen during an interview in ‚ÄúMy Old School.‚Äù Like most of the other people who appear on camera in this brisk, slippery documentary, Stefen has a particular person in mind, a student at Bearsden Academy in the early ‚Äô90s known to his classmates as Brandon Lee.

headline: ‚ÄòThe Reverend‚Äô Review: A Beer With a Music Chaser
text: When singing ‚ÄúGet Out of My Way,‚Äù the Rev. Vince Anderson takes no time getting to a growl and a wail. Anderson, the subject of the oft-rousing documentary ‚ÄúThe Reverend,‚Äù and his band, the Love Choir, have had a 20-year residency at Union Pool, a bar in Williamsburg. And that brassy, organ-banging, sax-honking representative of what Anderson dubs ‚Äúdirty gospel‚Äô‚Äô has been the invocation to Monday evening gatherings.

headline: ‚ÄòSkies of Lebanon‚Äô Review: A Beautiful Life, for a While
text: In the popular imagination of the West, Lebanon is most frequently invoked as a place of ruin and strife, not romance and enchantment. The debut feature from the filmmaker Chlo√© Mazlo, ‚ÄúSkies of Lebanon,‚Äù is, among other things, an intriguing swing of the pendulum of depiction.

headline: ‚ÄòThe Wheel‚Äô Review: Songs of Love and Hate
text: Not many movies faithfully recreate just how awful (and interminable) some arguments between couples can feel, but ‚ÄúThe Wheel‚Äù boldly makes the effort. In fact, the young couple at the film‚Äôs raw center ‚Äî married in their teens, locked into toxic dysfunction in their 20s ‚Äî could probably have been pulled out of their car wreck of a marriage long ago.

headline: ‚ÄòAnything‚Äôs Possible‚Äô Review: Teenagers‚Äô Romance Flowers
text: The high school senior Kelsa (Eva Reign) finds pleasure in discussing the animals she loves on her YouTube channel, seeking comfort in the fact that their names tend to be derived from what makes them unique. The detail sticks out in the actor, singer and author Billy Porter‚Äôs pleasant and diverting feature film directorial debut, ‚ÄúAnything‚Äôs Possible,‚Äù which is now streaming on Amazon Prime. Both intentionally and otherwise, the young adult romantic comedy scuffles with ‚Äî and tries to unpack the implication of ‚Äî uniqueness.

headline: Kennedy Center to Honor Gladys Knight, George Clooney, U2 and Others
text: Gladys Knight performed at the Kennedy Center Honors in 2021, paying tribute to one of the honorees, Garth Brooks, with a rendition of his song ‚ÄúWe Shall Be Free.‚Äù But when she returns to the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts this December, she will have a different role: She will be seated in the balcony, wearing a medal designating her as one of this year‚Äôs five honorees.

headline: Monarch Butterflies Are Endangered, Leading Wildlife Monitor Says
text: North America‚Äôs monarch butterfly, whose showy looks and extraordinary migration have made it one of the continent‚Äôs most beloved insects, has been classified as endangered by the International Union for Conservation of Nature, the world‚Äôs most comprehensive scientific authority on the status of species.

headline: Belgium Ratifies Prisoner-Exchange Treaty With Iran
text: BRUSSELS ‚Äî After two days of contentious debate, Belgium‚Äôs Parliament has approved a much-criticized treaty with Iran that would allow prisoner exchanges between the two countries.

headline: American Airlines has its best quarter of revenue ever, but profit is down from 2019.
text: American Airlines reported $13.4 billion in revenue in the three months that ended in June, the best quarter in the company‚Äôs history.

headline: Decision Day for the E.C.B.
text: The European Central Bank increased its benchmark interest rates today for the first time in a decade, as inflation surges across countries that use the euro. The bank‚Äôs benchmark interest rates, before the increase, had been a negative 0.5 percent. Europe‚Äôs central bank raised those rates today by half of a percentage point or back to zero. It first set the rate below zero, an unusual move for a central bank, in 2014, and has kept it in negative territory since.

headline: Russia Restarts Gas Shipments Through Pipeline, but Keeps Germany Guessing
text: Russia‚Äôs decision to restart the flow of natural gas through a vital pipeline on Thursday brought a moment of relief to Germany, which uses the fuel to power its most important industries and heat half its homes. But it is unlikely to be much more than that.

headline: Ford increases its battery supply to meet its electric-vehicle goals.
text: Ford Motor said on Thursday that it had reached an agreement to acquire battery packs from a Chinese supplier as it races to ramp up its global production of electric vehicles.

headline: My Boyfriend‚Äôs Ex Moved Across the Street From Us. Again. Should We Move?
text: Several years ago, while my boyfriend was out of the country, his then wife withdrew half their savings from the bank and moved to another state in secret. They divorced, and we met. Last year, his ex-wife decided to move back to our small city and bought a condo across the street from my boyfriend‚Äôs house. She changed her mind, though, and sold it quickly. Last month, she bought another house on the street a bit farther away. (Sigh!) She also initiates contact with my boyfriend. He and I had decided that I was going to move in with him this fall, but should we choose another neighborhood instead?

headline: Chess Replay: You Versus Karpov

headline: Smoke Rises: A Jazz Room Returns on the Upper West Side
text: On a recent Friday evening at Smoke, the storefront Upper West Side jazz club that‚Äôs been mostly shuttered since the spring of 2020, owners and staff scrambled about as you might expect in the run-up to a long-awaited reopening. As the crowd took its seats for a preview concert, technicians climbed ladders and handled minor crises. One of the venue‚Äôs co-owners, Paul Stache, consulted with an engineer on the in-room and livestream sound, while the other, Molly Sparrow Johnson, kept tabs on a wait staff that will be serving an expanded capacity of about 80 when it reopens on Thursday.

text: Nearly three years ago, Amazon announced that it would buy 100,000 custom-made delivery vehicles from Rivian, a fledgling maker of electric vehicles. On Thursday, after some delays, the companies said hundreds of the vans were finally on the road.

headline: In an Orchard With Blooming Poppies, an Anniversary in the Cotswolds
text: It was a perfectly crafted bag that brought together Melissa Morris, the American founder of the London-based leather house M√©tier, and Silka Rittson-Thomas, an art adviser and creative consultant. About four and a half years ago, Rittson-Thomas (who is also a contributing editor to T) purchased a M√©tier Private Eye bag ‚Äî a chic, roomy style constructed from lightweight leather, with ergonomic spaces for a laptop and other essentials. She instantly adored it and, soon after, went to meet Morris in person at the brand‚Äôs store in Mayfair. They‚Äôve been friends ever since. So, when Morris mentioned to Rittson-Thomas that the brand‚Äôs fifth anniversary was coming up, and that she wanted to throw some kind of summer celebration to mark it, Rittson-Thomas suggested she hold the event in the gardens of Walcot House, her home in the Cotswolds that she shares with her husband, the photographer Hugo Rittson-Thomas.

headline: ‚ÄòAlone Together‚Äô Review: Finding Love in a Pandemic Retreat
text: The minor key romance ‚ÄúAlone Together‚Äù is a modest affair, which credibly depicts the kinds of conversations about relationships that many people were confronted with during the early days of the pandemic. Its simplicity and lack of cinematic fancy strikes a tone of surprising relief.

headline: How to Get Vaccinated, Tested and Treated for Monkeypox

headline: China Is Playing Hardball with Troubled Debtors. That‚Äôs Dangerous for All of Us.

The pictures of the men tucked in a cabin around a wooden conference table evoked a clubby style of crisis management reminiscent of World War II.

headline: How can I sleep better in the heat?
text: High temperatures can wreak havoc on sleep. Under ideal conditions, your body temperature starts to fall by a couple of degrees about one to two hours before bedtime in preparation for sleep ‚Äî and it continues to decline while sleeping, said Leslie Swanson, a clinical psychologist and associate professor of psychiatry in the Sleep and Circadian Research Laboratory at the University of Michigan. This internal cooling effect helps us achieve the deep, restorative stage of sleep known as slow-wave sleep.

headline: Signs of the Tour
text: The cyclists competing in this year‚Äôs Tour de France will spend nearly a month on their bikes, earning only two days off during their sport‚Äôs most famous marathon. When the race ends on Sunday in Paris, the survivors and their teams will be able to look back on more than 2,000 miles spent navigating not only tens of thousands of twists and turns, but also punishing climbs and harrowing descents, tight curves and grinding switchbacks, narrow lanes and lonely breakaways.

headline: The Myth of the Good Trump Official
text: A central theme of the Jan. 6 hearings has been Republican redemption. A parade of Republican witnesses has testified to being pushed beyond the limits of their loyalty to Donald Trump. For some, the breaking point came when he tried to enlist them in a scheme to overturn state elections. Others revolted at the former president‚Äôs attempts to corrupt the Justice Department, or at his role in inciting an insurrection. A rioter, awakened to Trump‚Äôs lies, testified about being misled; in a poignant moment after the seventh hearing, he apologized to the Capitol Police.

headline: Angel Olsen, Yaya Bey and Others On Their Favorite Songs of Summer
text: A lot of us still remember the labor of love that was the mixtape, those countless hours spent pressing record, stop, rewind and play. But, while less time-consuming, curating a digital playlist, rather than relying on an algorithm-fueled compilation, can still be a thoughtful gesture, one that might make all the difference at a dinner party. Song choices can be a way to share (or forget) what‚Äôs going on in the world, act as a conversation starter and, above all, set the mood.

headline: The Gag Is: Keke Palmer Is a Movie Star

One road is called Louise Beavers Avenue, after the character actor best known for her role in 1934‚Äôs racial-passing melodrama ‚ÄúImitation of Life.‚Äù Her first onscreen performance was in the 1927 Universal production ‚ÄúUncle Tom‚Äôs Cabin,‚Äù in which she made an uncredited appearance as an enslaved person at a wedding. When Beavers died in 1962 in her early 60s (her birth year is in question), she had played more than 150 roles, most of them maids, servants, slaves and mammies. headline: The pandemic isn‚Äôt over, but most U.S. states formally say that it‚Äôs no longer a health emergency.

headline: Can I Force My Landlord to Install Window Boxes for Air-Conditioners?
text: Q: I live in a ground-floor, rent-stabilized apartment in Harlem, with a window in the living room and another in the bedroom. For years, the security bars on both windows lacked emergency egress and space for a window-unit air-conditioner. I requested emergency egress for the bedroom window and a gate to accommodate air-conditioning in the living room, but when the landlord replaced the building‚Äôs windows, he put an emergency gate in the living room window and standard bars in the bedroom window, so neither accommodates air-conditioning. I‚Äôm stuck with a portable air-conditioner, which is much more expensive than a window unit. Can I compel the landlord to install bars that allow for air-conditioning?

headline: This Week in Business: Amazon‚Äôs Latest Acquisition

Amazon announced on Thursday that it had reached a $3.9 billion deal to buy One Medical, a network of primary care clinics, as part of its quest to become a major player in the industry. The deal is the first acquisition under Andy Jassy, who became chief executive a year ago after Jeff Bezos stepped down. Mr. Jassy‚Äôs approach to the role has been much different from his predecessor‚Äôs, but on this decision, he hasn‚Äôt diverged too drastically from Mr. Bezos. One Medical is not the first health-care-related company Amazon has purchased. In 2018, it acquired PillPack, an online pharmacy.

headline: U.K., Eurovision Runner-up to Ukraine, Will Host Song Contest in 2023
text: Eurovision organizers confirmed on Monday that Britain would host the popular song contest in 2023 instead of war-torn Ukraine, which as this year‚Äôs winner would have traditionally hosted next year‚Äôs event but was ruled out because of safety concerns.

headline: Where China Is Changing Its Diplomatic Ways (at Least a Little)
text: Whirlwind visits to crisis-riven nations in Africa. A sleek training center for the continent‚Äôs up-and-coming politicians. The prospect of major debt forgiveness for a favorite African country.

headline: Cooling the Economy Without Crushing It
text: This week, the Federal Reserve will decide on its next move for interest rates. The decision, expected to be announced on Wednesday, will almost certainly be to raise its benchmark rate. The U.S. economy is facing its worst bout of inflation in four decades, and higher interest rates are likely to slow the economy and ease price increases. But how much remains a question.

headline: What to Know About California‚Äôs Head-Turning Gun Control Law
text: By one measure, Californians are about 25 percent less likely to die in mass shootings compared with residents of other states. Our state‚Äôs low rate of gun deaths is at least in part because of our strict firearm laws, experts say.

headline: What You Get for $1.5 Million in California
text: A Spanish-style home in Altadena, a Craftsman bungalow in San Francisco and a midcentury ranch house in Santa Barbara.

headline: $1.5 Million Homes in California
text: This house is 10 minutes from the center of Pasadena, but the views of nearby Hahamongna Watershed Park, a 1,300-acre protected green space, make it feel more remote.

headline: An Amazing World Record Runs Into a Question: Was It Too Amazing?
text: Tobi Amusan of Nigeria set a world record in the women‚Äôs 100-meter hurdles on Sunday at the world track and field championships in Eugene, Ore. That by itself was not surprising: World records often fall at big events, after all.

headline: A U.S. intelligence report finds that Russia‚Äôs use of ‚Äòfiltration centers‚Äô to detain and deport Ukrainians has intensified.
text: Russia is using more than a dozen so-called filtration centers in eastern Ukraine and western Russia to detain and deport thousands of Ukrainians, according to a newly declassified U.S. intelligence assessment.

headline: Smuggling Migrants at the Border Now a Billion-Dollar Business
text: CARRIZO SPRINGS, Texas ‚Äî From the street, the little brown house was unremarkable yet pleasant. A bright yellow toy school bus and red truck hung on the hog-wire fence, and the home‚Äôs facade featured a large Texas lone star. But in the backyard was a gutted mobile home that a prosecutor later described as a ‚Äúhouse of horrors.‚Äù

headline: The Hosts of ‚Äò5-4‚Äô Never Trusted the Supreme Court
text: For Rhiannon Hamam, it was a tossup between Bush v. Gore and Castle Rock v. Gonzales.

headline: What Is Beyonc√©‚Äôs Definitive Album?
text: Much is made of pop star ‚Äúeras‚Äù these days, but the term is deployed as a tool of marketing, not meaning. Rare is the artist who can sustain multiple visions and repeatedly regenerate. But different cultural and social moments have demanded different Beyonc√©s, and she has consistently delivered. At times she has been a singles powerhouse, dominating the radio and pop charts. At others, she has announced herself as a seismic cultural force, playing on a field much bigger than music. On Friday she will release ‚ÄúRenaissance,‚Äù her seventh solo studio album. Below, eight New York Times critics and reporters choose what they believe to be her definitive album so far, the one that reveals the most truth about the scope and shape of her career.

headline: Pope Francis is expected to deliver an apology long demanded by Canada‚Äôs Indigenous communities.
text: OTTAWA ‚Äî Pope Francis, on his first full day in Canada on Monday, is expected to ‚Äãapologize to ‚ÄãIndigenous communities for the Roman Catholic Church‚Äôs role in ‚Äãthe country‚Äôs notorious residential school system, ‚Äã‚Äãwhere thousands of Indigenous children died, and countless others were sexually and physically abused.

headline: As Prices Soar in Ukraine, War Adds Economic Havoc to the Human Toll
text: LVIV, Ukraine ‚Äî At his compact stall in Lviv‚Äôs main outdoor food market, Ihor Korpii arranged jars of blueberries that he and his wife had picked from a nearby forest into an attractive display. Fragrant dill and fresh peas harvested from their garden lay in neat piles on a table.

headline: Canada‚Äôs residential schools were a system of ‚Äòcultural genocide,‚Äô a commission found.
text: The investigation into Canada‚Äôs scandalous system of mandatory residential schools for Indigenous children was among the most comprehensive reviews in the country‚Äôs history, taking testimony from more than 6,000 witnesses and reviewing thousands of documents over six years.

headline: What to Cook Right Now
text: Good morning. One of the many pleasures of working from the office after so much time away is rediscovering the restaurants I used to haunt at lunch time. My old friends! It‚Äôs largely been true, save for my return to the place where I liked to get dry-fried cumin lamb of fragrant excellence and remarkable, fiery complexity. It‚Äôs a limp, pallid, salty mess now. For this I put on dress shoes and took the subway?

headline: Splitting T. Rex Into 3 Species Becomes a Dinosaur Royal Rumble
text: The world‚Äôs most iconic dinosaur is undergoing an identity crisis.

headline: California‚Äôs Largest Wildfire Slows After Exploding Near Yosemite
text: SAN FRANCISCO ‚Äî After growing explosively to become California‚Äôs largest wildfire so far in 2022, a blaze in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada moderated on Sunday, with firefighters able to defend communities a dozen miles from Yosemite National Park.

headline: Tesla will spend more to increase production at two new factories.
text: Tesla said on Monday that it was increasing spending by about $1 billion to ramp up its factories, develop new batteries and finance other projects.

headline: Michael R. Long, N.Y. Conservative Party Stalwart, Dies at 82
text: Michael R. Long, the devout ideologue who for three decades headed New York State‚Äôs Conservative Party ‚Äî which in 1994 provided the winning margin for the only Republican to be elected governor of the state in the last 50 years ‚Äî died on Sunday at his home in Breezy Point, Queens. He was 82.

headline: Biden Feeling Better as He Seeks to Show He Is Still Working Despite Covid
text: WASHINGTON ‚Äî President Biden said on Monday that he was feeling better and sleeping through the night again as he recovered from Covid-19, and he expressed hope that he could return to work in person by the end of the week.

headline: Russia Announces Deeper Cuts in Natural Gas Flows to Germany
text: BERLIN ‚Äî Russia‚Äôs state-owned gas monopoly, Gazprom, said on Monday that it would further reduce the amount of natural gas it sends to Germany through the Nord Stream 1 pipeline, less than a week after it resumed limited flows after an annual maintenance shutdown.

headline: 2 Killed and 2 Injured in Shootings in British Columbia
text: Two people were killed and two others were injured, one of them critically, in shootings early Monday in four locations in Langley, British Columbia, the authorities said.

headline: Masala Cheese Toast, Courtesy of La Bo√Æte
text: La Bo√Æte, the spice boutique in Hell‚Äôs Kitchen, delivers a free online newsletter with news about their products and creative recipes. A recent one for masala cheese toast by Kanchan Koya, a spice expert with a doctorate in molecular biology, evokes an after school snack she once enjoyed. It essentially is a grilled cheese sandwich: She mixes two cups of shredded Cheddar (vegan cheese is an option) with a minced shallot, a quarter cup of chopped cilantro, a bit of minced serrano chile, a half teaspoon of fine sea salt and a tablespoon of La Bo√Æte‚Äôs masala blend. The mixture is piled on whole grain bread, covered with another slice and fried, pressed down in butter. The recipe serves four, but that depends on the dimensions of your bread. Like all of La Bo√Æte‚Äôs recipes it calls for the company‚Äôs own spice mix, in this case Everyday Masala, but another masala would do.

headline: South African Wine Without the Buzz
text: The choices when it comes to nonalcoholic wines, especially still wines, have been growing in recent years. Lautus De-Alcoholised Wine from South Africa is already five years old, but it‚Äôs a new import for the United States and a welcome addition. Like most of the more palatable products in the category it starts with real, well-made wine using grapes from several regions: sauvignon blanc for the white and for the red, a blend of shiraz, cabernet sauvignon and pinotage aged in oak. Then the alcohol is removed. The sauvignon blanc has refreshing minerality and good acidity with fairly tart fruit; the red delivers decent body, a touch of tannin and red fruit richness without being sweet. The company also makes a lovely moscato ros√©, and white and ros√© sparklers.

headline: The Jackie Robinson Museum Is About a Lot More Than Baseball
text: Jackie Robinson‚Äôs family home in Stamford, Conn., had a den featuring trophies, artifacts and a big scrapbook commemorating his many achievements. David Robinson, his son, fondly recalled in an interview how one wall held photos and plaques depicting his father‚Äôs success in sports. Another wall ‚Äî with a collection twice as big ‚Äî highlighted his father‚Äôs social activism, something of far greater significance to Jackie Robinson and his family.

headline: Meal Kits From James Beard Chefs-in-Training
text: A new program at the James Beard Foundation, Beard House Fellows, uses the Beard House in the West Village for residencies for young chefs. There the chefs, mostly those who have completed training with the Careers Through Culinary Arts Program (C-CAP), work and learn. As part of the program they each create a meal kit with dinner for two, in collaboration with Great Performances for delivery nationwide. The cost of the kit helps support the residency, which is also funded by Capital One. From Wednesday through Aug. 9, the African fusion kit by Adijatu Jalloh, who graduated from New York City College of Technology and is developing several business ventures, can be ordered for delivery on Aug. 24. Her kit contains ginger-scallion prawns, berbere-spiced cauliflower, wheatberry salad, peanut sauce, crispy shallots and, for dessert, cheesecake with strawberry compote; like the other kits, some simple preparations are required for the food.

headline: Vying to Lead Britain, Candidates for Prime Minister Emulate Another: Thatcher
text: LONDON ‚Äî When Rishi Sunak kicked off his campaign for leader of Britain‚Äôs Conservative Party and prime minister on Saturday, his choice of venue ‚Äî a tire shop in the market town of Grantham ‚Äî felt almost inevitable. Grantham is the birthplace of Margaret Thatcher, an icon of the right who looms large in every Conservative leader contest, but never more so than in these economically straitened times.

headline: Brooklyn Clergyman Is Robbed While Delivering Sunday Sermon
text: A showy pastor who was in the middle of delivering his sermon and his wife were robbed at gunpoint of more than $1 million worth of jewelry at a Brooklyn church on Sunday, the police said. The heist was caught on a livestream video of the service.

headline: Scoops Go Flying at Catch‚Äòn Ice Cream
text: After rising through the ranks at Cold Stone Creamery franchises in Michigan and Missouri, Dylan Lemay, 25, considered a franchise of his own. But on the way he discovered social media, and began posting ice cream videos to YouTube and TikTok. Now, with millions of followers across platforms in his pocket and a few backers, he is opening an interactive ice cream shop on Friday in New York. There, balls of ice cream are mixed with toppings and tossed in the air by servers, thus the name: Catch‚Äòn Ice Cream From Dylan Lemay. Prices start at about $7. Its NoHo location is in the landmark Bayard-Condict building, the only example of the architect Louis Sullivan‚Äôs work in New York City; Mr. Lemay said he selected New York for his first store and because of the tourist industry.

headline: Prosecutor Is Barred From Pursuing Criminal Case Against Trump Ally
text: ATLANTA ‚Äî In an embarrassing blow to the prosecutor investigating election interference by former President Donald J. Trump, an Atlanta judge has disqualified District Attorney Fani T. Willis of Fulton County from developing a criminal case against one Trump ally, citing a conflict of interest.

headline: Justice Department sues poultry processors over unlawful labor practices.
text: WASHINGTON ‚Äî The Justice Department filed a lawsuit on Monday against three large poultry processors along with a proposed deal meant to end what it described as a decades-long scheme to deceive workers and suppress wages.

headline: Lizzo Earns Her Second No. 1 Song: ‚ÄòAbout Damn Time‚Äô
text: If you have tuned in your local Top 40 radio station recently, or fired up TikTok, there‚Äôs a good chance you have come across Lizzo‚Äôs discofied hit ‚ÄúAbout Damn Time‚Äù (or at least, on your phone, found it in meme form).

text: Follow live updates of the Euro 2022 final.

headline: In Robert Lowell‚Äôs ‚ÄòMemoirs,‚Äô Mental Illness, Creative Friends and a Takedown of Dad
text: In 1954, when he was in his late 30s, the poet Robert Lowell was committed to the Payne Whitney Psychiatric Clinic in New York City after a manic episode. As part of his therapy, he began to write personal prose about his family and childhood, to tap into the torrents that streamed below the glacier of his intellect. This writing was a trial run, of sorts, for the autobiographical poems in his breakthrough book, ‚ÄúLife Studies‚Äù (1959).

headline: Ex-congressman, banker and F.B.I. trainee are charged with insider trading.
text: A former Indiana congressman, an F.B.I. trainee, a Wall Street banker and several others made for an unlikely grouping when the federal authorities on Monday announced the filing of criminal and civil insider trading charges against nine people in a set of unrelated cases.

headline: A Rebound for a Summer Pairing of ‚ÄòHamlet‚Äô and ‚ÄòOresteia‚Äô at the Armory
text: Perhaps more than any other production of this post-shutdown season, the Park Avenue Armory‚Äôs summer stagings of ‚ÄúHamlet‚Äù and ‚ÄúOresteia‚Äù ‚Äî with their last-minute replacements and cast illnesses ‚Äî have faced the most hurdles on their way to opening night.

headline: Eyeing a City Captured by Russia, Ukraine Prepares an Ambitious Counterattack
text: KHERSON REGION BORDER, Ukraine ‚Äî The road to Russian-occupied Kherson in southern Ukraine passes through a no man‚Äôs land of charred wheat fields and cratered villages. The tails of rockets stick out of asphalt and the boom of incoming and outgoing artillery ricochets off tidy, abandoned homes.

headline: Woman Opens Fire at Dallas Love Field and Is Shot and Arrested
text: A 37-year-old woman was taken into custody on Monday after she fired several rounds inside Dallas Love Field Airport in Texas and was shot and injured by a police officer, the authorities said.

text: GARRISON, N.Y. ‚Äî A romance and a love story are two different things. In art, we‚Äôre not great at differentiating.

headline: Paul Sorvino, Master of the Mild-Mannered Mobster, Dies at 83
text: Paul Sorvino, the tough-guy actor ‚Äî and operatic tenor and figurative sculptor ‚Äî known for his roles as calm and often courteously quiet but dangerous men in films like ‚ÄúGoodfellas‚Äù and television shows like ‚ÄúLaw & Order,‚Äù died on Monday. He was 83.

headline: The Politics of Litigation May Be Changing
text: Is suing a Democratic thing or a Republican thing? It used to be a Democratic thing, then it became a Republican thing, and now it‚Äôs a Democratic thing again. Or maybe it‚Äôs the other way around. Anyway, the politics of litigation have become confusing in an interesting way.

headline: The Movement to End Homework Is Wrong
text: Do students really need to do their homework?

headline: The U.S. Is Behind in the Competition for the ‚ÄòOil‚Äô of the 21st Century
text: Semiconductors, the tiny computer chips that run everything from smartphones to satellites to missile defense systems, are often called the ‚Äúoil‚Äù of the 21st century. Maintaining U.S. economic and military might depend on a reliable supply. Semiconductor shortages during the pandemic brought some car assembly lines to a halt and left showrooms of home appliances barren, providing a glimpse of what would happen to the American economy if those chips ever ran out.

headline: Goodman Theater Names Susan V. Booth as Artistic Director
text: Susan V. Booth, the artistic director of the Alliance Theater in Atlanta, has been named the next artistic director of the Goodman Theater in Chicago, a dominant force in that city‚Äôs vibrant theater scene and one of the most influential regional nonprofits in the country.

headline: Fed Prepares Another Rate Increase as Wall Street Wonders What‚Äôs Next
text: Federal Reserve officials are set to make a second abnormally large interest rate increase this week as they race to cool down an overheating economy. The question for many economists and investors is just how far the central bank will go in its quest to tame inflation.

headline: Rikers Island Guards Charged With Misconduct in Teen‚Äôs Suicide Attempt
text: For nearly eight minutes, more than a half dozen New York City Department of Correction officers stood by as an 18-year-old detainee named Nicholas Feliciano tried to hang himself in a Rikers Island jail cell, not intervening even when he flailed his arms and then went still.

text: The U.S. Energy Department said Monday that it would lend $2.5 billion to a battery maker owned by General Motors and LG Energy Solution to build battery factories, advancing the Biden administration‚Äôs plan to promote electric vehicles and reduce dependence on China for critical components.

headline: A Yakitori Master Moves Downtown
text: Atsushi Kono, the longtime chef at Torishin, has moved his omakase chicken-skewer tastings to Kono, a new restaurant in Manhattan‚Äôs Chinatown.

text: One night last June, I found myself eating chicken skewers on the second-story terrace of a downtown hotel, wondering about the fire code.

headline: David Trimble, Peace Prize Winner in Ulster Strife, Dies at 77
text: LONDON ‚Äî David Trimble, a onetime Protestant firebrand who surprised many by reaching across the bloodstained sectarian divide in his native Northern Ireland and went on to secure high office, political honors and a Nobel Peace Prize, died on Monday. He was 77.

headline: Top Pence Aides Testify to Grand Jury in Jan. 6 Investigation
text: Two top aides to former Vice President Mike Pence testified last week to a federal grand jury in Washington investigating the events surrounding the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, the highest-ranking officials of the Trump administration so far known to have cooperated with the Justice Department‚Äôs widening inquiry into the events leading up to the assault.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Russia Seeks African Support
text: Russia‚Äôs top diplomat, Sergey Lavrov, set off on a tour of four African countries ‚Äî Egypt, Ethiopia, Uganda and the Republic of Congo ‚Äî seeking to place blame on the West for war-related grain shortages that have sparked fears of famine.

headline: Kushner Says He Was Treated for Thyroid Cancer While in White House
text: Jared Kushner, former President Donald J. Trump‚Äôs son-in-law and senior adviser, was diagnosed with thyroid cancer while he was serving in the West Wing, he wrote in an upcoming memoir set to be published next month.

text: Pope Francis offered a sweeping apology for the Catholic Church‚Äôs role in running boarding schools in Canada where Indigenous children were sexually and physically abused and where many died.

headline: How Has the Pandemic Changed Your Economic Situation?
text: The pandemic has drastically changed the global economy, affecting things such as the price and availability of goods and how people view their relationship to employers.

headline: How to Live With Covid When You Are Tired of Living With Covid
text: The United States is in the midst of another coronavirus surge, this time thanks to the Omicron subvariant BA.5. Scientists warn that the new subvariant appears to be the virus‚Äôs most transmissible version to date, and it is reinfecting people who have already dealt with previous variants once or twice, sometimes as recently as a few weeks ago.

headline: David Warner, Actor Who Played Villains and More, Dies at 80
text: David Warner, who started his career on the British stage, including playing Hamlet with the Royal Shakespeare Company when he was just 24, then gravitated toward film and television, accumulating more than 200 credits, including ‚ÄúThe Omen,‚Äù ‚ÄúTime After Time,‚Äù ‚ÄúTRON,‚Äù ‚ÄúTitanic‚Äù and ‚ÄúWallander,‚Äù died on Sunday in Northwest London. He was 80.

headline: Russia Cuts Gas Flow to Europe, Intensifying Fears It Is Weaponizing Fuel
text: BERLIN ‚Äî On the eve of a European Union emergency meeting on cutting natural gas consumption, Russia‚Äôs state-owned gas monopoly said Monday that it would slash gas deliveries to Germany, as President Vladimir V. Putin once again showed his unpredictability and his power to inflict pain on the bloc for backing Ukraine.

headline: As Monkeypox Spread in New York, 300,000 Vaccine Doses Sat in Denmark
text: On the Thursday before Pride Weekend last month, hundreds of men dropped what they were doing and raced to a city-run health clinic in Manhattan. Finally, more than a month after monkeypox appeared in New York City, a vaccine was being made available to sexually active gay and bisexual men, among whom the virus was rapidly spreading.

headline: The Monkeypox Emergency
text: The World Health Organization took the extraordinary step over the weekend of declaring monkeypox a ‚Äúpublic health emergency of international concern,‚Äù a designation currently used to describe only two other diseases, Covid-19 and polio.

headline: Indigenous Communities React to Pope Francis‚Äôs Apology
text: Indigenous leaders praised Pope Francis after he apologized for the Catholic Church‚Äôs role in abuse and forced assimilation of Indigenous people on their native land in Canada.

headline: Walmart lowers profit forecast as inflation hits customers‚Äô wallets.
text: Walmart lowered its profit outlook on Monday, saying inflation is pressuring its customers to make fewer purchases of general merchandise and to focus on necessities like groceries.

headline: Paul Sorvino: A Voluble Man Who Excelled as a Brick of a Mobster
text: When Paul Sorvino was offered the role of Paulie Cicero, the Queens-based mob underboss in Martin Scorsese‚Äôs ‚ÄúGoodfellas‚Äù (1990), he very much did not want to accept it. In the first place, he was a proud Italian American. A connoisseur of Italian culture, particularly food and music, he was not inclined to play a Mafioso. In addition, Sorvino, who died Monday at 83, was a voluble guy, and he liked playing voluble guys. Paulie was largely a brick. Much is made in the early scenes of the movie about how most of the criminal‚Äôs directives were executed with a mere nod.

headline: Bryan Young, an American volunteer who died fighting in Ukraine, felt called to help.
text: Bryan Young feared for his adopted homeland, his partner said. That‚Äôs why Mr. Young, a U.S. Army veteran, left the Republic of Georgia, where he settled and got married after an international cycling trip, and volunteered to fight the Russians.

headline: Diana Kennedy‚Äôs Complicated Relationship With Mexican Cuisine
text: Diana Kennedy sank into a dimpled leather chair at the Hotel Emma in San Antonio, leaned over her glass of Scotch and told me that the real enemy of every writer was mediocrity.

headline: Biden Says He‚Äôs on His Way to a ‚ÄòFull, Total Recovery‚Äô from Covid
text: President Biden held virtual meetings as he recovered from Covid-19, telling reporters that he was ‚Äúfeeling better every day‚Äù and hoped to return to work in person by the end of the week.

headline: Joni Mitchell Performs Surprise Show at Newport Folk Festival
text: Joni Mitchell, the revered Canadian singer-songwriter and one of the defining musicians of the 1960s and ‚Äô70s, surprised an audience in Rhode Island on Sunday when she appeared at the Newport Folk Festival to perform her first full set in about two decades, guitar in hand.

headline: ‚ÄòThe Better Bagel‚Äô Goes All In on Nutrition
text: The rollout of the Better Bagel has been gradual, from an online debut about a year ago to a full complement of flavors now. Next month, its products will be available nationwide at Whole Foods. The ‚Äúbetter‚Äù part of the name has merit; we‚Äôll get to that. But except that it‚Äôs round with sort of a hole in the middle, bagel is not what I‚Äôd call this oversize, puffy and slightly sour breadstuff. It‚Äôs meant to replace your regular bagel with better nutrition; it contains more protein (26 grams) and fiber (35 grams) than the average bagel (9 to 12 grams protein; 2 grams fiber). The Los Angeles company founded by Aimee Yang, a Wharton School graduate, does not tout the fiber, though it should, focusing instead on the low net carbs (5 grams). Enjoyment requires toasting and liberal schmearing to amp up the flavor.

headline: Rumrunning, Bootlegging and More Criminal History of ‚ÄòLiquor Island‚Äô
text: For Amy Kasuga Folk, the Southold Town Historian in Long Island, it pays to know the difference between the Prohibition terms rumrunning and bootlegging. As she explains in her book ‚ÄúRumrunning in Suffolk County,‚Äù rumrunning is about boats bringing verboten liquor to shore from ships moored at sea, where the bootleggers pick it up and drive it to its destination. This teamwork, she writes, led to the rise of organized crime in the United States. Long Island, at one time known as Liquor Island with its extensive shoreline, became a focal point for figures like Dutch Schultz and Charles ‚ÄúLucky‚Äù Luciano. The book covers the period of 1920 to 1933, year by year. A singular feature is a list of the hundreds of codes used by the smugglers from a notebook that a fisherman in Peconic Bay retrieved from the water.

headline: The Dystopian Myths of Red America
text: Desensitization is an amazing thing. At this point most political observers simply accept it as a fact of life that an overwhelming majority of Republicans accept the Big Lie that the 2020 election was stolen ‚Äî a claim with nothing to support it, not even plausible anecdotes.

headline: A Trump-Backed Veteran Ran Hard to the Right, Only to Be Outflanked
text: Joe Kent, a square-jawed Trump devotee running for a House seat in Washington State, is in a bit of a pickle.

headline: U.S. Officials Grow More Concerned About Potential Action by China on Taiwan
text: WASHINGTON ‚Äî The Biden administration has grown increasingly anxious this summer about China‚Äôs statements and actions regarding Taiwan, with some officials fearing that Chinese leaders might try to move against the self-governing island over the next year and a half ‚Äî perhaps by trying to cut off access to all or part of the Taiwan Strait, through which U.S. naval ships regularly pass.

headline: M.L.B. Players Choose Status Quo Over International Draft
text: Major League Baseball and its players‚Äô union couldn‚Äôt agree on the specifics of an international amateur draft ahead of Monday‚Äôs deadline, and thus the status quo will continue in the sport.

headline: Sandy Hook Parents to Testify Against Alex Jones, and a Culture of Lies
text: AUSTIN, Texas ‚Äî The far-right conspiracy broadcaster Alex Jones spread lies for years about the Sandy Hook school shooting, saying it was staged by the government and that the families of the victims were complicit in the hoax. Juries will now decide in three separate trials how much Mr. Jones must pay for the suffering he caused.

headline: Biden Rule Would Strengthen Health Protections for Gay and Transgender People
text: WASHINGTON ‚Äî The Biden administration said Monday that it intends to enshrine anti-discrimination protections for gay and transgender people in the Affordable Care Act ‚Äî a proposal that would officially reverse a policy adopted by the Department of Health and Human Services under former President Donald J. Trump.

headline: Corrections: July 26, 2022
text: An article on Saturday about a deal between Russian and Ukraine that would allow grain shipments misstated the price of wheat futures on Friday, July 22. Prices fell by more than 5 percent to around $7.60 per bushel, not $760 per bushel.

headline: Biden Lashes Trump Over Jan. 6, Saying He ‚ÄòLacked the Courage to Act‚Äô
text: WASHINGTON ‚Äî President Biden on Monday denounced former President Donald J. Trump‚Äôs refusal to decisively intervene to stop the Jan. 6, 2021, attack on the Capitol, declaring that his predecessor ‚Äúlacked the courage to act‚Äù and betrayed the police officers he claimed to support.

headline: Biden tries to persuade Americans that the U.S. is not in a recession.
text: President Biden and his aides on Monday escalated a campaign to try to convince American voters that the nation has not fallen into recession, before the release this week of new data that could show the economy continues to shrink.

headline: Pope Apologizes in Canada for Schools That Abused Indigenous Children
text: MASKWACIS, Alberta ‚Äî Pope Francis offered a sweeping apology directly to Indigenous people on their land in Canada on Monday, fulfilling a critical demand of many of the survivors of church-run residential schools that became gruesome centers of abuse, forced assimilation, cultural devastation and death for over a century.

headline: Grass Fire Destroys or Damages 20 Homes Outside Dallas
text: A fast-moving grass fire swept through a suburban neighborhood near Dallas on Monday, destroying or damaging at least 20 homes, displacing about 20 people and forcing evacuations as firefighters struggled to fight back flames in 103-degree heat, the authorities said.

headline: Some Time
text: TUESDAY PUZZLE ‚Äî Congratulations to the constructor of today‚Äôs grid, Lillian Simpson, who is making her debut in the New York Times Crossword. Without spoiling it, the theme in this puzzle is one of my favorites in a while. There‚Äôs also a lot of fun fill in here, and I particularly enjoyed the entries at 20- and 50-Across as well as 9-, 22- and 26-Down. I hope you have as much fun solving this puzzle as I did.

headline: ‚ÄòBetter Call Saul‚Äô Season 6, Episode 10 Recap: Sweet Revenge

Karen worked as a waitress at the local inn and spent her leisure time plotting an escape to some unspecified big city. headline: Sex Confessions and Protest From a Disillusioned Communist

headline: What in the World Happened to Elise Stefanik?

headline: How We Communicate Will Decide Whether Democracy Lives or Dies
text: ‚ÄúAt the very heart of democracy is a contradiction that cannot be resolved, one that has affected free societies from ancient Greece to contemporary America,‚Äù write Zac Gershberg and Sean Illing in their new book, ‚ÄúThe Paradox of Democracy.‚Äù In order to live up to its name, democracy must be open to free communication and expression; yet that very feature opens democracies up to the forces of chaos, fragmentation and demagoguery that undermine them. Historically, this paradox becomes particularly profound during transitions between different communication technologies. ‚ÄúWe see this time and again,‚Äù Gershberg and Illing write, ‚Äúmedia continually evolve faster than politics, resulting in recurring patterns of democratic instability.‚Äù

headline: Republicans Confront Unexpected Online Money Slowdown

headline: After Two Decades in Solitary, This Is His First Day Out
text: I was introduced to Jack Powers during his final month of nearly 33 years spent in prison. A former bank robber, Mr. Powers spent over two decades in solitary confinement, most of them in the notorious maximum-security prison known as the ADX.

headline: How Much Should I Spend to Keep My Elderly Dog Alive?

headline: Why Was Joshua Held for More Than Two Years for Someone Else‚Äôs Crimes?
text: On May 11, 2017, the River of Life Mission in Honolulu‚Äôs Chinatown was serving food when a 46-year-old man named Joshua Spriestersbach lined up. For more than a century, the neighborhood has been a gathering place for the city‚Äôs homeless, its sidewalks often jammed with people sleeping, sometimes setting up encampments for days or longer. A variety of organizations have sprung up to attack root causes ‚Äî meth addiction, mental illness, lack of housing ‚Äî but the most reliable meal service came from the River of Life, a charity with a storefront, a few blocks from the harbor, that always draws a line around the block. Spriestersbach was a regular. He would go from the park to the soup kitchen and back again, never without a newsboy cap, never interacting with anyone if he could help it. On that day in May, he was sitting on the sidewalk when a police officer approached him and placed him under arrest. There‚Äôd been no altercation, no incident, no fight. Later, he would say he thought it was because he fell asleep in line.

headline: Travel ‚ÄòWorks to Shake Things Up,‚Äô Says the Novelist Emily Henry
text: Over the last three years, the novelist Emily Henry has established a solid beachhead on summertime best seller lists with a series of travel-related rom-coms, starting with ‚ÄúBeach Read‚Äù in 2020, and followed by last summer‚Äôs ‚ÄúPeople We Meet on Vacation‚Äù and this year‚Äôs ‚ÄúBook Lovers.‚Äù All three novels currently share space on The Times‚Äôs combined Print and E-book fiction list.

headline: New York Renters Are Now Paying the Price for the ‚ÄòCovid Discount‚Äô

text: On a steamy evening at Flushing Meadows Corona Park in Queens, Jaime Cabal had a line of customers at his Mister Softee ice cream truck. text: Katie Hafner‚Äôs taut and utterly delightful debut is a novel of multitudes. We are emerging from a period of forced introversion, and ‚ÄúThe Boys‚Äù provides the perfect antidote. For anyone who now feels anxious about leaving the house or traveling abroad or re-entering the world, you will find, as I did, a kindred spirit in Ethan Fawcett.

text: ‚ÄúCODA,‚Äù a film about the hearing child of deaf parents, won this year‚Äôs Academy Award for best picture, and one of its stars, Troy Kotsur, became the first deaf man to win an acting Oscar when he took home the award for best supporting actor. Lauren Ridloff became the Marvel Cinematic Universe‚Äôs first deaf superhero in ‚ÄúEternals.‚Äù The Hulu mystery-comedy series ‚ÄúOnly Murders in the Building‚Äù won acclaim for an almost entirely silent episode that highlighted the perspective of a deaf character (played by James Caverly).

headline: In San Antonio, the Poor Live on Their Own Islands of Heat

She resisted the temptation to turn on the power-guzzling air-conditioner.

text: A debate has long raged at universities and think tanks, through public diplomacy and state media outlets: Does democracy or an authoritarian system perform better in times of crisis?

Trump to reverse his election defeat in the weeks before the Jan. 6 attack, including acknowledgments that a key element of their plan was of dubious legality and lived up to its billing as ‚Äúfake.‚Äù

headline: Kraken, a U.S. Crypto Exchange, Is Suspected of Violating Sanctions
text: Kraken, one of the world‚Äôs largest cryptocurrency exchanges, is under federal investigation, suspected of violating U.S. sanctions by allowing users in Iran and elsewhere to buy and sell digital tokens, according to five people affiliated with the company or with knowledge of the inquiry.

headline: Le Rock, From the Frenchette Team, Opens in Rockefeller Center
text: Every few decades, the reset button is pressed on the restaurants in Rockefeller Center. A big year was 1984, with the openings of the Sea Grill and American Festival Cafe by Restaurant Associates. This year promises to be notable as well, with Tishman Speyer, the company that owns and operates Rockefeller Center, continuing to shape the dining scene. A major addition is Le Rock, Lee Hanson and Riad Nasr‚Äôs grand interpretation of a French brasserie. (Mr. Hanson and Mr. Nasr, veterans of Balthazar, own Frenchette in TriBeCa and have Le Veau d‚ÄôOr on the Upper East Side in the wings.) With Workstead, a Brooklyn interior design studio, they have incorporated enough Art Deco features to anchor the soaring room to its historic setting. A verdigris screen separates the bar, terrazzo floors are new but don‚Äôt look it and bare burled wood tables sit at forest-green leather banquettes. Mr. Hanson and Mr. Nasr have to fill 130 seats indoors with another 70 on the terrace, and, to do so, especially with a potential tourist audience, they have given an international spin to the menu. ‚ÄúWe‚Äôve gone simpler than Frenchette, which has its own personality,‚Äù Mr. Hanson said. Mr. Nasr cited some classic brasserie items, like leeks vinaigrette, escargots, p√¢t√© maison and steak au poivre (made with bison). They share a menu, divided into Cette Semaine (weekly specials) and Tout le Temps (every day), which also lists falafel, a brochette of calamari and shishito peppers, and barbajuans, a kind of fried ravioli. Some items play it coy, using untranslated French names, like tablier de sapeur (breaded tripe) and cervelle de canut (fresh herbed cheese). In charge of the kitchen as executive chef is Walker Stern, a former owner of Battersby and Dover in Brooklyn. Mariah Neston is collaborating with Michelle Palazzo, the head pastry chef, on site to create a giant baba au rhum carved tableside. Dinner gets things rolling, with breakfast, which they do not serve at Frenchette, and lunch to follow.

headline: U.K. hits a British blogger with sanctions for pro-Russian propaganda.
text: A British citizen had his assets frozen by Britain‚Äôs Foreign Office on Tuesday as the government announced a raft of new sanctions on individuals, companies, and others supporting the government of President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia.

headline: Recession: What Does It Mean?
text: There‚Äôs a pretty good chance the Bureau of Economic Analysis, which produces the numbers on gross domestic product and other macroeconomic data, will declare on Thursday, preliminarily, that real G.D.P. shrank in the second quarter of 2022. Since it has already announced that real G.D.P. shrank in the first quarter, there will be a lot of breathless commentary to the effect that we‚Äôre officially in a recession.

headline: The Big, Bold Life of the Woman Who Brought Us the ‚ÄòIt Girl‚Äô
text: More than half a century before Stephen King‚Äôs ‚ÄúIt‚Äù seized little children, Elinor Glyn‚Äôs ‚ÄúIt‚Äù seized adult imaginations.

headline: A Maestro and His Musicians Face Scrutiny Over Ties to Russia
text: SALZBURG, Austria ‚Äî Teodor Currentzis is revered as one of classical music‚Äôs most original voices, a rebellious conductor who can breathe fresh life into well-known works. headline: Transportation Dept. Opens Program to Make Public Transit Accessible
text: WASHINGTON ‚Äî The Department of Transportation opened a program on Tuesday that allows cities to apply for federal funding to make public transit stations more accessible to disabled people, moving on the anniversary of the Americans With Disabilities Act to provide access to $1.75 billion to update stations that do not comply with the law.

headline: As the Trade Deadline Nears, the Brewers Could Be in Trouble

headline: Tiny Love Stories: Summer Loving

A mark up high (‚ÄúÀô‚Äù) meant a full stop, like our period; in the middle (‚Äú¬∑‚Äù) meant a brief pause, a firm but gentle separation, like our comma; and one on the bottom (‚Äú.‚Äù) meant something in between, a breather of sorts, like our semicolon.

headline: Alabama Takes From the Poor and Gives to the Rich

text: A small army of combine harvesters rolled across an endless farm field on a recent afternoon in western Ukraine, kicking dust clouds into the blue sky as the machines gathered in a sea of golden wheat. Mountains of soy and corn will be reaped in coming weeks. It will all add to a 20-million-ton backlog of grain that has been trapped in Ukraine during Russia‚Äôs grinding war.

headline: What‚Äôs the Deal With Water Bottles?
text: A standup comedian‚Äôs drink is much more than a prop or a thirst quencher. It‚Äôs a stealth statement.

headline: Planning Her Golden Years in the Golden State: What Could She Afford?
text: As she looked ahead to a new chapter in Southern California, a ‚Äòserial homebuyer‚Äô faced a decision: pay more to stay near the coast and take on renters or head inland to a new crop of 55-plus communities.

headline: Judge John Hodgman on Satin Sheets
text: Renee writes: My husband and I have a debate about how to put our satin sheets on the bed. He claims the sheets should go on ‚Äúthe way they‚Äôre meant to,‚Äù meaning the silky side faces up. I say they should be flipped so that the softer side is on top of us. Who‚Äôs right?

headline: Poem: Summer Terror
text: The title of this poem subverts expectations right away. After all, we associate summer with pleasure: vacations, the beach, sunshine. Each line operates in the declarative. Many lines end with a period, while others end with a semicolon, a relative of the period. Even the lines that end with commas can feel declarative: ‚ÄúI can smell something on them,‚Äù for example. But what‚Äôs being declared is less obvious. There‚Äôs a peculiarity around every corner: ‚Äúlike all flowers they look like ideas‚Äù or ‚ÄúThough after nine nights must come ten.‚Äù Sandra Lim‚Äôs poems often seem influenced by Louise Gl√ºck‚Äôs signature stark and stripped-down tone. What‚Äôs left is an intellectual, pale, yet strange chill. Selected by Victoria Chang

headline: In Savannah, Spanish Moss, Tea Roses and Murder
text: Around these parts, the publication of a new George Dawes Green novel is an event. Partly because he publishes so rarely ‚Äî four novels in 28 years ‚Äî and partly because each book inhabits a distinct world and space, be it a cave in Manhattan‚Äôs Inwood Park (his brilliant 1994 debut, ‚ÄúThe Caveman‚Äôs Valentine‚Äù), a courtroom (‚ÄúThe Juror,‚Äù released the following year) or the mad desperation surrounding lottery winners (2009‚Äôs ‚ÄúRavens‚Äù).

headline: Nancy Pelosi‚Äôs Trip to Taiwan Is Too Dangerous
text: The United States and China are on a collision course in the Taiwan Strait.

headline: This Novelist Spun an Existential Question Into a Best Seller
text: What would you do if you stepped outside one morning and found a box on your front steps ‚Äî or in the hallway of your apartment building or next to your tent in the desert ‚Äî containing a length of string that would indicate how long you had left to live? Would you open it, or would you toss that surprise interloper straight into the recycling bin?

headline: This 150-Year-Old Mining Law Hurts Taxpayers and the Environment
text: In 1872, seven years after the end of the Civil War, Ulysses S. Grant was president, John Wesley Powell was completing his second expedition down the Colorado River, and Congress was dispatching another party to map areas of the Southwest. Most Western territories were years away ‚Äî or, in New Mexico‚Äôs case, decades away ‚Äî from statehood.

headline: For First Time Since 1946, New Yorkers Have Just 2 Choices for Governor
text: ALBANY, N.Y. ‚Äî New York voters who dislike the Democrat or Republican candidates for governor have traditionally been able to cast their ballots for a long-shot candidate from any number of so-called third parties.

headline: Mohsin Hamid Is Working Through Literature, From the Top
text: ‚ÄúThe Story of a Brief Marriage,‚Äù by Anuk Arudpragasam, ‚ÄúThe Bad Guys in They‚Äôre Bee-hind You!‚Äù (Bad Guys No. 14), by Aaron Blabey, ‚ÄúPrinciples for Dealing With the Changing World Order,‚Äù by Ray Dalio, and ‚ÄúThe Last Children of Tokyo,‚Äù by Yoko Tawada. There are many more books on my wife‚Äôs night stand. Although it is precisely the same size as mine, mysteriously it also seems to be larger. She reads much more quickly than I do. We often share books, and I consider some of those on her side as also being, in a sense, on mine, but it is uncertain if she entirely feels the same, so I have not ventured to list them here.

headline: Swing Voters, Struggling With Their Options, Scramble Traditional Political Coalitions
text: ROCKY RIVER, Ohio ‚Äî A few weeks before Ohio‚Äôs Senate primaries, Kristen Bentz stood outside a grocery store in suburban Cleveland, feeling torn about the race.
