text: Two of New York City‚Äôs biggest sales so far this year closed in July, including a pair of co-ops sold together for $101 million by the estate of Paul G. Allen, the co-founder of Microsoft who died nearly four years ago.

headline: These Republican Governors Are Delivering Results, and Many Voters Like Them for It
text: Republican flamethrowers and culture warriors like Donald Trump and Representatives Matt Gaetz and Marjorie Taylor Greene typically draw an outsize amount of media attention.

headline: Ditching the Car and Enjoying the View on a Trip to the Berkshires
text: Evan Gottesman and his fianc√©e, Gabrielle Kleyner, were meeting friends in the Berkshires one weekend in early July. The couple, who live in Brooklyn, were trying to figure out how they would get to the rural region of western Massachusetts, which annually draws thousands of hikers, theater lovers and music aficionados with its mountains, lakes and myriad cultural centers.

headline: Surprise Deal Would Be Most Ambitious Climate Action Undertaken by U.S.
text: WASHINGTON ‚Äî The $369 billion climate and tax package forged in a surprise deal by Senate Democrats would be the most ambitious action ever taken by the United States to try to stop the planet from catastrophically overheating.

headline: In This Subway Series, the Mets Did All the Flexing
text: The final hit on Wednesday night bounced into the glove of Aaron Hicks, and of course he didn‚Äôt want it. Hicks, the Yankees‚Äô left fielder, gathered Starling Marte‚Äôs game-winning single, held it for a while and then flung it aside like a piece of gum. A ball boy retrieved it and tossed it into the crowd at Citi Field. Trash for the Yankees, treasure for the fans.

headline: Prague Gets a Reset and the Emphasis Is Local
text: Prague was justifiably popular with visitors before the pandemic, but life here often felt slightly out of whack before 2020. As a small counterbalance to an immense tragedy, the pandemic offered the city a chance for a much-needed reset. Residents had time to rediscover sites and neighborhoods that they‚Äôd long since abandoned to tourists. The sudden lack of foreign guests forced restaurant owners to refocus on customers who actually live here. Historic attractions underwent renovations. And new projects that went ahead with openings in 2020 and 2021 have made the city even more fun than before.

headline: Los Angeles Enjoys Its New Bridge a Little Too Much
text: LOS ANGELES ‚Äî Less than three weeks ago, with fireworks, crowds and the civic joy that only a new Instagram backdrop can muster, America‚Äôs second-largest city christened a stunning new $588 million landmark: a bridge that would create a ‚Äúribbon of light‚Äù between the downtown arts district and the historic bungalows of East Los Angeles.

headline: States With Abortion Bans Are Among Least Supportive for Mothers and Children
text: In Mississippi, which brought the abortion case that ended Roe v. Wade before the Supreme Court, Gov. Tate Reeves vowed that the state would now ‚Äútake every step necessary to support mothers and children.‚Äù

headline: ‚ÄòNegligent and Sexist‚Äô: Why Rape Survivors Asked Feds to Investigate N.Y.P.D.
text: By the time the U.S. Justice Department announced last month that it would investigate the New York Police Department‚Äôs handling of sex crimes, rape survivors and victim advocates had spent years pushing city and state officials to act.

headline: An Indiana Doctor Speaks Out on Abortion, and Pays a Price
text: Three weeks before the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade, Dr. Caitlin Bernard, an Indianapolis obstetrician-gynecologist, donned her white lab coat, put her infant daughter into a front-pack baby carrier and joined a few colleagues who marched to the State Capitol, hoping to deliver a letter to Gov. Eric Holcomb.

headline: They Flocked to China for Boom Times. Now They‚Äôre Thinking Twice.
text: A.H. Beard, a 123-year-old luxury mattress manufacturer based in Australia, started eyeing China around 2010. At the time, the family-owned company faced looming competition from low-cost, foreign-made mattresses in its home market. China, with its 1.4 billion consumers and a growing middle class with a taste for premium brands, seemed like a good place to expand.

headline: 13 New Books Coming in August
text: Gurnah, who received the Nobel Prize in Literature last year, often deals with themes of exile and displacement in his writing. His latest novel, set in East Africa under German rule in the 1900s, follows three characters: Ilyas, who joins the German troops; his sister, Afiya, who is raised by his best friend after he leaves; and Hamza, another former soldier who returns from the war and falls in love with Afiya.

headline: Climate Change Is Probably a Drag on Growth, but It‚Äôs Unclear How Much
text: It‚Äôs been hot out there. Like water-main-breaking, train-slowing, corn-scorching, road-buckling hot ‚Äî not to mention heat‚Äôs effects on human bodies, making it harder to work in construction and harvest crops.

headline: Tell us how the economy is affecting you.
text: How are you coping with your household expenses and your financial planning? How has the economic volatility in recent months affected you as a worker or a business owner?

headline: U.S. Economy Shows Another Decline, Fanning Recession Fears
text: A key measure of economic output fell for the second straight quarter, raising fears that the United States could be entering a recession ‚Äî or perhaps that one had already begun.

headline: How Expecting Inflation Can Actually Create More Inflation
text: To fight historic levels of inflation, the Federal Reserve this week, once again, raised interest rates, its most powerful weapon against rising prices.

headline: Shell reports record profit, again, with $11.5 billion in latest quarter.
text: Shell reported record earnings for the second consecutive quarter on Thursday, as the energy giant continues to prosper from high oil and gas prices spurred by the war in Ukraine and other factors.

headline: As Brittney Griner stands trial, Moscow says there‚Äôs no deal yet on a prisoner exchange.
text: With Russia and the United States continuing to discuss prisoner swaps that could result in the release of the basketball star Brittney Griner, Russia‚Äôs foreign ministry said on Thursday that no deal had yet been reached.

headline: A Deal, for Now
text: Many parts of federal policy shift back and forth over time. Taxes rise and fall, as do spending on anti-poverty programs and the military. If a package of policies doesn‚Äôt pass one year, it might pass in a future year, and the long-term trajectory of the United States probably won‚Äôt be affected much.

headline: Inmates Allege They Were Raped and Assaulted After Guard Was Bribed
text: Twenty-eight female detainees at an Indiana jail have alleged in two separate federal lawsuits that they were raped or assaulted last year by male detainees who paid a jail officer for access to keys to their cells.

headline: After 37 Years, the Sunny World of ‚ÄòNeighbours‚Äô Comes to an End
text: It was during a childhood bout of the chickenpox that Jon Dew happened to tune into the first episode of ‚ÄúNeighbours,‚Äù a soap opera following the lives of a group of families living in a fictional cul-de-sac in Melbourne, Australia.

headline: JetBlue and Spirit announce plan to merge, creating fifth-largest U.S. airline.
text: JetBlue Airways reached a deal to buy Spirit Airlines on Thursday, a merger that could reshape the airline industry by putting pressure on the nation‚Äôs four dominant carriers.

headline: ‚ÄòA Balance‚Äô Review: Critical Distance
text: About an hour into Yujiro Harumoto‚Äôs knotty and suspenseful morality tale ‚ÄúA Balance,‚Äù Yuko (Kumi Takiuchi), a documentary director, argues with an abortion doctor (Ryo Ikeda) that ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs moral isn‚Äôt always what‚Äôs best.‚Äù It‚Äôs a platitude that has already been tested for Yuko, whose life has become suddenly very complicated. But that test is only beginning.

headline: ‚ÄòHansan: Rising Dragon‚Äô Review: Naval Gazing
text: The dutiful war movie ‚ÄúHansan: Rising Dragon‚Äù recounts the successes of the 16th-century Korean national hero Yi Sun-shin, which were previously chronicled in the 2014 film ‚ÄúThe Admiral: Roaring Currents.‚Äù Directed by Kim Han-min, both films trumpet Admiral Yi‚Äôs savvy and courage in fending off the Japanese invaders attempting to conquer the peninsula. This time, the main event is the Battle of Hansan Island in 1592, a Korean victory that is showcased as a feat of both strategy and technology.

headline: ‚ÄòDC League of Super-Pets‚Äô Review: #ReleaseTheLassieCut
text: The animated family comedy ‚ÄúDC League of Super-Pets‚Äù proceeds from what can be described as a ‚Äúsure, why not‚Äù premise: Superman now has a Labrador retriever named Krypto the Super-Dog, voiced by Dwayne Johnson, who fights crime and has special powers. The movie combines the conventions of a comic book blockbuster with the tropes of a talking-animal flick, making it something like ‚ÄúJustice League‚Äù meets ‚ÄúShrek‚Äù ‚Äî big, loud and full of bombastic action but with an irreverent, jocular tone. The director, Jared Stern, was a writer of ‚ÄúThe Lego Batman Movie‚Äù (2017). Like that film, this one spends a lot of time gently mocking its superhero source material. When Lulu (voiced by Kate McKinnon), an evil guinea pig and the story‚Äôs megalomaniac villain, captures Clark Kent (John Krasinski), she ridicules the shoddy disguise of his alter ego: ‚ÄúA mustache, maybe, but not glasses!‚Äù

headline: ‚ÄòParadise Highway‚Äô Review: A Test of Loyalty
text: Growing up in a violent home, Sally (Juliette Binoche) only had one person to rely on: her brother, Dennis (Frank Grillo).

headline: ‚ÄòA Love Song‚Äô Review: When Moving Forward Means Looking Back
text: Framed by soaring mountains and a gleaming lake somewhere in Southwestern Colorado, a woman (Dale Dickey), wiry and weathered, catches crayfish and waits in her small camper for a special someone to arrive. The woman is Faye and, like Lito (Wes Studi), the childhood friend she hopes will respond to her invitation, she is long widowed. Maybe he, too, is ready for some company.

headline: ‚ÄòResurrection‚Äô Review: Mother of Fears
text: Somewhere near the end of ‚ÄúResurrection,‚Äù a sleek, hurtling, ridiculously entertaining horror movie from Andrew Semans, there‚Äôs a scene of such gruesomely bonkers intent that I actually gasped. And then I laughed, tickled by how easily Semans and his star, the charismatic Rebecca Hall, had persuaded me to invest in their lunatic shenanigans.

headline: ‚ÄòAli & Ava‚Äô Review: Don‚Äôt You Want to Sing Along?
text: In ‚ÄúAli & Ava‚Äù the writer-director Clio Barnard (‚ÄúThe Arbor,‚Äù ‚ÄúThe Selfish Giant‚Äù) leans into the emotional alchemy of an unexpected romance between Ali (Adeel Akhtar), a British-Pakistani D.J. who has recently separated from his wife, and Ava (Claire Rushbrook), an Irish-British teacher and mother of four.

headline: ‚ÄòVengeance‚Äô Review: A Dish Best Served With Frito Pie
text: Ben Manalowitz, who writes for The New Yorker (he‚Äôs played by B.J. Novak, who has been published in its pages), wants to break into podcasting. ‚ÄúNot every white guy in America needs to have a podcast,‚Äù someone tells him, but this white guy sees the platform as a perfect stage for his ambitions and his big thoughts about America.

headline: ‚ÄòSharp Stick‚Äô Review: The Babysitter‚Äôs Schlubs
text: Sarah Jo (Kristine Froseth), the mythical seductress at the center of ‚ÄúSharp Stick,‚Äù an uneven, uneasy fable of desire by the writer, director and performer Lena Dunham, is the kind of erotic nymph who exists only in Penthouse letters and vintage soft-core movies. A babysitter long of hair and limb but short on emotional demands, Sarah Jo ventures through modern day Los Angeles in modest floral pinafores, which she lifts above her waist in invitation. No need for conversation or dinner ‚Äî she only appears to eat plain yogurt, anyway.

headline: 4,000 Mistreated Beagles Need Homes. These Folks Are Stepping Up.
text: Hazel, a 6-year-old beagle, got scared her first night in a foster home when she played with a toy and it squeaked. She had never seen a stuffed animal or ball before. She was comfortable with water but afraid of the tub during her first bath.

headline: The Role of Art in a Time of War
text: KYIV, Ukraine ‚Äî You do not have to go far outside of Kyiv to see how the massacre of civilians and the trampling of culture still come one after the other. In Borodianka, a nucleus of Russian atrocities about 45 minutes north of here ‚Äî the drive is slower now that the bridges have been demolished ‚Äî the Palace of Culture has had its windows blown out; its concert hall is dust-caked, and the ticket booths have been ripped asunder. Halfway between the capital and the Belarusian border, I had to contort my body through twisted studs to enter the leveled Ivankiv Historical and Local History Museum, its statuary now pitted, its embroideries scorched. It is far worse further east.

headline: Who Is ‚ÄòWagatha Christie‚Äô? Let Us Explain.

headline: Here are some prisoner swaps that freed Americans.
text: The prospect of the United States exchanging a Russian prisoner for the basketball star Brittney Griner and Paul Whelan, a former Marine, is reminiscent of the fraught deals Washington orchestrated with Moscow and its allies during and after the Cold War.

headline: Which City Is Most Expensive for Renters? You Might Be Surprised.
text: Jersey City is sometimes called the sixth borough of New York City. But right now, it can claim to be first: As of June, it was the most expensive city in which to rent a home in the United States, topping famously expensive metros like San Francisco and Miami with an average rent of $5,500, according to a report by the listing portal Rent.

headline: The Fed Won‚Äôt Say the ‚ÄòR‚Äô Word
text: The Federal Reserve is continuing its aggressive campaign to cool inflation, even as the economy begins to slow. The U.S. central bank raised interest rates yesterday ‚Äî this time by three-quarters of a percentage point ‚Äî for the fourth time this year. Investors cheered the move, with the S&P 500 rising nearly 3 percent by the end of the day. Futures markets suggest stocks will open slightly lower today. The Fed‚Äôs benchmark short-term interest rate is now as high as 2.5 percent, up from near-zero in March.

headline: Is California Enjoying a Reprieve From Extreme Heat?
text: As a heat wave baked much of the United States last week, a Bay Area meteorologist shared on Twitter a map of high temperatures expected across the nation.

headline: Chess Replay: You Versus Kasparov
text: This is Chess Replay, an interactive puzzle based on a historic chess game. As a solver, you embody a famous player during a critical game in his or her career. A new edition of this puzzle is published each week on Thursdays.

headline: Why Is My Sister Telling People About My Miscarriage?
text: I had a miscarriage three weeks ago. My husband and I are gutted. Still, I was relieved (if you can call it that) that we lost the pregnancy early enough that very few people knew about it ‚Äî just my mother, my sister and my best friend. I thought: At least we can grieve in private. But my sister is telling people about my miscarriage, even posting about it on social media. She says she has the right to post whatever she wants, particularly if the medical care I received may be threatened in some states. I am furious that she is broadcasting my tragedy! I want her to stop, but I don‚Äôt have the strength to fight with her now. What should I do?

headline: The Instagram Chefs and Bakers Turning to Brick and Mortar
text: Welcome to the T List, a newsletter from the editors of T Magazine. Each week, we share things we‚Äôre eating, wearing, listening to or coveting now. Sign up here to find us in your inbox every Wednesday. And you can always reach us at tlist@nytimes.com.

headline: At the Serpentine, a Show of Nature‚Äôs Healing Power
text: It all started with extinction. An Extinction Marathon, actually: 12 hours of people talking about how species die out and what happens when they do. Stewart Brand, founder of the Whole Earth Catalog. Gustav Metzger, the pioneer of auto-destructive art. Adam Curtis, the British documentarian. The documentary filmmaker Laura Poitras. Gilbert & George. William Gibson. Yoko Ono. The list goes on.

headline: A Test Case for Australia‚Äôs Broad New Law Against Foreign Meddling
text: MELBOURNE, Australia ‚Äî Australia, gripped by growing anxiety about China‚Äôs influence on its internal affairs, introduced sweeping legislation a few years ago to prevent foreign interference, but until now the laws have never been tested in court.

headline: Pope Francis, Slowed by Aging, Finds Lessons in Frailty
text: LAC STE. ANNE, Alberta ‚Äî When Pope Francis landed in Canada this week, he lumbered out of a car on the tarmac, hobbled with difficulty to an awaiting wheelchair and froze in place as cameras shot at close range the spectacle of an aide adjusting the pontiff‚Äôs footrests.

headline: 8 Dead as Flash Flooding Swamps Parts of Kentucky
text: At least eight people died and others were rescued from rooftops on Thursday after heavy rains across southeastern Kentucky touched off what the governor said was ‚Äúone of the worst, most devastating flooding events‚Äù in state history.

headline: Memoir Writing Is Always an Act of Translation
text: The best essay collections unfold the tensions inherent in ethics, intimate relationships and art, and in the process offer a portrait of the writer‚Äôs mind. Marcia DeSanctis, an award-winning travel writer and longtime news producer, opens hers, A HARD PLACE TO LEAVE: Stories From a Restless Life (313 pp., Travelers‚Äô Tales, $27.95), with an episode in which a younger version of herself is on assignment in Cold War Moscow. Upon returning to her room with a fever, she encounters a hotel employee named Masha ‚Äî part concierge, part Kremlin informant ‚Äî trying on her clothes. DeSanctis reacts with pity rather than anger and soon the interloper is toweling the guest‚Äôs forehead and tucking her in. Before departing, DeSanctis agrees to bring Masha an illustrated edition of Pushkin‚Äôs fairy tales on her next trip. For the next 20 years, she returns to the hotel with the book, doomed never to find Masha. She recalls an embrace they shared at the end of their meeting: ‚ÄúI had recognized her perfume ‚Äî Amazone ‚Äî because it had come from my own bottle.‚Äù Our narrator has made a stunning entrance, proved herself intrepid and empathetic, gifted with the dispassionate gaze of a born observer.

headline: West Virginia Punishes Banks That It Says Don‚Äôt Support Coal
text: West Virginia on Thursday morning announced that five major financial institutions, including Goldman Sachs and JPMorgan, would be barred from doing business with the state because they have stopped supporting the coal industry.

headline: ‚ÄòPrinces Can Be Asian, Too‚Äô: A Dancer Breaks Barriers in Ballet
text: On a sleepy summer morning recently, a group of about 50 dancers from New York City Ballet gathered inside a sunny rehearsal studio at Lincoln Center and stretched. They had come from three weeks of rest and were back in company class, preparing for a tour in upstate New York. Some carried energy drinks and bottles of hand sanitizer; others brought their dogs, who settled into naps under the barre as the dancers began a series of exercises ‚Äî pli√©s, tendus, jumps and pirouettes.

headline: ‚ÄòHow to Please a Woman‚Äô Review: The Service Industry
text: The Australian comedy ‚ÄúHow to Please a Woman‚Äù hinges on an amusing high concept: a company that provides house cleaning and orgasms for women. This hook piques curiosity ‚Äî at least enough for a coy eyebrow raise. Light intrigue is often not enough, though, and in this case, the movie strains to sustain charm.

headline: ‚ÄòHypochondriac‚Äô Review: A Mother of All Breakdowns
text: In the psychological thriller ‚ÄúHypochondriac,‚Äù life and all its horrors begin with Mother. When the film‚Äôs protagonist, Will (played as a child by Ian Inigo), was young, his mother (Marlene Forte) suffered from psychosis. Her illness manifested in intense, violent spells. She would scream and hurt herself. One of Will‚Äôs most indelible memories is of his mother strangling him as a boy.

headline: German Inflation Hits 8.5 Percent, Again Driven by High Energy Prices
text: Annual inflation in Germany increased in July to 8.5 percent, from 8.2 percent the previous month, as further cuts to natural gas deliveries from Russia created concern that already record energy prices will climb even higher.

headline: Why Do I Sweat So Much in My Sleep?
text: Q: Why do I sweat in my sleep?

headline: Bernard Cribbins, British Actor Known for ‚ÄòDoctor Who,‚Äô Is Dead at 93
text: Bernard Cribbins, a British actor who had roles on ‚ÄúDoctor Who‚Äù and ‚ÄúFawlty Towers‚Äù and whose contributions to children‚Äôs programs delighted young audiences over a career that spanned seven decades, has died. He was 93.

headline: Democratic Lawmakers Want F.T.C. to Go After Gun Ads
text: A new bill being introduced in Congress on Thursday seeks to use the powers of the Federal Trade Commission to limit the spread of guns. The bill would allow the F.T.C. to investigate gunmakers for deceptive advertising practices. That is something the agency is charged with doing for all industries, but has been reluctant to do so with gun manufacturers, which has long received extra protections from Washington, the DealBook newsletter reports.

headline: Sona Movsesian Leans on The Rock, Cher and Mister Rogers
text: ‚ÄúThe World‚Äôs Worst Assistant,‚Äù a new memoir by Sona Movsesian, recounts what happens when an ambitious young woman who excelled at both the Burger King drive-through and the NBC page program managed to turn things around when she landed a job as Conan O‚ÄôBrien‚Äôs assistant ‚Äî a deal she sealed by asking if she could lie down during the interview.

headline: What the surprise deal means for climate
text: It could be a game changer.

headline: ‚ÄòBlue Island‚Äô Review: In Hong Kong, the Past Is Present
text: In ‚ÄúBlue Island,‚Äù a hybrid of documentary and dramatization from the director Chan Tze Woon, real-life students from contemporary Hong Kong perform re-enactments of the political struggles of previous generations.

headline: Why does Ukraine fight? So it can exist, Zelensky says.
text: KYIV ‚Äî With Russian forces in control of 20 percent of his nation‚Äôs territory, tens of thousands of his citizens killed and scores of cities and towns reduced to ashes, President Volodymyr Zelensky on Thursday asked Ukrainian citizens and the wider world to pause and remember why they fight.

headline: Should Red Wines Be Served Cool?
text: Wine is a joyous, never-ending education, as I relearn every month in Wine School. Even so, the lessons were humbling to me over the last few weeks as we examined how serving temperature affects red wines.

headline: Dry German Riesling: An Eternal Conundrum
text: Wine writers can be tireless, or perhaps tiresome, in recommending the virtues of perennially unloved wines.

headline: ‚ÄòMedusa‚Äô Review: Liberated Women
text: In ‚ÄúMedusa,‚Äù a pop music-scored spooky story about women‚Äôs liberation, a group of churchgoing gals in Brazil play Christian Stepford Wives by day, and by night, rove the streets wearing white masks, terrorizing women they deem tramps into repentance.

headline: ‚ÄòA Stone in the Mosaic‚Äô: A Director Enters the House of Wagner
text: New productions of Wagner‚Äôs ‚ÄúRing‚Äù cycle, a 16-hour epic taking place over four evenings, are always a highly anticipated event, and even more so when they take place at the annual Bayreuth Festival.

headline: A.I. Predicts the Shape of Nearly Every Protein Known to Science
text: In 2020, an artificial intelligence lab called DeepMind unveiled technology that could predict the shape of proteins ‚Äî the microscopic mechanisms that drive the behavior of the human body and all other living things.

headline: Iran Ramps Up Drone Exports, Signaling Global Ambitions
text: Iran has made steady advances in the design and production of military drones in recent years, and has stepped up their transfer to militant groups across the Middle East as it seeks to shift the dynamics of battlefields from Yemen to Gaza.

The new Forward Party announced by the former presidential candidate Andrew Yang, the former governor Christine Todd Whitman and the former congressman David Jolly is doomed to failure. headline: Help! My Lost Luggage Wasn‚Äôt Delivered for 12 Days. I Want Restitution.
text: I regularly travel between Houston and Atyrau, Kazakhstan (via Newark and Amsterdam) for work, taking United for the first two legs and Air Astana for the third. The trip is long but the routine is always the same: check your luggage in Texas and pick it up upon arrival. But this past January, United didn‚Äôt follow the routine: When I boarded in Newark, I saw on the United app that at least one of my bags had stayed behind. I alerted the flight attendant, who alerted the gate staff, who in turn suggested I get off the plane, get my luggage and fly the next day. But there are limited connections, I had to get to work and I had no idea where my second bag was. (Also lost, it turns out.) Thirteen days and countless calls and letters later, Astana delivered my luggage in Kazakhstan. United eventually offered me $150 in compensation. I believe this is not nearly enough, especially considering their policy on ‚Äúdelayed bags‚Äù says I may be eligible for $1,500 per bag if they can‚Äôt find my luggage in five days. Can you help? ‚Äî Laura, Missouri City, Texas

headline: In Compromise, the Climate Left May Be Vindicated
text: The deal, if it holds, is very big, several times as large as anything on climate the United States passed into law before. The architects and supporters of the $369 billion in climate and clean-energy provisions in Joe Manchin‚Äôs Inflation Reduction Act of 2022, announced Wednesday, are already calculating that it could reduce American carbon emissions by 40 percent, compared with 2005 levels, by 2030. That‚Äôs close enough to President Biden‚Äôs pledge of 50 percent that exhausted advocates seem prepared to count it as a victory, if a somewhat mixed one that still falls short of the demands of scientists and the Paris Agreement. headline: How is monkeypox spread?
text: The monkeypox virus can spread from person to person through close physical contact with infectious lesions or pustules, by touching items ‚Äî like clothing or bedding ‚Äî that previously touched the rash, or via the respiratory droplets produced by coughing or sneezing.

headline: How is monkeypox treated?
text: After a diagnosis, monkeypox treatment mainly involves managing symptoms, said Dr. Bernard Camins, the medical director for infection prevention at the Mount Sinai Health System. Patients with anal or rectal lesions may experience a lot of pain, especially while defecating, and in those cases, a doctor may prescribe pain killers or recommend stool softeners and shallow sitz baths, used to relieve pain or itchiness in the genital area, he said. Patients with sores in their mouth may have difficulty swallowing and can use medication to help. Some may develop secondary bacterial infections and require antibiotic treatment, especially if they have large, open lesions.

headline: Recession? Not for Big Tech.
text: When the president, the treasury secretary and other Biden administration officials insisted this week that the American economy is not currently in a recession, they were mocked for weaseling out of bad news on a technicality. The Commerce Department announced on Thursday that the broadest measure of economic activity, gross domestic product, fell for a second quarter in a row ‚Äî meeting a widely held, though unofficial, definition of recession. It is true, as the Biden folks argued, that the nation‚Äôs official recession arbiter, the National Bureau of Economic Research, has yet to call one, because it relies on many more signals. Still, it sure sounded as if the Biden team was splitting hairs.

headline: Followers of Iraqi Cleric Occupy Parliament Again, Demanding Reforms
text: BASRA, Iraq ‚Äî Iraqi protesters loyal to the nationalist Shiite cleric Moktada al-Sadr thronged Baghdad‚Äôs fortified Green Zone for the second time in a week on Saturday to prevent the formation of a new government. They scaled concrete barriers and pushed past security forces to get into the Iraqi Parliament, filling the empty seats of representatives and shouting their support for Mr. Sadr: ‚ÄúSon of Mohammed, take us wherever you want.‚Äù

headline: You Want to Clean Up the House? Same Here
text: A lot of you responded quite strongly to last week‚Äôs newsletter on defanging the Senate of most of its power. Not a negative response, necessarily ‚Äî you just had a lot of ideas! And as it happens, I agree with many of those ideas. Perhaps the most common one is related less to the Senate than to the House of Representatives. Many of you were adamant that if the goal is to bring the locus of policymaking back to the House, then the House, too, must be more democratic than it is, and that part of making the House more democratic is ending partisan gerrymandering.

headline: Alex Jones Puts Company Behind Infowars Empire Into Bankruptcy
text: AUSTIN, Texas ‚Äî Facing a potential $150 million judgment and two more damages trials for defaming the families of people killed in the 2012 Sandy Hook school shooting, the conspiracy broadcaster Alex Jones on Friday put his Infowars empire into Chapter 11 bankruptcy.

headline: Prince Charles‚Äôs Charity Accepted Millions From Family of Osama bin Laden
text: LONDON ‚Äî Prince Charles, heir to the British throne, faced new scrutiny over the financing of his charities on Saturday after a report found that one organization had accepted a donation of 1 million pounds ($1.21 million) from the family of Osama bin Laden.

headline: Why? Well, Why Not?
text: SUNDAY PUZZLE ‚Äî Jesse Goldberg is a software engineer in San Francisco. This is his third crossword for The Times (and his second Sunday puzzle ‚Äî his first, from almost exactly a year ago, was lovely and pulled quotations from a famous French kitchen, if you missed it). Many solvers will be familiar with this puzzle-loving constructor‚Äôs daily routine: Solve Wordle, check Wordlebot, play Spelling Bee, solve the crossword, in that order.

headline: Flooding Across Iran Leaves Dozens Dead
text: Days of heavy rain triggered flash floods and landslides across most of Iran‚Äôs provinces, marking the nation‚Äôs deadliest water-related episode in a decade.

headline: ‚ÄòWe Keep Getting Hit‚Äô: Flooded Kentucky Grows Weary After Another Natural Disaster
text: HAZARD, Ky. ‚Äî Firefighters and National Guard crews have swarmed into eastern Kentucky after days of deadly flooding, rescuing by the hundreds people who found themselves trapped in the perilous water.

headline: A 17-Year-Old Is Killed and 4 Are Hospitalized in River Tubing Stabbing
text: One person was killed and four others were hospitalized on Saturday after they were stabbed in their mid-sections while tubing on the Apple River in Wisconsin, a popular summer spot that attracts visitors from across the region, the authorities said.

headline: Corrections: July 31, 2022
text: An article on Page 24 this weekend about Barbados includes an outdated reference to the country‚Äôs publicly traded debt. BlackRock is one of the largest holders of the debt; it is no longer the largest holder of the debt. A picture caption with the article misstates the volume of coconuts a recycling center receives each week. The facility receives more than 100 tons each week, not eight. Another picture caption with the article misstates part of the name of a research center. It is the Walkers Institute for Regenerative Research, Education and Design not the Walkers Institute for Regenerative Research and Design.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
text: SUNDAY ‚Äî Hi busy bees! Welcome to today‚Äôs Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen‚Äôs weekly humor column, ‚ÄúDiary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.‚Äù

headline: ‚ÄòUnfortunately, the Packet Got Caught in the Branch of a Tree‚Äô
text: Dear Diary:

headline: As Latin America Shifts Left, Leaders Face a Short Honeymoon
text: BOGOT√Å, Colombia ‚Äî In Chile, a tattooed former student activist won the presidency with a pledge to oversee the most profound transformation of Chilean society in decades, widening the social safety net and shifting the tax burden to the wealthy.

headline: Kansas Abortion Vote Tests Political Energy in Post-Roe America
text: OLATHE, Kan. ‚Äî In the final days before Kansans decide whether to remove abortion rights protections from their State Constitution, the politically competitive Kansas City suburbs have become hotbeds of activism.

headline: What‚Äôs a Critic Doing in a War Zone?
text: A news organization needs all sorts of journalists and professionals to cover a war zone effectively: reporters and photographers who can gather information, local journalists and interpreters to gain access to sources, security experts and drivers to help everyone stay safe. One person you almost never need is a critic.

headline: Trained, Armed and Ready. To Teach Kindergarten.
text: RITTMAN, Ohio ‚Äî Mandi, a kindergarten teacher in Ohio, had already done what she could to secure her classroom against a gunman.

headline: When There‚Äôs Arsenic in the Water, but ‚ÄòWe Have Nowhere to Go‚Äô
text: THERMAL, Calif. ‚Äî Three times a week, Pascual Campos Ochoa, 26, loads up a duffel bag with a brown fleece blanket and a plastic container of oatmeal. A van picks him up from the dusty trailer park where he lives ‚Äî where stray dogs wander among the carcasses of old cars and working electricity is not a given ‚Äî and takes him to a clinic for kidney dialysis.

headline: Quotation of the Day: Trained, Armed and Ready. To Teach Kindergarten.
text: ‚ÄúThe last thing I want is for people to think we are just a bunch of gunslinging teachers who want an excuse to carry guns in schools....I love my kids. I‚Äôm going to do everything I can to keep them safe.‚Äù

headline: The Problem With Survivor Memoirs
text: Overcoming adversity is a classic plot arc among recent blockbuster coming-of-age memoirs ‚Äî from Tara Westover‚Äôs ‚ÄúEducated‚Äù to Viola Davis‚Äôs ‚ÄúFinding Me‚Äù to Cheryl Strayed‚Äôs ‚ÄúWild.‚Äù It‚Äôs a satisfying story type, and often a deceptively tidy one. With her debut memoir, ‚ÄúAcceptance,‚Äù Emi Nietfeld enters the genre ambivalently, paying careful attention to what gets elided in stories like hers: the cruelty of a society that makes survival contingent on excellence.

headline: Leave My Disability Out of Your Anti-Abortion Propaganda
text: Thirty years ago, when my mother was pregnant, an ultrasound revealed troubling abnormalities: the fetus‚Äôs organs were misarranged. This condition, she was told by her doctor, correlated with a wide variety of disabilities that could cause the baby to die at birth. The doctor told my mother that she could seek an abortion. She wanted her to know her options.

headline: Will the Biggest Publisher in the United States Get Even Bigger?
text: When the largest publisher in the country, Penguin Random House, struck a deal in the fall of 2020 to acquire its rival Simon & Schuster, publishing executives and antitrust experts predicted that the merger would draw intense scrutiny from government regulators.

headline: In ‚ÄòYoga,‚Äô Emmanuel Carr√®re Tries, Fitfully, to Capture Thought‚Äôs Flow
text: The first sentence of Emmanuel Carr√®re‚Äôs novel ‚ÄúYoga‚Äù outlines the whole book, so I give nothing away by saying that it is about trying to write what Carr√®re calls ‚Äúa subtle little book on yoga,‚Äù an effort derailed, over the course of four years, by terrorism, the refugee crisis, the loss of his editor and a ‚Äúmelancholic depression‚Äù so deep that he is committed to a psychiatric hospital. Yet it is also a book about yoga, about the ways in which meditation means, to borrow a phrase from Lenin, as Carr√®re does, ‚Äúworking with the available material.‚Äù

headline: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
text: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

headline: A New Yorker‚Äôs Opposition to Abortion Clouds Her House Re-Election Bid
text: As the lone Republican in the New York City congressional delegation, Representative Nicole Malliotakis has adopted certain stances that would make her an understandable outlier in a deeply Democratic city.

headline: Gen Z Knows What It Wants From Employers. And Employers Want Them.
text: Danielle Ross is a 26-year-old who lives in a small town in upstate New York. She describes herself as artistic and creative. She paints in her free time, and she has worked as a mermaid for children‚Äôs parties, swimming in a tail she made herself.

headline: United Auto Workers Seek to Shed a Legacy of Corruption
text: DETROIT ‚Äî For the United Auto Workers, the last five years have been one of the most troubling chapters in the union‚Äôs storied history.

headline: A Cyberattack Illuminates the Shaky State of Student Privacy
text: The software that many school districts use to track students‚Äô progress can record extremely confidential information on children: ‚ÄúIntellectual disability.‚Äù ‚ÄúEmotional Disturbance.‚Äù ‚ÄúHomeless.‚Äù ‚ÄúDisruptive.‚Äù ‚ÄúDefiance.‚Äù ‚ÄúPerpetrator.‚Äù ‚ÄúExcessive Talking.‚Äù ‚ÄúShould attend tutoring.‚Äù

headline: A Baseball Museum That Is ‚ÄòBetter Than True‚Äô
text: LOS ANGELES ‚Äî Now on display at the Los Angeles Central Library through November in an exhibit titled ‚ÄúSomething in Common.‚Äù There is a San Diego Chicken costume, a half-smoked cigar from Babe Ruth that likely ‚Äî maybe? possibly? ‚Äî was spirited from a Philadelphia brothel in 1924 and a baseball signed by Mother Teresa. The real Mother Teresa? Well ‚Ä¶ maybe not.

headline: Polo Season in the Hamptons
text: What‚Äôs summer in the Hamptons without a little polo? On July 23, Christie Brinkley hosted the annual Polo Hamptons match and cocktail party at the Maria and Kenneth Fishel Estate in Bridgehampton, N.Y. The horse-loving crowd came ready to cheer in floral dresses and wide-brimmed floppy hats.

headline: Pelosi Heads for Singapore, but Is Silent on Taiwan
text: Speaker Nancy Pelosi was expected to appear in Singapore on Monday as part of a closely watched tour of Asia that has stoked fears, including at the highest levels of the American government, of dangerously heightened tensions with China over the possibility that she would make a stop in Taiwan.

headline: In the I.C.U., Dying Sometimes Feels Like a Choice
text: My patient‚Äôs wife had just one question: Was her husband dying?

headline: Eric Greitens May Just Get What He Deserves
text: On Tuesday, Republican voters in Missouri will send a signal to G.O.P. leaders nationwide about what they will and won‚Äôt accept in a top candidate in the party‚Äôs current, Trumpian era: Namely, do they want a Senate nominee who exists in a perpetual swirl of scandal, including fresh accusations of domestic violence?

headline: The Sunday Read: ‚ÄòInside the Push to Diversify the Book Business‚Äô
text: For generations, America‚Äôs major publishers focused almost entirely on white readers. Now a new cadre of executives is trying to open up the industry.

headline: We Are Living in Richard Nixon‚Äôs America. Escaping It Won‚Äôt Be Easy.
text: It seems so na√Øve now, that moment in 2020 when Democratic insiders started to talk of Joe Biden as a transformational figure. But there were reasons to believe. To hold off a pandemic-induced collapse, the federal government had injected $2.2 trillion into the economy, much of it in New Deal-style relief. The summer‚Äôs protests altered the public‚Äôs perception of race‚Äôs role in the criminal justice system. And analyses were pointing to Republican losses large enough to clear the way for the biggest burst of progressive legislation since the 1960s.

headline: The Spread of Book Banning
text: Book-banning attempts have grown in the U.S. over the past few years from relatively isolated battles to a broader effort aimed at works about sexual and racial identity. Alexandra Alter and Elizabeth Harris cover the publishing industry. I spoke to them about what‚Äôs behind this trend.

headline: Fidel Ramos, Philippine President Who Broke With Marcos, Dies at 94
text: Fidel V. Ramos, a military leader who succeeded Corazon C. Aquino as president of the Philippines, and from 1992 to 1998 presided over robust economic growth, exceptional political stability and reconciliations with Communist insurgents and Muslim separatists,  died on Sunday in Manila.  He was 94.

headline: This Week in Business: Recession Fears
text: Wednesday was not a great day for the company formerly known as Facebook. First came a lawsuit from the Federal Trade Commission and then, the company announced its first-ever revenue decline since it went public. The F.T.C., led by Lina Khan, one of Big Tech‚Äôs biggest critics, is suing Meta to block it from buying Within, a virtual reality company that would aid the leap by Meta‚Äôs chief executive, Mark Zuckerberg, into the metaverse. In the suit, the F.T.C. accused Meta of trying to buy a company that it should have to compete with. Meta responded that the agency had put together a case ‚Äúbased on ideology and speculation.‚Äù Later, the company reported that its second-quarter revenue was down 1 percent from the previous year, results that Mr. Zuckerberg put into the context of an ‚Äúeconomic downturn that will have a broad impact‚Äù on digital advertising. Still, he appears relentless in advancing his vision for the next era of his business, and he has told employees that anyone who is not on board can leave.

headline: What to Cook This Week
text: Good morning. One of the great things to eat in New York City right now is a dish called celery Victor, served at Inga‚Äôs Bar in Brooklyn Heights. It‚Äôs a cold salad based on one that came out of a San Francisco hotel more than a century ago: braised stalks of celery in vinaigrette, with anchovies. At Inga‚Äôs Bar, fresh celery, greens and herbs join the plate, along with big chunks of Parmesan and dabs of pickled mustard seeds.

headline: A Nigerian Street Vendor Is Beaten to Death in Italy as Witnesses Stand By
text: ROME ‚Äî In May 2021 Alika Ogorchukwu, a 39-year-old Nigerian living in Italy, was hit by a car while he was riding his bicycle, an accident that forced him to use a crutch to move around.

headline: For American Girls, Many Meanings
text: To the Editor:

headline: One of Ukraine‚Äôs richest businessmen is killed in the port city of Mykolaiv.
text: MYKOLAIV ‚Äî The first air raid alarm rang out over Mykolaiv at 1:01 a.m. and for the next four hours, explosions thundered as Russian missiles rained down on this already battered southern port city.

headline: McKinney Fire Growing Quickly in Northern California
text: A raging wildfire in Klamath National Forest in California, fueled by strong winds from thunderstorms and high temperatures, grew to more than 51,000 acres.

headline: Food Is Identity. For Korean Chefs Who Were Adopted, It‚Äôs Complicated.
text: LOS ANGELES ‚Äî Katianna Hong is tinkering with her grandmother‚Äôs matzo ball soup for a second time. The first time, she adapted it for a staff meal while she was executive chef at the Charter Oak in the Napa Valley.

headline: In Libyan Town Searching for Justice, a Struggle Even to Find Graves
text: TARHUNA, Libya ‚Äî It is hard to find a starker illustration of the failures of Libya‚Äôs political leaders than Tarhuna, a town set between the Mediterranean coast and the desert where seven brothers from the Kani family and their militiamen detained, tortured and killed hundreds of residents in a five-year reign of terror.

headline: Covid. A Coma. A Stroke. Jos√© Parl√° Returns From the Edge.
text: DETROIT ‚Äî During the three months last year that the artist Jos√© Parl√° was in a medically induced coma after contracting Covid-19, he had vivid dreams that he later found difficult to process: managing a Miami hotel circa 1980 and navigating a kidnapping plot involving his brother and the Hong Kong triads. ‚ÄúI was perceiving these dreams not as dreams but as memories,‚Äù he said. ‚ÄúEvents that I believed had happened but weren‚Äôt real.‚Äù

headline: Review: ‚ÄòCat on a Hot Tin Roof‚Äô Knows Its Good Angles
text: We know from his personal writing (and context clues) that Tennessee Williams was into trade: hypermasculine men who are just as likely to have sex with men as they are to break their necks. These seductive brutes are strewn throughout his work, just as essential and memorable as his fading belles. There is no Blanche without Stanley.

headline: Bill Russell, Who Transformed Pro Basketball, Dies at 88
text: Bill Russell, whose defensive athleticism at center changed the face of pro basketball and propelled the Boston Celtics to 11 N.B.A. championships, the final two when he became the first Black head coach in a major American sports league, died on Sunday. He was 88.

headline: McKinney Fire Becomes California‚Äôs Largest of 2022, Burning 51,000 Acres
text: A fast-growing wildfire fueled by strong winds from thunderstorms and high temperatures in Northern California has grown to more than 51,000 acres in two days, becoming the state‚Äôs largest wildfire so far this year and forcing evacuations in rural neighborhoods.

headline: The Red Cross says it still doesn‚Äôt have access to the prison camp where dozens of Ukrainians died.
text: The International Committee of the Red Cross has not received confirmation that it will be allowed to visit the detention center where dozens of Ukrainian prisoners were killed in an explosion, the organization said in a statement on Sunday.

headline: For India‚Äôs Effort to Ban Disposable Plastic, One State Offers a Playbook
text: CHENNAI, India ‚Äî Amul Vasudevan, a vegetable hawker in the southern Indian state of Tamil Nadu, thought she was going to go out of business.

headline: Man With Loaded Assault Rifle Arrested Outside Iranian Writer‚Äôs Home
text: A man was arrested on Friday after he was found with a loaded AK-47 assault rifle outside the Brooklyn home of an Iranian American journalist who was the target of an international kidnapping plot said to be orchestrated by an Iranian intelligence network last year, according to the journalist, a court document and a person briefed on the matter.

headline: Banana Boat Recalls Hair and Scalp Sunscreen Over Low Levels of Carcinogen
text: The parent company of Banana Boat recalled batches of a sunscreen spray because they contained trace levels of benzene, a carcinogen, the U.S. Food and Drug Administration said. Consumers were urged to stop using the products.

headline: ‚ÄòEverything Has Healed‚Äô: Jacob deGrom Is Finally Ready
text: After what will have been a wait of 391 days, one of the best pitchers in baseball is finally expected to take the mound in a major league game. Jacob deGrom, a two-time winner of the National League‚Äôs Cy Young Award, who last pitched for the Mets on July 7, 2021, is scheduled to make his return from injury Tuesday night against the Nationals in Washington.

headline: A Town‚Äôs Housing Crisis Exposes a ‚ÄòHouse of Cards‚Äô
text: HAILEY, Idaho ‚Äî Near the private jets that shuttle billionaires to their opulent Sun Valley getaways, Ana Ramon Bartolome and her family have spent this summer living in the only place available to them: behind a blue tarp in a sweltering two-car garage.

headline: As Ukraine Orders Civilians to Evacuate the East, Residents Face a Grim Choice
text: DONETSK PROVINCE, Ukraine ‚Äî Thuds from the artillery pounding Ukraine‚Äôs embattled east reverberated in the distance, yet it was the shouts of playing children on a recent afternoon that echoed across the yard near the front line.

headline: Nichelle Nichols, Lieutenant Uhura on ‚ÄòStar Trek,‚Äô Dies at 89
text: Nichelle Nichols, the actress revered by ‚ÄúStar Trek‚Äù fans everywhere for her role as Lieutenant Uhura, the communications officer on the starship U.S.S. Enterprise, died on Saturday in Silver City, N.M. She was 89.

headline: Last Conviction in Salem Witch Trials Is Cleared 329 Years Later
text: Elizabeth Johnson Jr. is ‚Äî officially ‚Äî not a witch.

headline: Your Monday Briefing: Civilians in Donetsk Are Urged to Evacuate
text: President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine ordered hundreds of thousands of civilians living in Donetsk province to evacuate their homes after months of relentless Russian bombardment.

headline: Former Kremlin adviser is hospitalized in Europe.
text: Anatoly Chubais, who resigned as a top Kremlin adviser shortly after Russia‚Äôs invasion of Ukraine, was hospitalized on Sunday in a western European country in critical condition with the symptoms of a rare neurological disorder. Mr. Chubais had suddenly grown numb in his hands and legs, his wife, Avodtya Smirnova, told the Russian journalist Ksenia Sobchak.

headline: Morning Person
text: MONDAY PUZZLE ‚Äî Welcome and congratulations to today‚Äôs constructor, Garrett Chalfin, on making his New York Times Crossword debut as a rising high school senior. Mr. Chalfin joins the growing ranks of constructors who debuted as teenagers, becoming the 59th to do so.
